paragraph1: Pip's coming-of-age story unfolds with a unique blend of introspection and subtle adventure, capturing her journey as a late bloomer navigating the complexities of adolescence. Unlike her friends, who eagerly dive into animated discussions about crushes and relationships, Pip often feels out of sync, her naivety shielding her from the potential threats others easily perceive. Her path to personal growth is not marked by dramatic awakenings or losses of innocence but rather by a series of gentle revelations as she explores new experiences and gradually defines her own interests and boundaries. Pip's investigative lens is focused through Instagram, her keen eye for detail capturing the essence of quaint coffee shops and the vibrant pulse of teen fashion. This digital aesthetic mirrors the show's self-aware, stylish presentation, breathing new life into familiar coming-of-age themes. As Pip delves into this visual world, her story becomes a fresh tapestry of discovery, resonating with both humor and heartfelt moments.
paragraph2: Coming-of-age stories often use road trips as the mechanism of and the yardstick for maturing, and this often feels like a road-trip saga, only with suspects instead of pit stops. Pip is a late bloomer who feels left out of her friends’ crush chats, and she isn’t always aware of the obvious-to-others lurking sexual menace. Her pursuits cause her to grow and to grow up, not through miserable loss-of-innocence tragedies but rather through navigating the unfamiliar, through discovering what her interests and limits really are. Much of Pip’s investigatory technique revolves around Instagram, and the show itself often toys with Instagrammy aesthetics — with quaint coffee shops with big square windows, with funky androgynous teen fashion, with colors that pop just a little harder than they do in the natural world. It’s part of the show’s lush sense of self-awareness and savvy elegance, part of what makes its trek across well-worn territory feel like fresh first steps.

paragraph1: At Cafe St. Honoré, nestled in the New Town area north of George Street, Neil Forbes brings a masterful touch to traditional Scottish cuisine with a French flair. As a seasoned Scottish chef, Forbes crafts hearty dishes that showcase the country's rich ingredients, such as the tender confit partridge leg. The cafe offers an à la carte menu, as well as a set menu that provides excellent value for both lunch and dinner. For those looking to immerse themselves in Edinburgh's whisky culture, the Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street is a popular destination. However, for a more intimate and unique whisky tasting experience, the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on Queen Street is a hidden gem, offering single-cask bottlings with creative names that are sure to delight even the most discerning palates.
paragraph2: In a lane north of elegant George Street, in the central New Town area, Cafe St. Honoré, a longstanding locals’ favorite, is overseen by the veteran Scottish chef Neil Forbes. Instead of the small shared plates that dominate modern dining, find hearty dishes of Scottish produce cooked with French finesse, such as a confit partridge leg sourced from the nearby Borders region (£32). Alongside a revolving à la carte menu, there is also a good-value set menu (£28.50 for two courses, £36 for three) at both lunch and dinner. Whisky is big business in Edinburgh, typified by the glitzy multistory Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street. For a more intimate tasting, opt for the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on nearby Queen Street, where one-off bottlings of whisky from a single cask carry eccentric titles inspired by their tasting notes.

paragraph1: In California, the Democratic-majority Legislature is poised to pass a significant bill by the month's end, which will subsequently be sent to Governor Gavin Newsom. Newsom has yet to reveal his position on the legislation, which, if signed, would place California at the forefront of tech regulation, surpassing federal efforts. Historically, California has played a pivotal role in shaping U.S. tech consumer protections, with previous laws setting precedents. However, the current A.I. bill has stirred opposition, particularly from those concerned about its impact on the sharing of open-source software code by major tech companies. Critics argue that such restrictions could stifle innovation and growth among smaller A.I. firms. Despite amendments aimed at alleviating some of these concerns, apprehension remains within the open-source community. Chris Nicholson, a partner at Page One Ventures, underscores this unease, noting that the bill could potentially impede A.I. development. As California once again stands on the brink of influencing national tech policy, the debate continues to intensify.
paragraph2: The Democratic-majority Legislature is expected to pass the bill by the end of the month. It would then go to Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has not said whether he supports it. If the bill is signed, California will again be a step ahead of the federal government on tech regulation. California’s Legislature has helped shape U.S. tech consumer protections with a 2020 privacy law that curbed the collection of user data and a 2022 child online safety law. Opponents of the A.I. bill have argued that it would discourage tech giants from sharing the software code underlying their artificial intelligence with other businesses and software developers — a practice known as open source. They believe this would choke the progress of smaller A.I. companies. While the amendments alleviated some issues and improved on the earlier version, “the open source software community still rightly has concerns that this will be a damper on A.I. development,” said Chris Nicholson, a partner with Page One Ventures, a venture capital firm.

paragraph1: As schools continue to invest heavily in technology, artificial intelligence companies are aggressively marketing their products to educators, touting promises of enhanced student learning and streamlined administrative tasks. However, experts warn that the rush to adopt A.I. in educational settings poses significant risks, particularly when it comes to the use of taxpayer dollars. Concerns about student data privacy, the accuracy of A.I.-driven assessments, and the potential conflict with efforts to reduce children's screen time have raised red flags among educators and researchers. "Schools need to be cautious and critically assess the capabilities and limitations of A.I. before making significant investments," advises Natalie Milman, a professor of educational technology at George Washington University. Despite these concerns, companies like AllHere, which has developed an A.I.-powered attendance tracking system, are making inroads in schools across the country. Notably, AllHere did not respond to requests for interviews or written questions, fueling further skepticism about the transparency and accountability of A.I. companies operating in the education sector.
paragraph2: A.I. companies are heavily marketing themselves to schools, which spend tens of billions of dollars annually on technology. But AllHere’s sudden breakdown illustrates some of the risks of investing taxpayer dollars in artificial intelligence, a technology with enormous potential but little track record, especially when it comes to children. There are many complicated issues at play, including privacy of student data and the accuracy of any information offered via chatbots. And A.I. may also run counter to another growing interest for education leaders and parents — reducing children’s screen time. Natalie Milman, professor of educational technology at George Washington University, said she often advises schools to take a “wait and see” approach to purchasing new technology. While A.I. is worthy of use and testing, she said, she warned about schools “talking nebulously about this glorified tool. It has limitations, and we need to ensure we are being critical of what it can do, and its potential for harm and misinformation.” AllHere did not respond to interview requests or written questions.

paragraph1: In Manhattan, Mr. Ruddy attended a news conference to announce a significant deal, but the event took an unexpected turn when the media's negative coverage led to Charles Bluhdorn, chairman of Gulf & Western, which owns Paramount, deciding to fire him. However, director Francis Ford Coppola intervened, passionately arguing to Mr. Bluhdorn that Mr. Ruddy was indispensable for the continuation of the movie project. The film in question was "The Godfather," which went on to achieve remarkable success. It won three Oscars, with Mr. Ruddy receiving the award for Best Picture, Marlon Brando being honored as Best Actor, and the award for Best Adapted Screenplay going to Mr. Coppola and Mr. Puzo. Celebrated as one of the greatest movies ever made, "The Godfather" solidified its place in cinematic history, demonstrating the importance of perseverance and collaboration in the face of adversity.
paragraph2: Mr. Ruddy appeared at a news conference at the league’s office in Manhattan to announce the deal but didn’t anticipate the backlash from its coverage in the news media. The presence of Mr. Ruddy at the news conference so enraged Charles Bluhdorn, the combustible chairman of Gulf & Western, Paramount’s parent, that he fired him. But when Mr. Bluhdorn told Francis Ford Coppola, the director, and Robert Evans, the studio’s vice president of production, to find another producer, Mr. Coppola intervened. “Al Ruddy’s the only guy who can keep this movie going!” he told Mr. Bluhdorn. “The Godfather” won three Oscars, including Mr. Ruddy’s for best picture; for best actor, for Marlon Brando’s portrayal of Don Vito Corleone; and for best adapted screenplay, by Mr. Coppola and Mr. Puzo. The film has been widely praised as one of the best movies ever made.

paragraph1: A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible. CrowdStrike sent a faulty security update to its customers Thursday night, resulting in millions of Microsoft Windows devices shutting down and disruptions to airlines, hospitals, logistics companies and others. Americans “deserve to know in detail how this incident happened and the mitigation steps CrowdStrike is taking,” wrote Representative Mark Green of Tennessee, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, and Representative Andrew Garbarino, Republican of New York. The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”
paragraph2: A Congressional committee is set to scrutinize CrowdStrike, a prominent cybersecurity company, over a sweeping tech outage that crippled millions of Microsoft Windows devices and sent shockwaves across various industries, including airlines, hospitals, and logistics companies. At the center of the controversy is a faulty security update issued by CrowdStrike, which triggered the widespread disruptions. George Kurtz, the company's chief executive, has been summoned to testify at a hearing to account for the company's role in the debacle. Representatives Mark Green of Tennessee and Andrew Garbarino of New York, both Republicans, are spearheading the effort to hold CrowdStrike accountable, having dispatched a letter to Kurtz requesting his prompt response to schedule the hearing. A CrowdStrike spokeswoman confirmed that the company is in communication with the relevant congressional committees, but declined to provide further details, stating that any updates on briefings would be shared at the discretion of the committee members.

The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”

paragraph1: As I sit here, reflecting on the 20-year journey of the "Modern Love" column, I am struck by the serendipity of its inception. It was October 31, 2004, and our debut piece by Steve Friedman shared the pages with news of Yasser Arafat's deteriorating health and the heated U.S. presidential election between George W. Bush and John Kerry. Little did I know that this humble column would grow into a global phenomenon, expanding into a podcast, books, live presentations, a weekly column called "Tiny Love Stories," and television programs in multiple countries. My colleague Miya Lee has been instrumental in this growth, and I'm grateful for her partnership. As I look back, I'm also reminded of the personal journey that has unfolded alongside the column's evolution. I was 41 when we launched, married with two young children, and navigating the challenges of balancing work and family life. Fast forward to today, and I'm 61, separated, and proud of the independent adults my children have become. The "Modern Love" column has been a constant in my life, a reminder that love, in all its forms, is a universal language that transcends borders, cultures, and generations. As I celebrate this milestone, I'm filled with gratitude for the privilege of sharing these stories with the world and for the lessons I've learned along the way about love, loss, and the human condition.
paragraph2: Hace dos décadas, el 31 de octubre de 2004, apareció una breve nota en la portada de este diario junto con noticias sobre la salud de Yasser Arafat y las inminentes elecciones que se disputaban George W. Bush y John Kerry. Decía así: “Modern Love: Presentamos una nueva columna semanal sobre el amor y las relaciones. Hoy, Steve Friedman dice que está bien después de que lo abandonaron. Bien. En serio”. Así comenzó mi largo y extraño viaje como editor de Modern Love, hablando cada semana con desconocidos sobre los detalles más íntimos de sus enredos románticos, familiares y platónicos, y publicando después sus historias para cientos de miles o incluso millones de lectores. Nunca soñé que seguiría haciendo este trabajo 20 años después, pero ha sido una carrera maravillosa. Con el tiempo, y con la ayuda de mi colega Miya Lee, Modern Love ha crecido y ahora incluye un pódcast, libros, presentaciones en vivo, otra columna semanal, Tiny Love Stories, de 100 palabras y programas de televisión en Estados Unidos, India, Japón y los Países Bajos. Modern Love comenzó el mismo año que Facebook, tres años antes que los iPhone, ocho años antes que Tinder y 11 años antes de que el matrimonio entre personas del mismo sexo fuera legal en todo Estados Unidos. El mundo ha cambiado mucho en dos décadas, y mi vida también. Cuando empecé a escribir esta columna, tenía 41 años, llevaba 12 años casado y mis dos hijos estudiaban la escuela primaria. Ahora tengo 61, estoy separado desde hace tres años y mis dos hijos hace tiempo que se fueron de casa para trabajar y vivir de manera independiente.

paragraph1: Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.
paragraph2: One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.

Paragraph 2:
One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

paragraph1: Headquarters insisted I see him as much as possible, so I volunteered where he volunteered, showed up at events where I knew he would be, scoured the internet for mentions of his name. I was able to work my public relations job for four and a half years and keep up with the delusion. But the delusion gods wanted me to go regularly to the psych ward, where I was loaded up with antipsychotics, zapped with electroconvulsive therapy, and where my diagnosis deteriorated from bipolar I (the manic kind) to schizoaffective disorder (halfway to schizophrenia). I had no choice but to go on disability. My irritation mounted each year. It was like being caught in a whirlpool, the same information going round and round. My beloved seemed clueless. He knew nothing of NASA’s plan to cryogenically freeze our bodies and launch us to a faraway galaxy. Was headquarters simply incompetent? Why was I getting mind-melds to propose if he was just going to turn me down? I needed less noise, more signal. Headquarters was always putting my beloved’s needs first, sending me vexing mind-melds that he needed to move into my house and have his own bedroom suite. How? Who would pay for the renovations? I felt like a querulous housewife. The honeymoon was long over and so were the big Os.
paragraph2: I find myself consumed by an obsession that devours every waking moment, centered on him—my beloved. My thoughts, my actions, my very existence revolve around the magnetic pull he exerts over me. I follow him, finding solace in his proximity, yet my mind spirals further into chaos. The doctors label it schizoaffective disorder, a term that feels like an ill-fitting suit, but necessary for explaining my descent into this fragmented reality. My deteriorating mental state has forced me onto disability, a painful admission of my inability to function in a world that increasingly feels alien. "Headquarters" dictates my actions, a phantom authority whispering bizarre plans involving NASA and mind-melds, leaving me frustrated by its nonsensical commands. I am trapped in a world of delusions that grow more overwhelming by the day. The lack of reciprocation from my beloved cuts deep, as if our connection, which exists solely in my mind, has failed like a crumbling relationship. The unrequited nature of my fixation leaves me hollow, yearning for a reality where my love is returned. I stand on the precipice, teetering between the whispers of "headquarters" and the harsh clarity of my unreturned affection, longing for release from this relentless cycle of obsession and despair.

paragraph1: While Hyderabadi attire is synonymous with opulent threadwork, heavy tiers of silk and gilded beading, the contemporary fashion scene is evolving as well. Almari (“closet”) is a glossy showroom for top fashion designers from around the country, and the glittery blouses and purses suspended from the ceiling give the space a gallery-like feel. For a more traditional ambience, head to Manomay, an opulent boutique modeled after the 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad’s Old City. The warren of rooms is the setting for designs by Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, Ranna Gill and more, and the interior’s Old World details are thoughtfully conceived: An antique palanquin serves as a showcase; an intricately carved bookshelf doubles as a shoe rack.
paragraph2: Hyderabad's fashion landscape has transformed dramatically, offering shoppers contrasting retail experiences that reflect both contemporary and historical aesthetics. Almari stands as a modern fashion destination, where gleaming blouses and sophisticated purses from India's leading designers create an ambiance reminiscent of an art gallery. Meanwhile, Manomay transports visitors to a bygone era with its architectural inspiration drawn from the magnificent 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace. This traditional boutique houses collections from renowned designers like Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, and Ranna Gill, while its interior captivates with distinctive Old World elements. An antique palanquin repurposed as a display case and an intricately carved bookshelf serving as a shoe rack add to the store's historical charm.

paragraph1: In the gripping film "Dawn," directed by Matt Reeves, the fragile peace between humans and apes is put to the test. Ten years after the events of "Rise," a desperate group of humans seeks the help of Caesar, the wise and benevolent leader of a thriving ape community, to revive a dormant dam crucial to their survival. Caesar, driven by a desire for coexistence, agrees to assist, but his decision is met with fierce opposition from Koba, a scarred and vengeful ape fueled by a deep-seated hatred for humans. As Koba's treachery unfolds, Caesar is forced to confront the very principles he has sworn to uphold, including his sacred rule against apes killing one another.
paragraph2: In “Dawn” (on Hulu and Max), which was directed by Matt Reeves and takes place about “10 winters” after the events of “Rise,” humans encounter Caesar’s camp and ask him to help them restart a dam for their survival. Caesar, being the benevolent leader he is, obliges, but is met with resistance from Koba (Toby Kebbell), an ape who saw the worst of humanity in captivity before his escape. Koba plots to overthrow Caesar by making it look like humans murdered him, and therefore leads a crew of apes to attack the humans’ compound. Caesar, however, survives and must break one of his cardinal rules: “Ape not kill ape.”

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: The protracted and contentious breakup between billionaire Mr. Schmidt and his former partner, Ms. Simon, has been likened to the unraveling of a complex corporate merger. What began as a seemingly straightforward separation has devolved into a years-long saga of arbitrations, lawsuits, and dueling advisers. A confidential settlement reached in 2014, which included a financial payout and the appointment of investment adviser Derek Rundell, was intended to bring closure to the matter. However, the arrangement ultimately collapsed under the weight of a bitter dispute between Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell, setting off a chain reaction of legal battles and accusations of fraud related to a troubled investment in the luggage company Away. Ms. Simon has vehemently denied any wrongdoing, but the case continues to drag on, a testament to the challenges of untangling the intricate financial and personal ties that once bound the couple together.
paragraph2: For billionaires, and the people who love them, breaking up can be a little like unraveling a corporate merger gone wrong. Ending Mr. Schmidt’s affair has taken a decade — so far. There have been contracts, amended contracts, arbitrations, lawsuits and the platoon of advisers that inevitably go along with all that. Mr. Schmidt, now 69 years old, approved a confidential settlement in 2014 with Ms. Simon that paid her an undisclosed amount of money, and appointed an adviser, Derek Rundell, to set it up. Under the arrangement, Ms. Simon would bring Mr. Schmidt investment ideas that Mr. Rundell would evaluate on his behalf. But the deal imploded when Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell fought bitterly, leading to years of wrangling that culminated in accusations of fraud against Ms. Simon last year over an investment in the luggage maker Away. Ms. Simon has denied committing fraud.

paragraph1: But the biggest disappointment with the Vision Pro is how few good apps there are. Several months after its debut, there’s still no native YouTube or Netflix app. There’s no Spotify, no Instagram, no DoorDash. (You can still use some of these services in a web browser, or use unofficial third-party apps, but it’s a worse experience.) Some of these apps are missing because of corporate infighting. (Google and Meta, for example, have their own virtual reality ambitions and presumably don’t want to give Apple’s product a boost by making apps for it.) But others amount to a lack of confidence. Developers don’t want to make apps for platforms that nobody uses, and their reluctance so far — only about 2,000 apps have been developed for the Vision Pro, Apple said on Monday — says something about the device’s tepid reception. Apple has also been slow to update its own offerings for the Vision Pro, like a series of “immersive videos,” filmed on special 3-D cameras and released through Apple TV. These videos — which included a prehistoric nature film and a “rehearsal room” video of Alicia Keys and her band as they perform a song — were designed to show off the Vision Pro’s high-definition graphics and its “spatial audio” feature, and they are among the best things you can do with a Vision Pro.
paragraph2: Despite being launched several months ago, Apple's Vision Pro faces significant challenges due to the scarcity of quality apps available for the device. Major apps like YouTube, Netflix, Spotify, Instagram, and DoorDash are noticeably absent, largely due to corporate competition and a lack of developer confidence. Companies such as Google and Meta, who have their own virtual reality ambitions, show hesitation in supporting Apple's product, fearing it may bolster a competitor in a rapidly evolving market. Developers are equally cautious, reluctant to invest time and resources into creating apps for a platform that has yet to see substantial user adoption, as evidenced by the meager 2,000 apps developed so far. Compounding the issue, Apple has been slow to expand its own content offerings for the Vision Pro. The company has released a few immersive videos through Apple TV, including a prehistoric nature film and a rehearsal video of Alicia Keys and her band, designed to showcase the device's impressive high-definition graphics and spatial audio capabilities. While these videos represent some of the best experiences currently available on the Vision Pro, they are insufficient to compensate for the lack of third-party app support. The combination of these factors presents a considerable hurdle for Apple as it seeks to establish the Vision Pro as a dominant force in the virtual reality market.

paragraph1: My husband and I are happily child-free, though most of our new colleagues and friends have young children. Now that the worst of the pandemic seems to be behind us, we are eager to entertain at home and connect with our new friends. The problem: One of us would prefer to invite couples over without their children, so the adults can have a conversation. The other worries about the impression this might create, asking new friends and colleagues to assume the expense and complication of arranging child care. Any thoughts on this? NO KIDS Let’s start with the convivial basis of your question and go from there: You and your husband want to welcome new friends into your home to deepen your relationships with them. I love it! The hiccup: You want to exclude their kids. I get that, too. My home isn’t child-friendly, and I’m not particularly interested in redecorating or having my best attempts at sheet-pan dinners (or adult conversations) hijacked by fractious 8-year-olds.
paragraph2: As my husband and I navigate our new social circle, we're facing a dilemma that's left us questioning our hosting etiquette. We're a child-free couple who love to entertain, but we're at odds over one major issue: kids. I'm firmly in the camp that believes adult-only gatherings are the key to meaningful conversations and connections, while my husband worries that asking guests to leave their little ones behind will give us a reputation as inhospitable hosts. I understand his concerns, but our home is hardly child-friendly, with its fragile decor and lack of play areas. The thought of accommodating a gaggle of rambunctious kids during a dinner party is daunting, to say the least. And yet, I also see the value in being inclusive and welcoming to families. As we weigh our options, I'm left wondering: is it selfish to prioritize adult conversation, or are we simply being practical about our lifestyle?

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: In retrospect, James Cameron's 1986 blockbuster "Aliens" is a film that embodies many of the clichés that defined action movies of the era. Despite its enduring popularity, the movie's tough-talking characters, including a reluctant Ripley, feel like caricatures of '80s excess. The addition of a young girl in peril, played by Carrie Henn, and a soulless corporate villain, played by Paul Reiser, complete with a stereotypical 80s power suit, only add to the film's predictable nature. James Horner's bombastic score doesn't help, often overwhelming the on-screen action. And yet, the iconic confrontation between Ripley and the alien queen remains a masterclass in suspense and tension. Unfortunately, this standout moment is often lost amidst the film's otherwise heavy-handed approach, making "Aliens" feel like a product of its time, rather than a truly timeless classic.
paragraph2: 1986 ‘Aliens’ 👽👽 Written and directed by James Cameron, the first sequel to “Alien” is widely held as either the best or the second best movie in the series. But have you watched it recently? Because “Aliens” has aged badly. After 57 years in hypersleep, Ripley grudgingly agrees to help wipe out a nest of beasties threatening a settlement. “Aliens” bears many of the badges of dishonor of formulaic 1980s action: cartoonishly aggro toughies, a little girl in peril (Carrie Henn), a company tool with an upturned collar (Paul Reiser), a bombastically martial score (by James Horner) and, worst of all, an avalanche of hackneyed would-be catchphrases. Best: the confrontation between the alien queen (a major addition to the canon) and Ripley. Worst: almost everything else.

paragraph1: Culture Factory, 2 p.m. At the Cable Factory, a hulking limestone-brick factory complex, production has shifted from cables to culture. Located in the once-industrial west, this seven-story former manufacturing facility is today home to a mix of art studios, performance spaces, galleries, schools and museums. While exploring the site, don’t overlook the Finnish Museum of Photography (admission, €8), which recently hosted an exhibition of poignant, politically themed photographs.

Notably, the Finnish Museum of Photography recently showcased a thought-provoking exhibition of politically charged photographs, cementing the Cable Factory's status as a thriving arts center.

paragraph1: In the realm of clinical trials, expectancy effects play a significant role, particularly when examining the potential of psychedelics as "super placebos." Natasha Mason, a psychopharmacologist, critiques the design of a study conducted by Hopkins researchers, suggesting that its framework might have skewed results to emphasize spiritual experiences. This critique highlights the intricate balance required in experimental design to avoid bias. On the other hand, Dr. Richards defends the application of psychedelics, positing that they inherently facilitate religious experiences through their profound effect on consciousness. This debate underscores the complexity surrounding the use of psychedelics in clinical settings, where expectation and actual drug effects intertwine. The narrative takes a turn when a journal released a paper in November 2016 that failed to mention a participant's death, raising concerns about transparency. This omission came to light when reporter Bob Tedeschi, guided by Katherine MacLean, a former professor at Hopkins, probed further into the study's circumstances by consulting Roland. MacLean's advice underscores the importance of thorough investigation and the ethical responsibility of researchers to disclose all relevant information. The situation exemplifies the challenges in maintaining integrity and accountability in clinical research, especially when dealing with substances as contentious and potentially transformative as psychedelics.
paragraph2: Such expectancy effects influence clinical trials of all kinds. Because of volunteers’ hopes around a trial, even those who receive a placebo will often show more improvement than those who receive nothing. Some experts have suggested that psychedelics function as “super placebos” because they increase suggestibility. Natasha Mason, a psychopharmacologist at Maastricht University in the Netherlands, said that while she understood the Hopkins researchers’ goals, the experimental design had put a thumb on the spiritual scale. “Their mystical experiences results are very high compared to other groups,” she said. Dr. Richards rejected such criticism. Psychedelic drugs, he said, open a state of consciousness that allows for religious experiences. “The Buddha, if you will, is in the human mind,” he said. “Whether there is a statue in the room or not doesn’t matter.” In November 2016, a week before publication, the journal gave journalists an early look at the paper. The man’s death was not mentioned, recalled Bob Tedeschi, a reporter who covered the research for Stat. He only learned about it after sending the initial version of the paper to Katherine MacLean, who was a professor at Hopkins when the suicide took place. “Go back to Roland and ask if there were any deaths,” she recalled telling him.

paragraph1: One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.
paragraph2: Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

Paragraph 2:
Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.

paragraph1: As Ms. Walz steps into the national spotlight, critics have been quick to paint her as a left-wing radical, particularly focusing on her and her husband's political responses in the aftermath of George Floyd's death. Yet within Minnesota's borders, she has cultivated a markedly different reputation as a steady, competent presence that effectively balances her husband's more outgoing personality. At 58, Ms. Walz embraces her role as both partner and adviser to her husband, maintaining an active presence in the state capital where she advocates for progressive initiatives, including educational programs for incarcerated individuals. "I've always seen my role as a partner," she notes, reflecting on her position in the administration. Her roots run deep in Minnesota, where she grew up in Ivanhoe as the eldest of four sisters, born to parents who were both educators. This background appears to have shaped her nurturing approach to public service, with her sister Heidi Ohlmann observing, "She's always been the caretaker of the family." Despite the attempts to characterize her through a partisan lens, Ms. Walz continues to focus on her work, leveraging her measured approach to advance her policy objectives while maintaining her distinctive leadership style.
paragraph2: As Ms. Walz enters the national stage, critics on the right are already trying to portray her — as they have with her husband — as a left-wing radical who countenanced the civil unrest in her state after the death George Floyd. But at home in Minnesota, where she has spent most of her life, friends and political observers describe her as the coolheaded and ultracompetent counterpart to a man known for an intuitive and charismatic political style. “We have always worked as a partnership,” Ms. Walz, 58, told the self-improvement podcast “What If It Works” last month, later adding, “We are still one another’s closest advisers.” Ms. Walz did not comment for this article. The first gubernatorial spouse in Minnesota to keep an office in the state capital, Ms. Walz regularly advises her husband and has used her platform to advance policy initiatives, most significantly around offering college degree programs to inmates. Raised in the tiny farming town of Ivanhoe, Minn., only a 15-minute drive from South Dakota’s eastern border, Ms. Walz is the daughter of schoolteachers, and the eldest of four sisters. Ms. Walz was a caretaker in the family, according to her youngest sister, Heidi Ohlmann. “She’s always looking out for everyone,” Ms. Ohlmann said in an interview.

paragraph1: Dr. Walker, along with her colleague Dr. Cronin and their team, is deeply immersed in the ambitious task of expanding the assembly theory of life, a pursuit she finds exhilarating. Her excitement is particularly piqued by their groundbreaking project to develop an "origin-of-life engine" within the laboratory. This innovative endeavor involves using robots to systematically mix inert chemicals in myriad combinations, with the hopeful potential of witnessing the emergence of new life forms. Dr. Walker finds the prospect of observing these nascent life forms in the lab far more exhilarating than the discovery of extraterrestrial life, as it allows for direct testing and observation of their theoretical frameworks. However, her enthusiasm is somewhat tempered by her critique of Dr. Hazen's recent study. Dr. Walker points out that Dr. Hazen's team made a critical error by applying methods designed for analyzing molecules to the study of minerals, which inherently possess different properties. This flaw, she suggests, undermines the study's findings. Despite this, Dr. Walker remains focused on her own research endeavors, collaborating closely with Dr. Cronin and their colleagues to push the boundaries of scientific understanding in life's origins, driven by the thrilling possibility of creating life in the lab and testing the very limits of their assembly theory.
paragraph2: Dr. Walker said Dr. Hazen’s study was flawed. His team copied experiments that she and her colleagues had designed specifically to look at molecules. But minerals are different from molecules in some important ways. Instead of free-floating clusters of atoms, they are lattices that include some disorder in their structures. Dr. Walker said that she and Dr. Cronin are working with their colleagues to extend the assembly theory of life. They also have a far more ambitious effort underway: to build what she calls “an origin-of-life engine in the lab.” Robots will mix inert chemicals in a vast number of combinations, looking for ones that produce more complex compounds. Under the right conditions, the chemicals may form droplets that may be able to bootstrap themselves to a higher and higher assembly index. Above a certain threshold, they might become alive — but as a form of life we’ve never seen before. If we do discover life on other worlds, Dr. Walker expects it will be a milestone in human history. But the idea of an origin-of-life engine has made her more interested in watching new life emerge in a lab here on Earth. “To me, it’s more exciting as a scientist, because you can test the theory and see it happen,” she said.

paragraph1: As I look back on 1999, I recall a time when the line between truth and fiction was blissfully clear. We'd enter a movie theater, suspend our disbelief, and for two hours, contradictory realities coexisted. But as the credits rolled, we'd exit into a shared world, collectively acknowledging the fantasy we'd just witnessed. Fast forward to today, and it's as if we've never left the theater. Each of us now inhabits a bespoke reality, making it increasingly disorienting to find common ground. Your truth, my truth – the notion of a shared reality feels like a relic of the past.
paragraph2: In 1999, the gray area between truth and fiction, where the person seated to your left believed the opposite of the person seated to your right, was contained safely with the movie’s run time. And as we all left the theater, we collectively realized it was all a ride. Now, in a way, that ride never ends. And perhaps most unnerving is the knowledge that each one of us is living in an increasingly unique version of the world, making reality less of a communal experience than ever.

paragraph1: In the unsettling found footage horror film "Life of Belle," now streaming on Tubi, a family's security monitors capture the disturbing descent of a mother into erratic behavior. As she systematically removes food from the house, convinced it's poisoned, a sense of unease settles over the viewer. The ominous decision to leave the knives behind is a harbinger of the danger that's to come. Unlike its supernatural predecessors "Paranormal Activity" and "He's Watching," "Life of Belle" grounds its horror in the all-too-real issue of untreated mental illness. Director Shawn Robinson's decision to cast his own family members pays off, as they deliver naturalistic performances that add to the film's sense of unease. With its low-budget aesthetic and unflinching portrayal of a family in crisis, "Life of Belle" is a chilling reminder that sometimes the most terrifying monsters are the ones that lurk within.
paragraph2: ‘Life of Belle’ Stream it on Tubi. Security monitors also capture the mom’s increasingly erratic behavior, like when she empties the house of food, convinced it’s poison. What mom doesn’t remove are the knives — the first clue that the home will soon become a house of horrors. This feature debut from the writer-director Shawn Robinson looks a lot like other low-budget found footage horror films. Like “Paranormal Activity,” it’s set inside a house. Like “He’s Watching,” its leads are a brave young brother and sister. But in those films, otherworldly forces invade domestic space. Here, Robinson takes a disturbingly different path, using a parent’s real, untreated mental illness as the antagonistic force, forgoing metaphor. Far from being exploitative, the film extends compassion toward the suffering of both parent and child. The Robinson family is related in real life — and their performances are scary movie naturalism at its best.

paragraph1: On Thursday, the group filed a petition with the Supreme Court asking it to vacate the ruling of the appellate court and send it back to the district court to stand trial. The filing argued that the government had bogged down the case in procedural issues rather than letting it be decided on its merits. The Justice Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The plaintiffs are represented by Our Children’s Trust, a nonprofit law firm based in Eugene, Ore., that has filed similar lawsuits and legal actions based on constitutional claims across the country. Their strategy scored a big win in Hawaii in June, when Gov. Josh Green announced a settlement with the plaintiffs, who had sued the state’s Department of Transportation over its use of fossil fuels. As part of the agreement, the state said it would decarbonize its transportation system within 20 years, expand bicycle lanes and increase spending on electric-vehicle chargers. paragraph2: Our Children’s Trust, a nonprofit law firm, has recently petitioned the Supreme Court to overturn an appellate court's decision, seeking to have their case returned to the district court for trial. The group argues that the government has been overly focused on procedural issues at the expense of addressing the substantive merits of the case. This legal maneuver underscores their ongoing commitment to advocating for environmental justice and climate accountability. Notably, the Justice Department has not yet issued any comments regarding this petition, leaving the future of the case uncertain. This move comes on the heels of a major victory for Our Children’s Trust in Hawaii, where they successfully negotiated a settlement with the state government to decarbonize its transportation system. This achievement highlights the organization's ability to effect significant change at the state level, potentially setting a precedent for similar cases across the nation. By pushing for the case to be reconsidered in a district court, Our Children’s Trust aims to shift the focus back to the core issues of the lawsuit, emphasizing the need for governmental accountability in environmental policies. Their efforts continue to spotlight the critical intersection of legal advocacy and environmental sustainability, reinforcing their role as a formidable force in the fight against climate change.

paragraph1: The New York Times has filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, alleging copyright infringement related to news content used in AI systems. OpenAI, a company that provides AI tools capable of generating social media posts, images, and computer programs, similar to industry giants Google and Meta, has seen its technology utilized in influence campaigns worldwide. Notably, a Russian campaign dubbed Doppelganger leveraged OpenAI's tools to create anti-Ukraine comments in multiple languages, as well as translate and edit pro-Russian articles into English and French, converting them into Facebook posts. Similarly, a Chinese campaign known as Spamouflage has also employed OpenAI's technology. The lawsuit marks a significant development in the ongoing debate over the use of AI-generated content and its implications for media outlets and intellectual property rights.
paragraph2: (The New York Times has sued OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, claiming copyright infringement of news content related to A.I. systems.) Like Google, Meta and Microsoft, OpenAI offers online chatbots and other A.I. tools that can write social media posts, generate photorealistic images and write computer programs. In its report, the company said its tools had been used in influence campaigns that researchers had tracked for years, including a Russian campaign called Doppelganger and a Chinese campaign called Spamouflage. The Doppelganger campaign used OpenAI’s technology to generate anti-Ukraine comments that were posted on X in English, French, German, Italian and Polish, OpenAI said. The company’s tools were also used to translate and edit articles that supported Russia in the war in Ukraine into English and French, and to convert anti-Ukraine news articles into Facebook posts.

paragraph1: A 16th-century palazzo with stone columns, gilded mirrors and chandeliers might sound like a recipe for pretentiousness. But Palazzo Preca, run by two Maltese sisters from a family of noted restaurateurs, defies expectations. The mood is easygoing, and the fenek moqli — in local parlance — is an inspiring concoction of plump rabbit nuggets rendered moist by a thick, elegant wine reduction, and velvety mashed potatoes. If the grilled rabbit liver appetizer feels like overkill, consider the seductive, spicy linguine Caruso, with diced squid, meaty shrimp, hot chiles and a zesty tomato sauce. The wine list is a Mediterranean tour, including Syrian, Israeli and Maltese bottles. Dinner for two, without drinks: about €70.
paragraph2: Palazzo Preca, nestled within a grand 16th-century building, exudes a unique blend of elegance and casual charm. Run by two Maltese sisters from a family celebrated for their culinary expertise, the restaurant offers a captivating dining experience. Guests can savor dishes such as fenek moqli, featuring succulent rabbit nuggets in a rich wine reduction accompanied by creamy mashed potatoes, and linguine Caruso, a fiery pasta dish brimming with squid, shrimp, chiles, and tangy tomato sauce. The wine list showcases an impressive selection from the Mediterranean region, perfectly complementing the flavors on the menu. A delightful dinner for two, excluding drinks, costs around €70, providing a memorable culinary journey.

paragraph1: In the quiet, rural landscape of southeast Ireland in 1985, a subtle yet profound transformation is underway in the life of Bill Furlong, a humble coal and fuel seller. Played with nuanced intensity by Cillian Murphy, Bill navigates the intricate web of relationships in his small town, where the nuns wield considerable influence over the community. At home, Bill finds comfort in the loving companionship of his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and their daughters, their modest means notwithstanding. However, the tranquility of Bill's existence is disrupted when he witnesses a disturbing scene: a young woman, suspected to be unmarried and pregnant, is forcibly taken into a building near the local convent. The woman's desperate resistance and evident distress leave an indelible mark on Bill, stirring a deep sense of empathy and recognition. As he grapples with the implications of what he has seen, Bill's thoughts turn to his own mother's past, and the seeds of a quiet rebellion are sown.
paragraph2: “Small Things Like These” plays just a little like a gangster film, except the web of power at its center is spun by nuns. Set in 1985 and based on Claire Keegan’s 2021 novel, it is a story about how people create and maintain control and the many shades of complicity that result. In this case, the setting is southeast Ireland, and the nuns’ control has woven its way into every aspect of life in a small town. Bill Furlong (Cillian Murphy) sells and delivers coal and fuel in that town, an occupation that barely supports his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and a house full of daughters. But they’re doing OK. He can put food on the table, and they have a happy home life. One day, however, something changes inside Bill: He sees a young woman being nearly dragged into a building near the local convent, and it troubles him. He suspects that she is pregnant and unmarried, like his own mother was, and is being brought to the nuns by her horrified family. She is, quite literally, kicking and screaming. Bill can’t stop thinking about her.

paragraph1: Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.
paragraph2: KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.

paragraph1: In California, the Democratic-majority Legislature is poised to pass a significant bill by the month's end, which will subsequently be sent to Governor Gavin Newsom. Newsom has yet to reveal his position on the legislation, which, if signed, would place California at the forefront of tech regulation, surpassing federal efforts. Historically, California has played a pivotal role in shaping U.S. tech consumer protections, with previous laws setting precedents. However, the current A.I. bill has stirred opposition, particularly from those concerned about its impact on the sharing of open-source software code by major tech companies. Critics argue that such restrictions could stifle innovation and growth among smaller A.I. firms. Despite amendments aimed at alleviating some of these concerns, apprehension remains within the open-source community. Chris Nicholson, a partner at Page One Ventures, underscores this unease, noting that the bill could potentially impede A.I. development. As California once again stands on the brink of influencing national tech policy, the debate continues to intensify.
paragraph2: The Democratic-majority Legislature is expected to pass the bill by the end of the month. It would then go to Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has not said whether he supports it. If the bill is signed, California will again be a step ahead of the federal government on tech regulation. California’s Legislature has helped shape U.S. tech consumer protections with a 2020 privacy law that curbed the collection of user data and a 2022 child online safety law. Opponents of the A.I. bill have argued that it would discourage tech giants from sharing the software code underlying their artificial intelligence with other businesses and software developers — a practice known as open source. They believe this would choke the progress of smaller A.I. companies. While the amendments alleviated some issues and improved on the earlier version, “the open source software community still rightly has concerns that this will be a damper on A.I. development,” said Chris Nicholson, a partner with Page One Ventures, a venture capital firm.

paragraph1: As I reflect on my time playing alongside Mariko, I'm struck by the depth of our emotional connection. In an interview after her poignant on-screen departure, I caught myself referring to her as "Mariko-sama" - a term of reverence that slipped out unexpectedly, like a subconscious farewell. Only now do I realize the profound impact her journey had on me, a resonance that went unnoticed during filming. I'm left with a sense of awe and gratitude for the experience, and a renewed commitment to approaching future projects with the same level of dedication and emotional investment that Mariko inspired in me.
paragraph2: How much of Mariko do you carry with you? I still get emotional talking about her journey. There was an interview I did after the episode when she dies was aired, and I called her “Mariko-sama” for the first time, which you never do. It’s like calling myself “Miss Anna.” I felt that, almost unconsciously, I was saying goodbye to her. While I was filming it, I didn’t understand the intensity of what I was mentally going through, and how much it had affected me, but it speaks volumes now. I want to approach all my projects the way I approach Mariko.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
As I reflect on my time playing alongside Mariko, I'm struck by the depth of our emotional connection. In an interview after her poignant on-screen departure, I caught myself referring to her as "Mariko-sama" - a term of reverence that slipped out unexpectedly, like a subconscious farewell. Only now do I realize the profound impact her journey had on me, a resonance that went unnoticed during filming. I'm left with a sense of awe and gratitude for the experience, and a renewed commitment to approaching future projects with the same level of dedication and emotional investment that Mariko inspired in me.

Paragraph 2:
How much of Mariko do you carry with you? I still get emotional talking about her journey. There was an interview I did after the episode when she dies was aired, and I called her “Mariko-sama” for the first time, which you never do. It’s like calling myself “Miss Anna.” I felt that, almost unconsciously, I was saying goodbye to her. While I was filming it, I didn’t understand the intensity of what I was mentally going through, and how much it had affected me, but it speaks volumes now. I want to approach all my projects the way I approach Mariko.

paragraph1: KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.
paragraph2: Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.

Paragraph 1:
KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.

Paragraph 2:
Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.

paragraph1: In a recent study published in Nature Medicine, researchers explored the psychological effects of the drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, commonly prescribed for diabetes and obesity, respectively. The study, funded by the National Institutes of Health, found that individuals using these medications exhibited a slightly reduced likelihood of experiencing suicidal thoughts compared to those who were not taking them. Utilizing a comprehensive database of anonymized electronic health records from over 100 million individuals, the researchers meticulously compared two distinct groups: those prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and those receiving Ozempic or other blood sugar-lowering medications. The findings of this extensive analysis aim to provide reassurance to users of these drugs, highlighting a potential mental health benefit alongside their physical health uses. Importantly, the study was conducted independently of Novo Nordisk, the manufacturer of both medications, ensuring the results were free from any conflicts of interest. This research not only contributes to the understanding of the multifaceted impacts of these medications but also underscores the importance of considering mental health outcomes when assessing the overall benefits of pharmaceutical interventions for chronic conditions like diabetes and obesity.
paragraph2: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday. Millions of people take Ozempic and Wegovy, which are considered to be among the biggest blockbusters in medical history. But last year a European drug safety agency said it was investigating whether the drugs cause suicidal thoughts. The new study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, was funded by the National Institutes of Health and used a huge population. The findings provide data that may potentially reassure people who take the drugs. Novo Nordisk, maker of the drugs, had no role in the study, and the study’s investigators had no conflicts of interest. The investigators used anonymized electronic health records from a database of 100.8 million people. That allowed them to look at two groups: 240,618 who were prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and 1,589,855 who were prescribed Ozempic or other medicines to lower their blood sugar. Suicidal thoughts were included in patients’ records as part of routine monitoring of their health.

paragraph1: As Ms. Walz steps into the national spotlight, critics have been quick to paint her as a left-wing radical, particularly focusing on her and her husband's political responses in the aftermath of George Floyd's death. Yet within Minnesota's borders, she has cultivated a markedly different reputation as a steady, competent presence that effectively balances her husband's more outgoing personality. At 58, Ms. Walz embraces her role as both partner and adviser to her husband, maintaining an active presence in the state capital where she advocates for progressive initiatives, including educational programs for incarcerated individuals. "I've always seen my role as a partner," she notes, reflecting on her position in the administration. Her roots run deep in Minnesota, where she grew up in Ivanhoe as the eldest of four sisters, born to parents who were both educators. This background appears to have shaped her nurturing approach to public service, with her sister Heidi Ohlmann observing, "She's always been the caretaker of the family." Despite the attempts to characterize her through a partisan lens, Ms. Walz continues to focus on her work, leveraging her measured approach to advance her policy objectives while maintaining her distinctive leadership style.
paragraph2: As Ms. Walz enters the national stage, critics on the right are already trying to portray her — as they have with her husband — as a left-wing radical who countenanced the civil unrest in her state after the death George Floyd. But at home in Minnesota, where she has spent most of her life, friends and political observers describe her as the coolheaded and ultracompetent counterpart to a man known for an intuitive and charismatic political style. “We have always worked as a partnership,” Ms. Walz, 58, told the self-improvement podcast “What If It Works” last month, later adding, “We are still one another’s closest advisers.” Ms. Walz did not comment for this article. The first gubernatorial spouse in Minnesota to keep an office in the state capital, Ms. Walz regularly advises her husband and has used her platform to advance policy initiatives, most significantly around offering college degree programs to inmates. Raised in the tiny farming town of Ivanhoe, Minn., only a 15-minute drive from South Dakota’s eastern border, Ms. Walz is the daughter of schoolteachers, and the eldest of four sisters. Ms. Walz was a caretaker in the family, according to her youngest sister, Heidi Ohlmann. “She’s always looking out for everyone,” Ms. Ohlmann said in an interview.

paragraph1: "A Different Man" serves as a modern morality play, echoing the thematic depth of classic fables like "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "The Elephant Man." It scrutinizes society's obsession with rigid beauty standards, exposing how those deemed conventionally attractive often succeed through mere genetic fortune. The narrative's overt presentation of this reality injects a touch of humor into its critique. By adopting a third-person perspective, the work provides an analytical lens on its themes, exploring the superficial values that dictate societal success and the moral implications of such biases, without anchoring the analysis to any one character's viewpoint.
paragraph2: Like many literary and cinematic fables before it — think of “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” or “The Elephant Man” — “A Different Man” is really a morality play, of a kind. It’s just that the moral isn’t all that straightforward. It’s about a societal obsession with particular standards of beauty. The fact that conventionally attractive people, or people with certain features and skin colors, tend to encounter more success in life simply by dint of genetic luck is explicit throughout. But that fact is so obvious, and stated so blatantly outright, that it feels like a joke.

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:

It scrutinizes society's obsession with rigid beauty standards, exposing how those deemed conventionally attractive often succeed through mere genetic fortune. The narrative's overt presentation of this reality injects a touch of humor into its critique. By adopting a third-person perspective, the work provides an analytical lens on its themes, exploring the superficial values that dictate societal success and the moral implications of such biases, without anchoring the analysis to any one character's viewpoint.

Paragraph 2:
Like many literary and cinematic fables before it — think of “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” or “The Elephant Man” — “A Different Man” is really a morality play, of a kind. It’s just that the moral isn’t all that straightforward. It’s about a societal obsession with particular standards of beauty. The fact that conventionally attractive people, or people with certain features and skin colors, tend to encounter more success in life simply by dint of genetic luck is explicit throughout. But that fact is so obvious, and stated so blatantly outright, that it feels like a joke.

paragraph1: In the quiet, rural landscape of southeast Ireland in 1985, a subtle yet profound transformation is underway in the life of Bill Furlong, a humble coal and fuel seller. Played with nuanced intensity by Cillian Murphy, Bill navigates the intricate web of relationships in his small town, where the nuns wield considerable influence over the community. At home, Bill finds comfort in the loving companionship of his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and their daughters, their modest means notwithstanding. However, the tranquility of Bill's existence is disrupted when he witnesses a disturbing scene: a young woman, suspected to be unmarried and pregnant, is forcibly taken into a building near the local convent. The woman's desperate resistance and evident distress leave an indelible mark on Bill, stirring a deep sense of empathy and recognition. As he grapples with the implications of what he has seen, Bill's thoughts turn to his own mother's past, and the seeds of a quiet rebellion are sown.
paragraph2: “Small Things Like These” plays just a little like a gangster film, except the web of power at its center is spun by nuns. Set in 1985 and based on Claire Keegan’s 2021 novel, it is a story about how people create and maintain control and the many shades of complicity that result. In this case, the setting is southeast Ireland, and the nuns’ control has woven its way into every aspect of life in a small town. Bill Furlong (Cillian Murphy) sells and delivers coal and fuel in that town, an occupation that barely supports his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and a house full of daughters. But they’re doing OK. He can put food on the table, and they have a happy home life. One day, however, something changes inside Bill: He sees a young woman being nearly dragged into a building near the local convent, and it troubles him. He suspects that she is pregnant and unmarried, like his own mother was, and is being brought to the nuns by her horrified family. She is, quite literally, kicking and screaming. Bill can’t stop thinking about her.
