paragraph1: It appears that my sibling’s spouse also has limited interest in providing for their children. I surely don’t want to hand over anything to my sibling’s spouse, but to give it to the children directly would be a way of enabling the spouse to skirt the obligation to care for them. I could continue to make charitable contributions in my sibling’s name, but what right do I have to use money belonging to others? (What I have already done may not have been entirely proper.) I could put funds in trust for the kids but would rather gift them a nontaxable amount annually. Or I could just wait until the kids need help with something critical. Turning any funds over to my sibling’s spouse would turn my stomach. Name Withheld
paragraph2: I've been losing sleep over how to help my sister's kids without inadvertently supporting her husband's irresponsible behavior. Every time I see them struggling, my heart aches, but simply handing over money feels like enabling his chronic neglect of their needs. I've explored several options, from establishing a trust fund to making annual gifts within the tax-free limit, but each solution comes with its own complications. Making charitable donations in my sister's name could indirectly benefit the children, yet I worry it's not enough. The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
It appears that my sibling’s spouse also has limited interest in providing for their children. I surely don’t want to hand over anything to my sibling’s spouse, but to give it to the children directly would be a way of enabling the spouse to skirt the obligation to care for them. I could continue to make charitable contributions in my sibling’s name, but what right do I have to use money belonging to others? (What I have already done may not have been entirely proper.) I could put funds in trust for the kids but would rather gift them a nontaxable amount annually. Or I could just wait until the kids need help with something critical. Turning any funds over to my sibling’s spouse would turn my stomach. Name Withheld

Paragraph 2:
I've been losing sleep over how to help my sister's kids without inadvertently supporting her husband's irresponsible behavior. Every time I see them struggling, my heart aches, but simply handing over money feels like enabling his chronic neglect of their needs. I've explored several options, from establishing a trust fund to making annual gifts within the tax-free limit, but each solution comes with its own complications. Making charitable donations in my sister's name could indirectly benefit the children, yet I worry it's not enough. The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.

paragraph1: “And what, you may ask, are the reasons why?” Ray Bradbury asked in his foreword for the Kansas Centennial edition of L. Frank Baum’s classic novel. “‘The Wizard of Oz’ will never die?” More than 20 years after the musical “Wicked” became a Broadway megahit, the first part of big-screen adaptation, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, will arrive this fall. The second film comes out next year. It might be time to pose a related question: Why won’t the Wicked Witch of the West ever die? The character has grown in stature since she first appeared as the villain in just one chapter of Baum’s novel nearly 125 years ago. Every subsequent adaptation has made her more visible, more memorable and — in a twist — more heroic. Much like the Land of Oz’s symbolic meaning as a stand-in for the United States, her fate reflects our nation’s continuing debates about race, gender and who is and isn’t considered American.
paragraph2: The enduring legacy of "The Wizard of Oz" and its iconic characters, especially the Wicked Witch of the West, continues to captivate audiences around the world. Ray Bradbury, in his foreword for a special edition of L. Frank Baum's novel, famously pondered why "The Wizard of Oz" remains timeless, inviting readers to explore the deeper layers of its narrative. This question takes on new dimensions with the upcoming film adaptation of the musical "Wicked," starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande. This adaptation underscores the continued relevance and evolution of the Wicked Witch of the West. Originally depicted as a minor villain in Baum's novel, the character has since gained prominence and complexity through various adaptations. She now symbolizes broader societal issues such as race, gender, and national identity in the United States. The Wicked Witch's transformation from a simple antagonist to a complex figure mirrors evolving cultural narratives, ensuring that her story remains a powerful and relevant part of modern discourse.

paragraph1: 9 My Aunt Eloise Eloise Uggams was the star of the family. She had a beautiful singing voice. She went all over the world with the U.S.O.; she did “Porgy and Bess” on Broadway. She would teach me songs as a kid. She was able to see possibility in me; she felt I had talent. My parents just thought, “Oh, she can sing. That’s so cute!” But they never thought about it as a career.
paragraph2: Reflecting on my Aunt Eloise Uggams, I recall her as the family's shining star, celebrated for her stunning singing voice and accomplished career. Aunt Eloise traveled the world with the U.S.O. and graced Broadway in "Porgy and Bess." She was pivotal in nurturing my musical talent, teaching me songs as a child and recognizing my potential, unlike my parents, who saw my singing as nothing more than a charming hobby, not a career possibility.

paragraph1: The squirrel's beady eyes bore into me as I sit here under the maple tree, my phone clutched in my hand like some kind of lifeline. Three hours, seventeen minutes, and still no text back. Mom says I'm too good for someone who can't even bother to cancel properly, and Sarah keeps insisting I need to "know my worth," but right now, all I know is this hollow feeling in my chest. It's funny how a simple unanswered message can make you question everything about yourself. The squirrel tilts its head, probably wondering why I'm still here, and honestly, I'm wondering the same thing.
paragraph2:
Under the Tree
This squirrel stared at me, wondering why I was sitting under its tree. I always come to this tree when I feel out of sorts. I was supposed to have a date that day but never got a text back. Friends say it has nothing to do with me. Mom says, “You need higher self-esteem.” I love myself, but I’m slowly unraveling, trying to see myself the way I know I should. Under the tree with the squirrel staring at me, I thought, “It’s nice to have other living things acknowledge me.” — Mia Mitchell

paragraph1: I've been losing sleep over how to help my sister's kids without inadvertently supporting her husband's irresponsible behavior. Every time I see them struggling, my heart aches, but simply handing over money feels like enabling his chronic neglect of their needs. I've explored several options, from establishing a trust fund to making annual gifts within the tax-free limit, but each solution comes with its own complications. Making charitable donations in my sister's name could indirectly benefit the children, yet I worry it's not enough. The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.
paragraph2: It appears that my sibling’s spouse also has limited interest in providing for their children. I surely don’t want to hand over anything to my sibling’s spouse, but to give it to the children directly would be a way of enabling the spouse to skirt the obligation to care for them. I could continue to make charitable contributions in my sibling’s name, but what right do I have to use money belonging to others? (What I have already done may not have been entirely proper.) I could put funds in trust for the kids but would rather gift them a nontaxable amount annually. Or I could just wait until the kids need help with something critical. Turning any funds over to my sibling’s spouse would turn my stomach. Name Withheld

paragraph1: As I sit in my newly acquired home, surrounded by the eerie silence of a space that was meant to be shared, I'm reminded of the gamble I took on love and real estate. My partner, a skilled carpenter and house framer, and I had been navigating the tumultuous waters of our relationship for years, our frequent arguments and breakups a testament to our passion and instability. Despite our rocky past, we decided to take the plunge and buy a house together in Bozeman, Montana, a decision that seemed reckless in hindsight. With my better credit, I took on the mortgage, while my partner agreed to contribute financially and lend his expertise to renovation projects. But just weeks after closing, our relationship imploded in a final, brutal argument, leaving me alone in this sprawling space with only my cat for company. Now, as I wander the empty rooms, I'm forced to confront the uncertainty of my decision and the daunting prospect of starting anew, solo. The house, once a symbol of our shared dreams, has become a bittersweet reminder of what could have been, and the mortgage, a constant, nagging reminder of my own vulnerability.
paragraph2: “I don’t want to own a house by myself,” I said to my partner of four years as we discussed the benefits of owning property in Bozeman, Mont., our increasingly unaffordable mountain town. “We have to try to make this work.” I was a 30-year-old writer; he was a carpenter and house framer, several years younger. We had been “trying to make it work” for the past year. We fought bitterly, took breaks, got back together. I moved out of our shared house, back in, and out again. Then, in June 2018, a reasonably priced house came on the market during one of our “Let’s try again” periods. The house was spacious: three bedrooms, a two-car garage and a fenced-in backyard. The mortgage was manageable for two people, but not for me alone. Which is why, after the final meeting with the real estate agent, we agreed to split the monthly payment down the middle. My credit was better, so I would be the only person on the actual paperwork, but I would have my partner’s financial contribution and his construction skills to ease the stress of solo homeownership — if we could make our relationship work. Two months later, I closed on the house. Two days after that, we had one last fight and broke up for good, leaving me alone in the house with my cat.

paragraph1: “Over time, you will suffer less, essentially,” said Dr. Riris, an archaeologist at Bournemouth University in England. “There tends not to be wholesale collapse.” The researchers tracked the history of societies by taking advantage of the way archaeologists tell time. Most organic material, whether it’s charcoal or mussel shells, contains trace amounts of radioactive carbon-14, which gradually breaks down over thousands of years. By measuring the carbon-14 left at an archaeological site, researchers can estimate its age. This approach can also track population changes. As human groups get bigger, they burn more wood, eat more food and leave behind more garbage, all of which can be dated. When those groups shrink, their sites become rarer.
paragraph2: Dr. Riris, an archaeologist at Bournemouth University, elucidates a method employed by researchers to explore the historical trajectory of societies. She articulates how societies typically do not undergo total collapse over time. Instead, researchers utilize the decay of radioactive carbon-14 in organic materials to approximate the age of archaeological sites. This radiocarbon dating technique is instrumental in tracing population changes, as it allows scientists to infer the size of human groups from the amount of physical evidence they leave behind. Larger groups tend to leave more substantial remnants, such as burned wood and food remains, which can be precisely dated, whereas smaller groups leave fewer traces, making their historical footprint less discernible.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Hyderabad's fashion landscape has transformed dramatically, offering shoppers contrasting retail experiences that reflect both contemporary and historical aesthetics. Almari stands as a modern fashion destination, where gleaming blouses and sophisticated purses from India's leading designers create an ambiance reminiscent of an art gallery. Meanwhile, Manomay transports visitors to a bygone era with its architectural inspiration drawn from the magnificent 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace. This traditional boutique houses collections from renowned designers like Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, and Ranna Gill, while its interior captivates with distinctive Old World elements. An antique palanquin repurposed as a display case and an intricately carved bookshelf serving as a shoe rack add to the store's historical charm.
paragraph2: While Hyderabadi attire is synonymous with opulent threadwork, heavy tiers of silk and gilded beading, the contemporary fashion scene is evolving as well. Almari (“closet”) is a glossy showroom for top fashion designers from around the country, and the glittery blouses and purses suspended from the ceiling give the space a gallery-like feel. For a more traditional ambience, head to Manomay, an opulent boutique modeled after the 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad’s Old City. The warren of rooms is the setting for designs by Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, Ranna Gill and more, and the interior’s Old World details are thoughtfully conceived: An antique palanquin serves as a showcase; an intricately carved bookshelf doubles as a shoe rack.

paragraph1: Palazzo Preca, nestled within a grand 16th-century building, exudes a unique blend of elegance and casual charm. Run by two Maltese sisters from a family celebrated for their culinary expertise, the restaurant offers a captivating dining experience. Guests can savor dishes such as fenek moqli, featuring succulent rabbit nuggets in a rich wine reduction accompanied by creamy mashed potatoes, and linguine Caruso, a fiery pasta dish brimming with squid, shrimp, chiles, and tangy tomato sauce. The wine list showcases an impressive selection from the Mediterranean region, perfectly complementing the flavors on the menu. A delightful dinner for two, excluding drinks, costs around €70, providing a memorable culinary journey.
paragraph2: A 16th-century palazzo with stone columns, gilded mirrors and chandeliers might sound like a recipe for pretentiousness. But Palazzo Preca, run by two Maltese sisters from a family of noted restaurateurs, defies expectations. The mood is easygoing, and the fenek moqli — in local parlance — is an inspiring concoction of plump rabbit nuggets rendered moist by a thick, elegant wine reduction, and velvety mashed potatoes. If the grilled rabbit liver appetizer feels like overkill, consider the seductive, spicy linguine Caruso, with diced squid, meaty shrimp, hot chiles and a zesty tomato sauce. The wine list is a Mediterranean tour, including Syrian, Israeli and Maltese bottles. Dinner for two, without drinks: about €70.

paragraph1: Driving through Canada's boreal forests with my colleague Bryan Denton, I was struck speechless by the devastating aftermath of 2023's record-breaking wildfires. Where dense forests once stood, only blackened stumps remained, stretching endlessly across the scorched landscape. The destruction was so complete that local residents told us they were discovering geographical features they'd never seen before – hills, rivers, and even distant towns that had been hidden behind the thick forest canopy. As we navigated the desolate terrain, I couldn't shake the feeling of profound loss. The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.
paragraph2: As a reporter, I’ve experienced the aftermath of several disasters, including dam bursts, landslides and floods. But nothing quite prepared me to witness the extent of the destruction in Canada’s boreal forests that I saw in June, one year after the record-breaking wildfires of 2023. At one point, my colleague Bryan Denton and I drove for an entire hour and saw almost no living trees in the forests we could see from the road. Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.

paragraph1: Toni Braxton, the Grammy-winning R&B singer and actress, has always been protective of her personal space. "I'm old school, I'm aloof," she admits, reflecting on her initial reluctance to reboot the reality show "Braxton Family Values," which she starred in alongside her sisters Traci, Towanda, Trina, and Tamar. However, after Traci's passing from esophageal cancer in 2022, Toni decided to participate in the new series, "The Braxtons," as a tribute to her sister's memory. "She wanted us to keep going, to keep the show alive," Toni explains. The new series, which premiered on We TV and ALLBLK, takes a more somber tone, exploring themes of grief and healing as the family navigates life without Traci. "It's different without her, it's just not the same," Toni notes, her voice tinged with sadness. Despite her reservations, Toni has continued to thrive in her career, with recent stints on Broadway and a Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer. As she looks to the future, Toni is determined to keep her sister's memory alive, both on and off screen. "I'm doing this for Traci," she says, her voice filled with conviction.
paragraph2: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. “Not that I don’t love hanging out with my sisters — I’m just not comfortable with people being in my space like that,” she said. “I’m old school. I’m a bit aloof.” She ultimately did it for Traci, who died of esophageal cancer in 2022 and who had been adamant that her sisters continue with the show. Grief and healing are the main themes in the all-new series “The Braxtons,” which airs on We TV and is available on the streaming service ALLBLK. It isn’t the same without Traci, Toni Braxton said. “Part of our DNA is missing. Everyone is trying figure out how to live in this heartache.” Besides “Braxton Family Values,” Braxton is known for her roles on Broadway (“Beauty and the Beast,” “Aida,” “After Midnight”) and for her many R&B hits, including “Breathe Again,” “Another Sad Love Song” and “Un-Break My Heart” — which she performs in “Love & Laughter,” her joint Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer.

paragraph1: Michael and I first connected at Soul Motion, where we'd meet twice weekly to lose ourselves in dance. Our friendship blossomed naturally, punctuated by inside jokes and genuine laughter that carried over from the dance floor to cozy dinner gatherings with our circle of friends. paragraph1: In interviews, experts not involved in the case noted that when preterm labor starts before 24 weeks of gestation, the baby is extremely unlikely to survive, so hospitals do not generally take extraordinary measures to save the fetus. Labor in these cases can be protracted, so a woman who is admitted might be hospitalized for several days. Ms. Hermelyn turned to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn, a hospital that predominantly serves patients who are low-income, on Medicaid or uninsured, and where the staff knew her. They admitted her, sought to relieve her emotional distress and tried, but failed, to save the baby. The mother herself needed care, said Dr. Daniel Faustin, director of Wyckoff’s division of maternal and fetal medicine. Ms. Hermelyn had a high-risk pregnancy, and preterm labor put her at risk of serious infection. If she delivered at home, she would risk deadly hemorrhaging. “Even if you give up on the baby, you cannot give up on the mother,” he said. “The best place for her to be if she’s going to deliver is in the hospital, to make sure that after this unfortunate experience, her life is not at risk.”
paragraph2: At Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn, a hospital that predominantly serves low-income, Medicaid, or uninsured patients, Ms. Hermelyn, a woman experiencing preterm labor before 24 weeks of gestation, was recently admitted. In cases like hers, experts agree that the chances of the baby's survival are slim, and hospitals typically refrain from taking extraordinary measures to save the fetus. However, the staff at Wyckoff Heights, familiar with Ms. Hermelyn's situation, worked to alleviate her emotional distress while attempting to save the baby, despite the long odds. Although their efforts were ultimately unsuccessful, Dr. Daniel Faustin, the director of the hospital's division of maternal and fetal medicine, emphasized the importance of prioritizing Ms. Hermelyn's care, given her high-risk pregnancy and vulnerability to serious infection and hemorrhaging if she were to deliver at home. "The hospital is the safest place for her to be," Dr. Faustin stressed, highlighting the need to ensure Ms. Hermelyn's life was not at risk following this traumatic experience. Despite the tragic outcome, the hospital's efforts underscore the critical role that institutions like Wyckoff Heights play in providing vital care to vulnerable populations.

paragraph1:
Under the Tree
This squirrel stared at me, wondering why I was sitting under its tree. I always come to this tree when I feel out of sorts. I was supposed to have a date that day but never got a text back. Friends say it has nothing to do with me. Mom says, “You need higher self-esteem.” I love myself, but I’m slowly unraveling, trying to see myself the way I know I should. Under the tree with the squirrel staring at me, I thought, “It’s nice to have other living things acknowledge me.” — Mia Mitchell
paragraph2: The squirrel's beady eyes bore into me as I sit here under the maple tree, my phone clutched in my hand like some kind of lifeline. Three hours, seventeen minutes, and still no text back. Mom says I'm too good for someone who can't even bother to cancel properly, and Sarah keeps insisting I need to "know my worth," but right now, all I know is this hollow feeling in my chest. It's funny how a simple unanswered message can make you question everything about yourself. The squirrel tilts its head, probably wondering why I'm still here, and honestly, I'm wondering the same thing.

paragraph1: Savings Accounts and C.D.s What’s happening now: The rate reversal is likely to be most disappointing for savers, who have benefited from juicier yields on everything from online savings accounts and certificates of deposit to money market funds. Those are all likely to inch lower, in line with the Fed’s move, but some providers may move faster than others. That usually depends on whether the bank wants to attract new customers by dangling yields that are more attractive than their competitors’ offerings. But you can safely assume that online high-yield savings account will still offer more competitive rates than traditional commercial banks, whose yields have remained anemic throughout this period of higher interest rates (averaging 0.45 percent as of September, according to DepositAccounts.com, part of the online loan marketplace LendingTree).
paragraph2: Following a rate reversal by the Federal Reserve, the landscape for savers utilizing financial products such as online savings accounts, certificates of deposit (C.D.s), and money market funds is poised for change. These rates are anticipated to decrease, although the pace at which this occurs may differ among financial institutions. Banks are likely to adjust their rates based on their strategic goals, particularly their desire to attract new customers by offering competitive yields. Despite the overall downward trend, online high-yield savings accounts are expected to continue providing more favorable rates compared to traditional commercial banks, which have historically maintained lower yields. This shift highlights the importance of savers staying informed and potentially seeking out online options to maximize their returns amidst changing economic conditions.

paragraph1: In the gripping thriller set in 1995, police captain Ma Zhe, portrayed by Zhu Yilong, is tasked with solving the murder of Granny Four, a case that initially seems straightforward. The obvious suspect is "the madman," a character played by Kang Chunlei, whom Granny Four had taken under her wing. However, as Ma Zhe delves deeper, the investigation becomes increasingly complex. He follows a trail of cryptic clues, including a cassette tape found at the crime scene, which leads him to a mysterious woman. A conversation with Wang Jianyu, a suspiciously cooperative hairdresser, raises more questions than answers, keeping Ma Zhe - and the viewer - on edge.
paragraph2: The story, largely set in 1995, follows a police captain named Ma Zhe (Zhu Yilong) as he investigates the killing of a woman called Granny Four. At first, the case seems straightforward: Granny Four had taken in a simpleton who, throughout the movie, is known only as “the madman” (Kang Chunlei) — a natural suspect. But nothing is so clear-cut. Many of this thriller’s pleasures involve watching Ma Zhe chase leads, as he listens to a cassette found at the crime scene to try to locate a woman heard on it or questions a hairdresser (Wang Jianyu) who seems eager to be apprehended.

paragraph1: “She made sure that her deputies were very involved in the crafting of the language, and all of us who are working on it were very grateful that she was willing to lend her name and her office to the cause,” Mr. Chiu said. Attorneys in her office tried to help ensure that the bill could survive legal challenges they anticipated from anti-abortion groups, he said, adding that he appreciated “knowing that our bill was heavily vetted by her team. They were careful to make sure that it was well crafted.” Ms. Harris praised the bill in a public statement when Gov. Jerry Brown signed it into law. “I am proud to have cosponsored the Reproductive FACT Act, which ensures that all women have equal access to comprehensive reproductive health care services, and that they have the facts they need to make informed decisions about their health and their lives,” she said. The law was quickly challenged by crisis pregnancy centers, which sued Ms. Harris in her capacity as attorney general. Her successor, Xavier Becerra, became the defendant in the cases when he became the attorney general in 2017 after Ms. Harris was elected to the United States Senate. Judges at the district court and appellate court levels upheld the law, but in 2018, the Supreme Court sided with pregnancy centers in the case, invalidating the law.
paragraph2: Mr. Chiu's collaboration with Ms. Harris and her deputies proved instrumental in crafting the Reproductive FACT Act, a bill designed to withstand anticipated legal opposition from anti-abortion organizations. As the attorney general during this period, Ms. Harris played a pivotal role in shaping the legislation and publicly endorsed it upon its enactment by Governor Jerry Brown. The law, however, soon encountered significant resistance from crisis pregnancy centers, resulting in multiple legal challenges that initially named Ms. Harris as the defendant in her official capacity. Following her election to the United States Senate, these cases were transferred to her successor, Xavier Becerra, who continued to defend the law's constitutionality. Despite initial victories in lower courts that appeared to validate the careful legal groundwork laid by Ms. Harris and her team, the law's journey through the judicial system ultimately concluded with its invalidation by the Supreme Court in 2018. This outcome, while disappointing for its supporters, highlighted the complex interplay between state-level legislative efforts and federal constitutional interpretation, as well as the challenges faced by lawmakers in crafting legislation that can successfully navigate both immediate legal challenges and long-term judicial scrutiny.

paragraph1: In a lane north of elegant George Street, in the central New Town area, Cafe St. Honoré, a longstanding locals’ favorite, is overseen by the veteran Scottish chef Neil Forbes. Instead of the small shared plates that dominate modern dining, find hearty dishes of Scottish produce cooked with French finesse, such as a confit partridge leg sourced from the nearby Borders region (£32). Alongside a revolving à la carte menu, there is also a good-value set menu (£28.50 for two courses, £36 for three) at both lunch and dinner. Whisky is big business in Edinburgh, typified by the glitzy multistory Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street. For a more intimate tasting, opt for the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on nearby Queen Street, where one-off bottlings of whisky from a single cask carry eccentric titles inspired by their tasting notes.
paragraph2: At Cafe St. Honoré, nestled in the New Town area north of George Street, Neil Forbes brings a masterful touch to traditional Scottish cuisine with a French flair. As a seasoned Scottish chef, Forbes crafts hearty dishes that showcase the country's rich ingredients, such as the tender confit partridge leg. The cafe offers an à la carte menu, as well as a set menu that provides excellent value for both lunch and dinner. For those looking to immerse themselves in Edinburgh's whisky culture, the Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street is a popular destination. However, for a more intimate and unique whisky tasting experience, the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on Queen Street is a hidden gem, offering single-cask bottlings with creative names that are sure to delight even the most discerning palates.

paragraph1: “Over time, you will suffer less, essentially,” said Dr. Riris, an archaeologist at Bournemouth University in England. “There tends not to be wholesale collapse.” The researchers tracked the history of societies by taking advantage of the way archaeologists tell time. Most organic material, whether it’s charcoal or mussel shells, contains trace amounts of radioactive carbon-14, which gradually breaks down over thousands of years. By measuring the carbon-14 left at an archaeological site, researchers can estimate its age. This approach can also track population changes. As human groups get bigger, they burn more wood, eat more food and leave behind more garbage, all of which can be dated. When those groups shrink, their sites become rarer.
paragraph2: Dr. Riris, an archaeologist at Bournemouth University, elucidates a method employed by researchers to explore the historical trajectory of societies. She articulates how societies typically do not undergo total collapse over time. Instead, researchers utilize the decay of radioactive carbon-14 in organic materials to approximate the age of archaeological sites. This radiocarbon dating technique is instrumental in tracing population changes, as it allows scientists to infer the size of human groups from the amount of physical evidence they leave behind. Larger groups tend to leave more substantial remnants, such as burned wood and food remains, which can be precisely dated, whereas smaller groups leave fewer traces, making their historical footprint less discernible.

paragraph1: In 2013, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum unveiled an exhibition to honor the 40th anniversary of martial arts legend Bruce Lee's untimely death at 32. This captivating display showcases an array of memorabilia from Lee's illustrious life, celebrating his multifaceted talents and enduring legacy. Visitors can marvel at footage of Lee's impressive cha-cha dance moves, examine his punching bags, and explore his meticulously planned training schedules. The exhibition also features his 1970s sweaters and the iconic yellow tracksuit from "Game of Death." For those eager to delve into Lee's world, bus 170 offers the most convenient transport option from Causeway Bay to the museum, ensuring easy access to this remarkable tribute.
paragraph2: Hong Kong has produced plenty of film stars, but few have left as indelible a mark on the city as Bruce Lee, the martial arts legend. To mark the 40th anniversary of Lee’s untimely death at 32, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum opened an excellent exhibition on his life in 2013, gathering memorabilia from his early years (including footage of his smooth cha-cha dance moves), along with his well-worn punching bags, old training schedules, skintight 1970s sweaters, and the famous yellow tracksuit he wore in “Game of Death,” which Lee was filming when he died. The best transport option is bus 170, which connects directly to Causeway Bay.

paragraph1: As you watch your friends embark on an international adventure without you, it's natural to feel left out. But consider this: traveling in a group of four is often more convenient than five, with easier seating arrangements and accommodation options. It's not that your friends don't value your company, but rather that they may have been forced to make practical decisions. When traveling with others, personal rhythms and preferences can also come into play, and sometimes it's simply easier to coordinate with a smaller group. paragraph1: In her second year overseeing the sports program, Ms. Page initially believed the benefits of athletics lay primarily in participation and personal growth, rather than in winning titles, which she assumed were the domain of larger schools. However, her perspective began to shift as she witnessed the dedication and determination of the head coach, Tamara Karcher, and her assistant, Steven Rabinowitz, who tirelessly motivated the players to overcome numerous challenges. Ms. Karcher, in particular, faced several logistical hurdles, such as securing playing fields for practice and games. One memorable incident involved a man who refused to leave a dugout, necessitating police intervention to resolve the situation. Although this ordeal was unpleasant for the team, it underscored the persistent issues they encountered in maintaining access to adequate facilities. Despite these challenges, Ms. Page came to appreciate the resilience and teamwork fostered by the sports program, recognizing that its true value extended beyond mere participation and growth, potentially even towards achieving competitive success.
paragraph2: Ms. Page, who is in her second year in charge, always assumed that any athletic rewards would come in the form of participation, camaraderie, personal development and enjoyment. A citywide sports title was the terrain of the big high schools. But she credited the head coach, Tamara Karcher, and her assistant, Steven Rabinowitz, a history teacher at Baccalaureate, for inspiring the best from the players, whose love of the game helped them work through the logistical obstacles. Ms. Karcher said the biggest headache she faced was clearing people off fields before games when the team had a permit to use them. Sometimes there’s a soccer game happening, or kids are goofing off. Earlier this season, a man reading a book in a dugout refused to leave, claiming he was not bothering anyone. But it was a potentially unsafe situation. “The cops got involved, and I’ll just leave it at that,” Ms. Karcher said. “It’s unpleasant for the girls to have to deal with that.”

paragraph1: Despite being launched several months ago, Apple's Vision Pro faces significant challenges due to the scarcity of quality apps available for the device. Major apps like YouTube, Netflix, Spotify, Instagram, and DoorDash are noticeably absent, largely due to corporate competition and a lack of developer confidence. Companies such as Google and Meta, who have their own virtual reality ambitions, show hesitation in supporting Apple's product, fearing it may bolster a competitor in a rapidly evolving market. Developers are equally cautious, reluctant to invest time and resources into creating apps for a platform that has yet to see substantial user adoption, as evidenced by the meager 2,000 apps developed so far. Compounding the issue, Apple has been slow to expand its own content offerings for the Vision Pro. The company has released a few immersive videos through Apple TV, including a prehistoric nature film and a rehearsal video of Alicia Keys and her band, designed to showcase the device's impressive high-definition graphics and spatial audio capabilities. While these videos represent some of the best experiences currently available on the Vision Pro, they are insufficient to compensate for the lack of third-party app support. The combination of these factors presents a considerable hurdle for Apple as it seeks to establish the Vision Pro as a dominant force in the virtual reality market.
paragraph2: But the biggest disappointment with the Vision Pro is how few good apps there are. Several months after its debut, there’s still no native YouTube or Netflix app. There’s no Spotify, no Instagram, no DoorDash. (You can still use some of these services in a web browser, or use unofficial third-party apps, but it’s a worse experience.) Some of these apps are missing because of corporate infighting. (Google and Meta, for example, have their own virtual reality ambitions and presumably don’t want to give Apple’s product a boost by making apps for it.) But others amount to a lack of confidence. Developers don’t want to make apps for platforms that nobody uses, and their reluctance so far — only about 2,000 apps have been developed for the Vision Pro, Apple said on Monday — says something about the device’s tepid reception. Apple has also been slow to update its own offerings for the Vision Pro, like a series of “immersive videos,” filmed on special 3-D cameras and released through Apple TV. These videos — which included a prehistoric nature film and a “rehearsal room” video of Alicia Keys and her band as they perform a song — were designed to show off the Vision Pro’s high-definition graphics and its “spatial audio” feature, and they are among the best things you can do with a Vision Pro.

paragraph1: Hong Kong has produced plenty of film stars, but few have left as indelible a mark on the city as Bruce Lee, the martial arts legend. To mark the 40th anniversary of Lee’s untimely death at 32, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum opened an excellent exhibition on his life in 2013, gathering memorabilia from his early years (including footage of his smooth cha-cha dance moves), along with his well-worn punching bags, old training schedules, skintight 1970s sweaters, and the famous yellow tracksuit he wore in “Game of Death,” which Lee was filming when he died. The best transport option is bus 170, which connects directly to Causeway Bay.
paragraph2: In 2013, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum unveiled an exhibition to honor the 40th anniversary of martial arts legend Bruce Lee's untimely death at 32. This captivating display showcases an array of memorabilia from Lee's illustrious life, celebrating his multifaceted talents and enduring legacy. Visitors can marvel at footage of Lee's impressive cha-cha dance moves, examine his punching bags, and explore his meticulously planned training schedules. The exhibition also features his 1970s sweaters and the iconic yellow tracksuit from "Game of Death." For those eager to delve into Lee's world, bus 170 offers the most convenient transport option from Causeway Bay to the museum, ensuring easy access to this remarkable tribute.

paragraph1: Our Children’s Trust, a nonprofit law firm, has recently petitioned the Supreme Court to overturn an appellate court's decision, seeking to have their case returned to the district court for trial. The group argues that the government has been overly focused on procedural issues at the expense of addressing the substantive merits of the case. This legal maneuver underscores their ongoing commitment to advocating for environmental justice and climate accountability. Notably, the Justice Department has not yet issued any comments regarding this petition, leaving the future of the case uncertain. This move comes on the heels of a major victory for Our Children’s Trust in Hawaii, where they successfully negotiated a settlement with the state government to decarbonize its transportation system. This achievement highlights the organization's ability to effect significant change at the state level, potentially setting a precedent for similar cases across the nation. By pushing for the case to be reconsidered in a district court, Our Children’s Trust aims to shift the focus back to the core issues of the lawsuit, emphasizing the need for governmental accountability in environmental policies. Their efforts continue to spotlight the critical intersection of legal advocacy and environmental sustainability, reinforcing their role as a formidable force in the fight against climate change.
paragraph2: On Thursday, the group filed a petition with the Supreme Court asking it to vacate the ruling of the appellate court and send it back to the district court to stand trial. The filing argued that the government had bogged down the case in procedural issues rather than letting it be decided on its merits. The Justice Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The plaintiffs are represented by Our Children’s Trust, a nonprofit law firm based in Eugene, Ore., that has filed similar lawsuits and legal actions based on constitutional claims across the country. Their strategy scored a big win in Hawaii in June, when Gov. Josh Green announced a settlement with the plaintiffs, who had sued the state’s Department of Transportation over its use of fossil fuels. As part of the agreement, the state said it would decarbonize its transportation system within 20 years, expand bicycle lanes and increase spending on electric-vehicle chargers. paragraph1: Like many literary and cinematic fables before it — think of “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” or “The Elephant Man” — “A Different Man” is really a morality play, of a kind. It’s just that the moral isn’t all that straightforward. It’s about a societal obsession with particular standards of beauty. The fact that conventionally attractive people, or people with certain features and skin colors, tend to encounter more success in life simply by dint of genetic luck is explicit throughout. But that fact is so obvious, and stated so blatantly outright, that it feels like a joke.
paragraph2: "A Different Man" serves as a modern morality play, echoing the thematic depth of classic fables like "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "The Elephant Man." It scrutinizes society's obsession with rigid beauty standards, exposing how those deemed conventionally attractive often succeed through mere genetic fortune. The narrative's overt presentation of this reality injects a touch of humor into its critique. By adopting a third-person perspective, the work provides an analytical lens on its themes, exploring the superficial values that dictate societal success and the moral implications of such biases, without anchoring the analysis to any one character's viewpoint.

paragraph1: In the heart of Buenos Aires' Colegiales neighborhood, Chef Antonio Soriano is redefining Argentine cuisine at Astor Manduque Porteño. This intimate restaurant offers a constantly evolving menu that showcases Soriano's innovative approach to traditional dishes. Adventurous diners can indulge in creative offerings such as blood sausage tempura and beef tongue salad, with the option to choose from three, five, or all eight available dishes. Portion sizes adjust accordingly, ensuring a satisfying experience. To complement the meal, a thoughtfully curated wine pairing is available, striking a perfect balance between quality and quantity. With each bite, Soriano's passion for Argentine cuisine shines through, making Astor Manduque Porteño a must-visit destination for foodies and locals alike.
paragraph2:
4. Modern Argentina | 10:30 p.m.
Head to the quietly trending Colegiales neighborhood for dinner (around 1,300 pesos with wine for two) at Astor Manduque Porteño (the name translates, roughly, to “where locals eat”). The chef Antonio Soriano is a leading light of the new school of Argentine cooking, and his oft-changing menu is packed with creative dishes, which recently included blood sausage tempura and a salad of beef tongue. There are just eight dishes on offer at any one time, and diners can opt to try three, five or all of the choices, with course size diminishing proportionately. Add the wine pairing, which doesn’t skimp on quality or quantity.

paragraph1: At Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn, a hospital that predominantly serves low-income, Medicaid, or uninsured patients, Ms. Hermelyn, a woman experiencing preterm labor before 24 weeks of gestation, was recently admitted. In cases like hers, experts agree that the chances of the baby's survival are slim, and hospitals typically refrain from taking extraordinary measures to save the fetus. However, the staff at Wyckoff Heights, familiar with Ms. Hermelyn's situation, worked to alleviate her emotional distress while attempting to save the baby, despite the long odds. Although their efforts were ultimately unsuccessful, Dr. Daniel Faustin, the director of the hospital's division of maternal and fetal medicine, emphasized the importance of prioritizing Ms. Hermelyn's care, given her high-risk pregnancy and vulnerability to serious infection and hemorrhaging if she were to deliver at home. "The hospital is the safest place for her to be," Dr. Faustin stressed, highlighting the need to ensure Ms. Hermelyn's life was not at risk following this traumatic experience. Despite the tragic outcome, the hospital's efforts underscore the critical role that institutions like Wyckoff Heights play in providing vital care to vulnerable populations.
paragraph2: In interviews, experts not involved in the case noted that when preterm labor starts before 24 weeks of gestation, the baby is extremely unlikely to survive, so hospitals do not generally take extraordinary measures to save the fetus. Labor in these cases can be protracted, so a woman who is admitted might be hospitalized for several days. Ms. Hermelyn turned to Wyckoff Heights Medical Center in Brooklyn, a hospital that predominantly serves patients who are low-income, on Medicaid or uninsured, and where the staff knew her. They admitted her, sought to relieve her emotional distress and tried, but failed, to save the baby. The mother herself needed care, said Dr. Daniel Faustin, director of Wyckoff’s division of maternal and fetal medicine. Ms. Hermelyn had a high-risk pregnancy, and preterm labor put her at risk of serious infection. If she delivered at home, she would risk deadly hemorrhaging. “Even if you give up on the baby, you cannot give up on the mother,” he said. “The best place for her to be if she’s going to deliver is in the hospital, to make sure that after this unfortunate experience, her life is not at risk.”

paragraph1: Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.
paragraph2: The piece has yet another unique element that Dr. Maldonado discovered as she sketched it. “I realized that below the head of the decapitated person there is a glyph that is possibly the name of the person whose head was cut off,” she said. Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.

Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. paragraph1: The pair’s relationship, a key story line in Season 2, is a “fresh flavor” for the show, McKay said: “It’s like a little Hitchcock in there. And also the sense of a descent and a very dark, toxic relationship.” Edwards, a prolific stage actor, said he was struck by the similarities between the character of Celebrimbor and Shakespeare’s Richard II, whom he has played onstage — including the smith’s susceptibility to flattery. Edwards learned how to forge a ring, with the help of a jeweler (there is a ringmaking scene where this came in handy). The series, which moved its base from New Zealand to Britain for Season 2, has weathered production disruptions, like much of Hollywood. Covid lockdowns stopped filming for its first season, and then, three weeks before the end of shooting this season, according to the showrunners, the union for writers in Hollywood went on strike. “That was one of the most challenging moments for us as showrunners on this show,” McKay said. “But we had to stand with our guild and had to step away.” At that point, much of the writing for Season 2 was complete, according to J.D. Payne, the other showrunner, and the pair charged Brandstrom, the director, and Lindsey Weber, one of the show’s executive producers — neither of whom were in the writing union — with finishing production.
paragraph2: During the production of Season 2, the television series navigated a multitude of challenges, both logistical and creative, which significantly shaped the final product. The relocation of filming from New Zealand to Britain marked a pivotal shift, compounded by the disruptions caused by Covid lockdowns and a writers' strike. These obstacles necessitated innovative solutions from the team, led by showrunners McKay and J.D. Payne. Amidst these challenges, McKay highlighted the evolving relationship between two central characters, describing it as a "fresh flavor" infused with Hitchcockian elements and a dark, toxic dynamic that added depth to the narrative. Actor Edwards, who portrayed Celebrimbor, found a unique connection between his character and Shakespeare's Richard II, noting their mutual vulnerability to flattery. This thematic exploration was further enriched by Edwards' commitment to authenticity, as he learned the intricate art of ring forging for a crucial scene. When the writers' strike forced McKay and Payne to pause their involvement, they entrusted the completion of production to director Brandstrom and executive producer Lindsey Weber, who were not bound by union restrictions. With much of the writing already completed, Brandstrom and Weber skillfully navigated the remaining hurdles, ensuring that the season maintained its creative vision despite the turbulent production process.

paragraph1: MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?
paragraph2: As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.

paragraph1: Forgive me for wondering: Is he referring to “an eye for an eye” or the stoning of disobedient children? Either way, for both Trump and true believers, it hardly matters that the First Amendment was intended to protect religion from the state, not to have the state impose a religion. (So much for originalism.) Their goal is to impose one form of religion, Christianity, and the underlying message is that those who do not share it will have to submit. Not only have such moves been declared unconstitutional (“I can’t wait to be sued,” Landry said), but they are also exclusionary and offensive to many. Despite what the Christian nationalist movement would have you believe, America was not founded as a Christian nation. Nor is it one today. In a pluralistic country, neither the Bible nor Judeo-Christian values are universal, including in the two heavily Christian Southern states in which these laws were passed.
paragraph2: Reflecting on the actions and motivations of certain political figures, I find myself questioning whether individuals like Trump and Landry are driven by a literal interpretation of biblical principles, such as "an eye for an eye" or the stoning of disobedient children. Their apparent disregard for the First Amendment, designed to protect religion from state interference, is deeply concerning. It seems they are advancing an agenda that aligns with the Christian nationalist movement, which erroneously claims that America was founded as a Christian nation. However, this perspective overlooks the pluralistic foundation of our country and the constitutional prohibition against imposing a single religion. Such actions are not only unconstitutional but also exclusionary and offensive, particularly in the Southern states where these laws have been enacted. They undermine the diverse fabric of our nation and threaten the freedom of religion that is supposed to be a cornerstone of American democracy, disregarding the rights of those who hold different beliefs.

paragraph1: I met my partner when I was just nineteen, serving drinks at a local bar where life seemed simpler than it is now. Unlike my mother and grandmother, who followed the traditional path of early marriage and settled domesticity, our relationship took a different turn. We fell hard and fast, young and fearless enough to pack our lives into boxes and move to a new state, where we adopted our beloved puppy, Mansfield, who became our first shared responsibility. There was a time when marriage seemed inevitable – my partner even bought a ring – but I wasn't ready then, and somehow, the right moment never came again. Sometimes I wonder if I've disappointed my family by not following in their conventional footsteps, but our love story has written its own rules. Society's expectations weigh heavily at times, whispering doubts about the legitimacy of a partnership without marriage certificates and shared last names. Yet, I've learned to navigate these waters with a practiced smile and well-timed jokes, masking the complexity of our chosen path. Behind my carefully curated image of success and contentment lies a deeper truth: that love doesn't always need traditional validation to be real, even if explaining that to others remains a constant challenge.
paragraph2: But the truth is that my circumstances were different from my mother’s and grandmother’s. First, we never got married. We met when I was 19, tending bar at an on-campus performing arts center. I gave him a free drink, and he took out my recycling. He was so handsome that he should have been vain, but he wasn’t, and he liked animals more than people. We merged our lives and moved to a new state. We adopted a hound puppy and named him Mansfield, after the town where we fell in love. Early on, my partner bought a ring and then returned it, correctly assuming that I wasn’t ready for marriage. He didn’t mention this until years later when he had three jalapeño margaritas on vacation and confessed, sputtering, “Did I never tell you that?” By the time I was 30, most of our friends were married, but it had never felt like the right time for us. When people asked him why we hadn’t tied the knot, he would say that he was waiting for me to propose. I’d cite economics and feminism while harboring a feeling I admitted to no one: Things had gotten hard at times, and someday I might need an out. Our life was beautiful but not without its shadows, a fact that I hid behind a veneer of professional success and witty banter.

paragraph1: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, plans to shut its San Francisco office “over the next few weeks,” according to an internal email obtained by The New York Times. In the email, which X’s chief executive, Linda Yaccarino, sent to employees on Monday, the company said workers would move to existing offices in San Jose, Calif. X will also open an engineering-focused office in Palo Alto, Calif., which it will share with xAI, the artificial intelligence outfit owned by Mr. Musk, the email said. “This is an important decision that impacts many of you, but it is the right one for our company in the long term,” Ms. Yaccarino wrote to employees.
paragraph2: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, is set to close its San Francisco office in the coming weeks, according to an internal email sent by the company's chief executive, Linda Yaccarino. Additionally, a new engineering-focused office will be established in Palo Alto, California, which will be shared with xAI, another Musk-owned company. Ms. Yaccarino emphasized that while the move will have an impact, it is a strategic decision that will ultimately benefit the company in the long term. The closure marks a significant shift for X, as it consolidates its Bay Area presence.

paragraph1: In 1999, the gray area between truth and fiction, where the person seated to your left believed the opposite of the person seated to your right, was contained safely with the movie’s run time. And as we all left the theater, we collectively realized it was all a ride. Now, in a way, that ride never ends. And perhaps most unnerving is the knowledge that each one of us is living in an increasingly unique version of the world, making reality less of a communal experience than ever.
paragraph2: As I look back on 1999, I recall a time when the line between truth and fiction was blissfully clear. We'd enter a movie theater, suspend our disbelief, and for two hours, contradictory realities coexisted. But as the credits rolled, we'd exit into a shared world, collectively acknowledging the fantasy we'd just witnessed. Fast forward to today, and it's as if we've never left the theater. Each of us now inhabits a bespoke reality, making it increasingly disorienting to find common ground. Your truth, my truth – the notion of a shared reality feels like a relic of the past.

X will also open an engineering-focused office in Palo Alto, Calif., which it will share with xAI, the artificial intelligence outfit owned by Mr. Musk, the email said. “This is an important decision that impacts many of you, but it is the right one for our company in the long term,” Ms. Yaccarino wrote to employees.
paragraph2: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, is set to close its San Francisco office in the coming weeks, according to an internal email sent by the company's chief executive, Linda Yaccarino. The decision, outlined in the email to employees, will involve relocating staff to existing offices in San Jose, California. Additionally, a new engineering-focused office will be established in Palo Alto, California, which will be shared with xAI, another Musk-owned company. Ms. Yaccarino emphasized that while the move will have an impact, it is a strategic decision that will ultimately benefit the company in the long term. The closure marks a significant shift for X, as it consolidates its Bay Area presence.

paragraph1: (The New York Times has sued OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, claiming copyright infringement of news content related to A.I. systems.) Like Google, Meta and Microsoft, OpenAI offers online chatbots and other A.I. tools that can write social media posts, generate photorealistic images and write computer programs. In its report, the company said its tools had been used in influence campaigns that researchers had tracked for years, including a Russian campaign called Doppelganger and a Chinese campaign called Spamouflage. The Doppelganger campaign used OpenAI’s technology to generate anti-Ukraine comments that were posted on X in English, French, German, Italian and Polish, OpenAI said. The company’s tools were also used to translate and edit articles that supported Russia in the war in Ukraine into English and French, and to convert anti-Ukraine news articles into Facebook posts.
paragraph2: The New York Times has filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, alleging copyright infringement related to news content used in AI systems. OpenAI, a company that provides AI tools capable of generating social media posts, images, and computer programs, similar to industry giants Google and Meta, has seen its technology utilized in influence campaigns worldwide. Notably, a Russian campaign dubbed Doppelganger leveraged OpenAI's tools to create anti-Ukraine comments in multiple languages, as well as translate and edit pro-Russian articles into English and French, converting them into Facebook posts. Similarly, a Chinese campaign known as Spamouflage has also employed OpenAI's technology. The lawsuit marks a significant development in the ongoing debate over the use of AI-generated content and its implications for media outlets and intellectual property rights.

paragraph1: Still, Ms. Reeves showed some restraint in the face of pressure to inject a lot more cash into Britain’s struggling public services. She announced more money in the next few years, especially for teachers, defense and local authorities. But starting in 2026, day-to-day spending for government departments would grow on average 1.3 percent annually, after accounting for inflation, which analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies said would still leave some departments with very tight budgets. At the same time, Ms. Reeves also set to increase public investment. She said that over the next five years, the government would increase capital spending by £100 billion to invest in projects, such as school buildings, hospital beds and diagnostics centers. In all, Ms. Reeves’s measures will temporarily aid the economy but leave its size “largely unchanged” in five years, the Office for Budget Responsibility said. It forecast slightly higher growth for this year and next, but said growth would then slow to below 2 percent a year. However, a sustained increase in public investment would raise the supply potential of the economy, which could increase long-term growth, the budget responsibility office said.
paragraph2: Ms. Reeves demonstrated a measured approach to fiscal policy while facing mounting pressure to boost Britain's public service funding. Her announcement outlined increased funding allocations over the coming years, with specific focus on teachers, defense, and local authorities, though she maintained strict control by capping day-to-day departmental spending growth at 1.3 percent annually from 2026, accounting for inflation. The Institute for Fiscal Studies' analysis suggested this conservative approach would create challenging financial constraints for certain departments. A notable aspect of her strategy included a substantial £100 billion increase in public investment over five years, targeting critical infrastructure such as school buildings and hospitals. The Office for Budget Responsibility's assessment indicated that while these measures would provide temporary economic support, they would not substantially alter the economy's size within five years, as growth was projected to decelerate below 2 percent annually. Nevertheless, they acknowledged that the increased public investment could potentially enhance the economy's capacity for long-term growth.

paragraph1: The deliberate approach to the Starliner spacecraft's return reflects a commitment to thorough safety protocols and inclusive decision-making. "While this process may take longer, we must consider every voice at the table," he explained, emphasizing the delicate balance between progress and precaution. Boeing has affirmed its preparedness to support NASA's mission, placing astronaut safety at the forefront of operations. Mr. Bowersox indicated that the selection of astronauts for return would follow an extensive review process, though the ultimate authority lies with NASA Administrator Bill Nelson. This methodical strategy underscores the complex nature of space operations and the paramount importance of crew safety.
paragraph2: With the more inclusive process, “I recognize that that may mean, at times, we don’t move very fast,” he said. “We need to be very careful to make sure that everybody’s perspective is shared.” In a statement, Boeing said that it was ready to support NASA for the return of Starliner, with or without the astronauts. The company was “focused first and foremost on ensuring the safety of the astronauts,” it said. Mr. Bowersox said that he would make a decision on how to bring the astronauts home after the agencywide review, although Bill Nelson, the NASA administrator, would have the final call.

paragraph1: Stepping into Baltimore's Paper Moon Diner feels like entering a whimsical time capsule where eclectic decor meets comfort food. The walls, splashed with vibrant hues, serve as a backdrop for an extraordinary collection of vintage treasures, from Radio Flyer wagons to miniature robots and an army of dolls watching diners from every corner. This retro wonderland complements the classic American fare, with apple-smoked bacon sizzling on plates alongside perfectly poached eggs Benedict and fluffy made-to-order omelets, while servers keep the coffee flowing endlessly in true diner tradition.
paragraph2: The Paper Moon Diner, a Baltimore institution near the Baltimore Museum of Art, is decorated floor to ceiling with retro toys. Dolls and Radio Flyer wagons are wedged between ceiling beams, the windows and tables are painted in bright primary colors, and walls are covered with a quirky collection of miniature robots, dart boards and the occasional tree branch. The menu of diner classics hits the mark with apple-smoked bacon, eggs Benedict and made-to-order omelets. Soak in the atmosphere over a bottomless cup of coffee. Breakfast for two, around $30.

paragraph1: In the ongoing legal saga surrounding Purdue Pharma and the Sackler family, Judge Sean H. Lane, who presides over the Purdue bankruptcy cases, has opted to maintain a pause on lawsuits against both Purdue and the Sacklers during a designated mediation period. This pause comes amidst strategic legal maneuvers by a government-appointed committee representing the creditors, who have taken significant steps by filing a claim against the Sacklers. They accuse the family of illicitly transferring $11.5 billion from Purdue Pharma in an effort to shield these assets from potential litigation, a move commonly referred to as fraudulent conveyance. This tactic is frequently employed in bankruptcy cases as creditors strive to reclaim funds they contend were improperly reallocated. The committee's filing is comprehensive, including a request for a jury trial and a meticulously crafted draft complaint. Notably, Purdue Pharma itself is not directly advancing this claim; however, the company has shown its endorsement of the creditors' actions. Purdue has indicated that should mediation not yield a resolution, litigation will become an inevitable course, with the creditors' committee being optimally positioned to manage these claims. This expression of support underscores the intricate legal dynamics at play, as the stakeholders navigate a complex landscape of mediation and potential litigation to address the contentious financial maneuvers executed by the Sackler family amidst Purdue's bankruptcy proceedings.
paragraph2: Groups of plaintiffs had long been planning for this outcome. On Tuesday, Judge Sean H. Lane of the U. S. Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, N.Y., who oversees the Purdue cases, said the lawsuits against Purdue and the Sacklers would continue to be paused during the mediation period. The intent of the recent spate of filings is to paint a vivid picture of the legal onslaught that the Sacklers would be likely to face should the short window of time for allotted mediation slam shut without a deal. A filing this week from a government-appointed committee representing a broad group of creditors argues that the Sacklers illegally siphoned $11.5 billion from Purdue in less than a decade to wall off the money from potential litigation. That kind of claim, known as fraudulent conveyance, is a standard move in bankruptcy court in which creditors can seek to reclaim money they believe has been illegally squirreled away and should be included in distributions to them. The creditors’ filing included both a request to bring the case and a 200-page draft of their prospective complaint, in which they requested a jury trial. Although Purdue is not directly pursuing this claim against its owners, the company said on Tuesday that it supported the action. “If a consensual resolution is not reached through mediation, however, litigation will be necessary, and we believe the creditors’ committee is the party best situated to prosecute these claims,” Purdue said in a statement.

paragraph1:
8 p.m. Eat dinner in a box
Sofía Pfannl, a Paraguayan chef, and José Miguel Burga, a Peruvian sommelier, met while working at Central, the acclaimed restaurant in Lima. Their backstory is tangible at Pakuri, the restaurant they own together in the modish Villa Morra district. In the chic space of repurposed shipping containers, they serve Peruvian-style ceviche, chicharrones and ají amarillo alongside Paraguayan manioc chips, sweet potato purée and butternut squash fettuccine. While José’s wine list is a roll call of South America’s best vineyards, the atmosphere remains unstuffy: the restaurant has a youthful cohort of cooks and servers, a basketball game is often on the T.V. behind the bar, and the owners’ pets wander around. Outside, a verdant patio faces a quiet cobbled street.
paragraph2: At Pakuri, nestled in the Villa Morra district, diners are treated to a unique culinary experience crafted by Paraguayan chef Sofía Pfannl and Peruvian sommelier José Miguel Burga. The restaurant, housed in repurposed shipping containers, exudes a chic yet relaxed atmosphere. The menu is an exquisite fusion of Peruvian and Paraguayan flavors, featuring dishes like ceviche, chicharrones, and ají amarillo, complemented by manioc chips, sweet potato purée, and butternut squash fettuccine. José's expertly curated wine list highlights the finest vineyards of South America. Despite its sophisticated offerings, the ambiance remains laid-back, with a young staff, a basketball game playing on TV, and the owners' pets freely exploring the space. The lush patio, opening onto a serene cobbled street, enhances the dining experience.

paragraph1: 12) 11 a.m. Jet off Though closed this summer, because of the high water level affecting the dock, the Whirlpool Jet Boat Tour facility in Niagara-on-the-Lake should be open next year (this season customers are being sent to their other outlet at Niagara Falls). Don’t miss the chance to ride on their custom-built vessels that navigate the strong rapids on the lower Niagara River, a seven-mile gorge carved out by the strong currents in the Niagara River. With hundreds of thousands of gallons of water flowing over the falls every minute, it is a journey like no other. Get wet on this wild ride to acclimate back to reality after the quiet of Niagara-on-the-Lake. Cost: 69.95 dollars for an adult and 44.95 dollars for children, who must be at least 40 inches tall.
paragraph2: The Whirlpool Jet Boat Tour facility in Niagara-on-the-Lake has temporarily suspended operations for the summer season due to elevated water levels impacting the dock infrastructure. While this location remains closed, adventure seekers are being directed to the company's alternative outlet in Niagara Falls, where they can still experience the exhilarating journey through the lower Niagara River's powerful rapids. The tour features specially designed vessels that navigate through the churning waters, offering visitors an unforgettable combination of scenic views and heart-pounding excitement. Adult tickets are available for purchase, while children meeting the minimum height requirement can participate at a reduced rate. Management anticipates reopening the Niagara-on-the-Lake facility next year once water levels return to normal, allowing them to resume operations at both locations.

paragraph1: Mr. Ruddy appeared at a news conference at the league’s office in Manhattan to announce the deal but didn’t anticipate the backlash from its coverage in the news media. The presence of Mr. Ruddy at the news conference so enraged Charles Bluhdorn, the combustible chairman of Gulf & Western, Paramount’s parent, that he fired him. But when Mr. Bluhdorn told Francis Ford Coppola, the director, and Robert Evans, the studio’s vice president of production, to find another producer, Mr. Coppola intervened. “Al Ruddy’s the only guy who can keep this movie going!” he told Mr. Bluhdorn. “The Godfather” won three Oscars, including Mr. Ruddy’s for best picture; for best actor, for Marlon Brando’s portrayal of Don Vito Corleone; and for best adapted screenplay, by Mr. Coppola and Mr. Puzo. The film has been widely praised as one of the best movies ever made.

The film in question was "The Godfather," which went on to achieve remarkable success. It won three Oscars, with Mr. Ruddy receiving the award for Best Picture, Marlon Brando being honored as Best Actor, and the award for Best Adapted Screenplay going to Mr. Coppola and Mr. Puzo. Celebrated as one of the greatest movies ever made, "The Godfather" solidified its place in cinematic history, demonstrating the importance of perseverance and collaboration in the face of adversity.
