paragraph1: As Ms. Walz enters the national stage, critics on the right are already trying to portray her — as they have with her husband — as a left-wing radical who countenanced the civil unrest in her state after the death George Floyd. But at home in Minnesota, where she has spent most of her life, friends and political observers describe her as the coolheaded and ultracompetent counterpart to a man known for an intuitive and charismatic political style. “We have always worked as a partnership,” Ms. Walz, 58, told the self-improvement podcast “What If It Works” last month, later adding, “We are still one another’s closest advisers.” Ms. Walz did not comment for this article. The first gubernatorial spouse in Minnesota to keep an office in the state capital, Ms. Walz regularly advises her husband and has used her platform to advance policy initiatives, most significantly around offering college degree programs to inmates. Raised in the tiny farming town of Ivanhoe, Minn., only a 15-minute drive from South Dakota’s eastern border, Ms. Walz is the daughter of schoolteachers, and the eldest of four sisters. Ms. Walz was a caretaker in the family, according to her youngest sister, Heidi Ohlmann. “She’s always looking out for everyone,” Ms. Ohlmann said in an interview.
paragraph2: As Ms. Walz steps into the national spotlight, critics have been quick to paint her as a left-wing radical, particularly focusing on her and her husband's political responses in the aftermath of George Floyd's death. Yet within Minnesota's borders, she has cultivated a markedly different reputation as a steady, competent presence that effectively balances her husband's more outgoing personality. At 58, Ms. Walz embraces her role as both partner and adviser to her husband, maintaining an active presence in the state capital where she advocates for progressive initiatives, including educational programs for incarcerated individuals. "I've always seen my role as a partner," she notes, reflecting on her position in the administration. Her roots run deep in Minnesota, where she grew up in Ivanhoe as the eldest of four sisters, born to parents who were both educators. This background appears to have shaped her nurturing approach to public service, with her sister Heidi Ohlmann observing, "She's always been the caretaker of the family." Despite the attempts to characterize her through a partisan lens, Ms. Walz continues to focus on her work, leveraging her measured approach to advance her policy objectives while maintaining her distinctive leadership style.

paragraph1: But the truth is that my circumstances were different from my mother’s and grandmother’s. First, we never got married. We met when I was 19, tending bar at an on-campus performing arts center. I gave him a free drink, and he took out my recycling. He was so handsome that he should have been vain, but he wasn’t, and he liked animals more than people. We merged our lives and moved to a new state. We adopted a hound puppy and named him Mansfield, after the town where we fell in love. Early on, my partner bought a ring and then returned it, correctly assuming that I wasn’t ready for marriage. He didn’t mention this until years later when he had three jalapeño margaritas on vacation and confessed, sputtering, “Did I never tell you that?” By the time I was 30, most of our friends were married, but it had never felt like the right time for us. When people asked him why we hadn’t tied the knot, he would say that he was waiting for me to propose. I’d cite economics and feminism while harboring a feeling I admitted to no one: Things had gotten hard at times, and someday I might need an out. Our life was beautiful but not without its shadows, a fact that I hid behind a veneer of professional success and witty banter.
paragraph2: I met my partner when I was just nineteen, serving drinks at a local bar where life seemed simpler than it is now. Unlike my mother and grandmother, who followed the traditional path of early marriage and settled domesticity, our relationship took a different turn. We fell hard and fast, young and fearless enough to pack our lives into boxes and move to a new state, where we adopted our beloved puppy, Mansfield, who became our first shared responsibility. There was a time when marriage seemed inevitable – my partner even bought a ring – but I wasn't ready then, and somehow, the right moment never came again. Sometimes I wonder if I've disappointed my family by not following in their conventional footsteps, but our love story has written its own rules. Society's expectations weigh heavily at times, whispering doubts about the legitimacy of a partnership without marriage certificates and shared last names. Yet, I've learned to navigate these waters with a practiced smile and well-timed jokes, masking the complexity of our chosen path. Behind my carefully curated image of success and contentment lies a deeper truth: that love doesn't always need traditional validation to be real, even if explaining that to others remains a constant challenge.

Paragraph 1:
But the truth is that my circumstances were different from my mother’s and grandmother’s. First, we never got married. We met when I was 19, tending bar at an on-campus performing arts center. I gave him a free drink, and he took out my recycling. He was so handsome that he should have been vain, but he wasn’t, and he liked animals more than people. We merged our lives and moved to a new state. We adopted a hound puppy and named him Mansfield, after the town where we fell in love. Early on, my partner bought a ring and then returned it, correctly assuming that I wasn’t ready for marriage. He didn’t mention this until years later when he had three jalapeño margaritas on vacation and confessed, sputtering, “Did I never tell you that?” By the time I was 30, most of our friends were married, but it had never felt like the right time for us. When people asked him why we hadn’t tied the knot, he would say that he was waiting for me to propose. I’d cite economics and feminism while harboring a feeling I admitted to no one: Things had gotten hard at times, and someday I might need an out. Our life was beautiful but not without its shadows, a fact that I hid behind a veneer of professional success and witty banter.

Paragraph 2:
I met my partner when I was just nineteen, serving drinks at a local bar where life seemed simpler than it is now. Unlike my mother and grandmother, who followed the traditional path of early marriage and settled domesticity, our relationship took a different turn. We fell hard and fast, young and fearless enough to pack our lives into boxes and move to a new state, where we adopted our beloved puppy, Mansfield, who became our first shared responsibility. There was a time when marriage seemed inevitable – my partner even bought a ring – but I wasn't ready then, and somehow, the right moment never came again. Sometimes I wonder if I've disappointed my family by not following in their conventional footsteps, but our love story has written its own rules. Society's expectations weigh heavily at times, whispering doubts about the legitimacy of a partnership without marriage certificates and shared last names. Yet, I've learned to navigate these waters with a practiced smile and well-timed jokes, masking the complexity of our chosen path. Behind my carefully curated image of success and contentment lies a deeper truth: that love doesn't always need traditional validation to be real, even if explaining that to others remains a constant challenge.

paragraph1: Connie Chung's appointment as co-anchor of the "CBS Evening News" alongside Dan Rather represents a landmark achievement in her broadcast journalism career. This role marked a significant milestone, both personally and culturally, as she became one of the few Chinese American women to reach such heights in the industry. The anchor appointment meant even more because she was a Chinese American woman, brought up by strict parents; in accordance with tradition, she lived with them until she was nearly 30, even as she was climbing the ladder — often wearing stiletto heels.

paragraph1: Hong Kong has produced plenty of film stars, but few have left as indelible a mark on the city as Bruce Lee, the martial arts legend. The exhibition also features his 1970s sweaters and the iconic yellow tracksuit from "Game of Death." paragraph1: MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?
paragraph2: As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.

MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?

Paragraph 2:
As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.

paragraph1: 1986 ‘Aliens’ 👽👽 Written and directed by James Cameron, the first sequel to “Alien” is widely held as either the best or the second best movie in the series. But have you watched it recently? Because “Aliens” has aged badly. After 57 years in hypersleep, Ripley grudgingly agrees to help wipe out a nest of beasties threatening a settlement. “Aliens” bears many of the badges of dishonor of formulaic 1980s action: cartoonishly aggro toughies, a little girl in peril (Carrie Henn), a company tool with an upturned collar (Paul Reiser), a bombastically martial score (by James Horner) and, worst of all, an avalanche of hackneyed would-be catchphrases. Best: the confrontation between the alien queen (a major addition to the canon) and Ripley. Worst: almost everything else.
paragraph2: In retrospect, James Cameron's 1986 blockbuster "Aliens" is a film that embodies many of the clichés that defined action movies of the era. Despite its enduring popularity, the movie's tough-talking characters, including a reluctant Ripley, feel like caricatures of '80s excess. The addition of a young girl in peril, played by Carrie Henn, and a soulless corporate villain, played by Paul Reiser, complete with a stereotypical 80s power suit, only add to the film's predictable nature. James Horner's bombastic score doesn't help, often overwhelming the on-screen action. And yet, the iconic confrontation between Ripley and the alien queen remains a masterclass in suspense and tension. Unfortunately, this standout moment is often lost amidst the film's otherwise heavy-handed approach, making "Aliens" feel like a product of its time, rather than a truly timeless classic.

paragraph1: KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.
paragraph2: Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.

Paragraph 1:
KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.

Paragraph 2:
Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.

paragraph1: As I surveyed the bustling scene around the Palazzo del Cinema, I couldn't help but notice the palpable excitement in the air. Groups of young people had set up camp, their eager faces turned towards the red carpet, all hoping to catch a glimpse of a star from Tim Burton's much-anticipated film, "Beetlejuice Beetlejuice," which was set to open the Venice Film Festival. Among the crowd, a teenage boy stood with his parents, his eyes fixed on the entrance. His father broke the anticipation with a question, asking if Jenna Ortega, the popular actress, would be attending. The boy nodded shyly, prompting his parents to exchange knowing smiles, as if silently acknowledging a shared understanding of the boy's admiration for Ortega. It was fascinating to observe how casting stars like Ortega could generate such a fervent interest in films and festivals alike. This stood in stark contrast to the previous year's festival, which had been notably subdued due to an actors' strike that left it devoid of A-list celebrities. The strike had forced organizers to replace a high-profile film with a less glamorous one, and the resulting lack of star power had noticeably dampened the excitement among festival-goers. Today, however, the atmosphere was undeniably electric.
paragraph2: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars. As I surveyed the scene, a teenage boy pulled up on a bicycle, accompanied by his parents. All three craned their necks to check out the still-empty red carpet. “Jenna Ortega is going to be here?” asked his father. The boy nodded shyly and his parents exchanged grins. “That’s his great love, you know,” the father said. Just as casting Ortega, the popular star of “Wednesday,” helped juice interest in Burton’s sequel, so too do glamorous movie stars turbocharge a film festival. Last year, Venice had to make do with precious few A-listers since the actors’ strike barred anyone who had appeared in a big-studio film from doing press for it. That meant the Zendaya tennis romance “Challengers,” planned as the glamorous opening salvo for last year’s festival, was yanked from the lineup and replaced by the Italian war drama “Comandante.” While that movie had its scattered highlights, it didn’t exactly have teenagers lining up for it at 11 in the morning.

paragraph1: Stepping into Baltimore's Paper Moon Diner feels like entering a whimsical time capsule where eclectic decor meets comfort food. The walls, splashed with vibrant hues, serve as a backdrop for an extraordinary collection of vintage treasures, from Radio Flyer wagons to miniature robots and an army of dolls watching diners from every corner. This retro wonderland complements the classic American fare, with apple-smoked bacon sizzling on plates alongside perfectly poached eggs Benedict and fluffy made-to-order omelets, while servers keep the coffee flowing endlessly in true diner tradition.
paragraph2: The Paper Moon Diner, a Baltimore institution near the Baltimore Museum of Art, is decorated floor to ceiling with retro toys. Dolls and Radio Flyer wagons are wedged between ceiling beams, the windows and tables are painted in bright primary colors, and walls are covered with a quirky collection of miniature robots, dart boards and the occasional tree branch. The menu of diner classics hits the mark with apple-smoked bacon, eggs Benedict and made-to-order omelets. Soak in the atmosphere over a bottomless cup of coffee. Breakfast for two, around $30.

paragraph1: The speed with which the shell companies have sprung into action has overwhelmed Western regulators. As soon as one supplier is ferreted out, new ones sprout in its place, sometimes with the same owner. Some of the companies operate in the United States’ backyard, including one Russia-linked firm fronted — apparently unwittingly — by a Latvian-Canadian retiree in a two-story house in a Toronto suburb. A Commerce Department spokeswoman did not directly address how Russia had flouted trade restrictions and said U.S. export controls meant that “Russia is increasingly unable to meet its heightened wartime demand in the face of shrinking supply and is paying more for what it does get.” A Treasury Department spokeswoman said the agency had expanded its efforts to penalize those trading with Russia and supporting its war efforts. Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs didn’t respond to requests for comment. China plays an essential role. As the world’s leading assembler of electronics, it imports huge numbers of Western components and turns them into consumer electronics. Chinese firms can easily channel those supplies to Russia, industry experts said.
paragraph2: Western regulators face significant challenges in tackling the complex web of shell companies that are adept at circumventing trade restrictions to supply Russia. These elusive entities are notorious for their ability to swiftly replace one another when shut down, sometimes even under the same ownership, thus perpetuating their operations. A notable example includes a company linked to Russia, fronted by a Latvian-Canadian retiree residing in a Toronto suburb, possibly unbeknownst to them. The U.S. Commerce and Treasury Departments have been vocal about this issue, with spokeswomen from both agencies commenting on ongoing efforts. The Commerce Department underscores the substantial impact that export controls have had on Russia's capacity to fulfill its wartime needs, whereas the Treasury Department is focused on imposing penalties on those who facilitate Russia's efforts. Meanwhile, Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has remained silent on the matter. The situation is further complicated by China's pivotal role, as Chinese firms have the capability to reroute Western electronic components to Russia, which adds another layer of difficulty for regulators striving to enforce trade restrictions effectively.

paragraph1: Rather than play wait-and-see and have A.I. thrust upon them in ways they couldn’t control, Anthony and Joe Russo, the directors of the previous two “Avengers” movies for Marvel Studios, hired a machine-learning scientist away from Apple to help guide how their production company, AGBO, would use it. “There’s a lot of ways that we are experimenting with A.I. right now,” Anthony Russo told me. “We’re not quite sure what’s going to work and what’s not going to work.” But he is sure that A.I. will figure somehow into how he and his brother make the next two “Avengers” movies, both currently scheduled for 2026, even if it’s only to help with brainstorming ideas and working through them faster. Over several months of talking to people around Hollywood about A.I., I noticed a pattern: The people who knew the least about its potential uses in the filmmaking process feared it the most; and the people who understood it best, who had actually worked with it, harbored the most faith in the resilience of human creativity, as well as the most skepticism about generative A.I.’s ever supplanting it. There was a broad consensus about the urgency of confronting its many potential misuses — tech companies’ skirting copyright laws and scraping proprietary content to train their machine-learning models; actors’ likenesses being appropriated without their permission; studios’ circumventing contractual terms designed to ensure that everything we see onscreen gets written by an actual human being. I must’ve heard the phrase “proper guardrails” at least a dozen times. But as the prolific Emmy-winning television director Paris Barclay, who has six episodes of multiple shows airing this fall alone, put it, “That’s what unions are for.”
paragraph2: In a fascinating development, Anthony and Joe Russo, the visionary directors behind Marvel's blockbuster "Avengers" movies, are ambitiously embracing artificial intelligence (A.I.) within their production company, AGBO. By recruiting a machine-learning scientist from Apple, they are keen to explore how A.I. can revolutionize filmmaking, especially for their upcoming projects. Anthony Russo candidly admitted to me his uncertainty about A.I.'s specific applications but remains optimistic about its significant role in their future films. Observing a broader trend in Hollywood, I noticed a pattern where individuals unfamiliar with A.I. often approach it with trepidation, whereas those well-versed in its capabilities maintain faith in the enduring power of human creativity, expressing skepticism about A.I.'s potential to supplant it. However, this technological exploration is not without its challenges. Concerns have been raised about potential misuses of A.I., such as infringement on copyright and unauthorized exploitation of actors' likenesses. These issues underscore the urgent need for "proper guardrails" to ensure ethical use. Paris Barclay, a prominent television director, highlighted the critical role of unions in navigating these complex challenges. As the industry stands at this technological crossroads, the dialogue surrounding A.I.'s integration in filmmaking emphasizes a balance between innovation and protection of creative rights. The Russo brothers' foray into A.I. represents both a bold step into the future and a testament to their commitment to pushing the boundaries of cinematic storytelling, all while acknowledging the importance of safeguarding the creative integrity that defines Hollywood.

paragraph1: Postcard From the Future Months into dating, my girlfriend and I sat across from another couple and drank margaritas. “If we ever get married,” I said, “we’re going to combine our last names to create a new one: Lavisi.” Our friends laughed at our plan, made so early in our relationship. One of them addressed the free postcard that came with our check to our future selves: “Dani and Jen Lavisi, 123 Lesbian Lane, Lesbos, Greece.” It hung on our fridge for five years — a joke that became a prophecy when that same friend married us and we legally changed our names. — Danielle Lavisi
paragraph2: In the early days of my relationship with Jen, we found ourselves enjoying drinks with another couple. In a playful moment, I suggested that if we ever got married, we should combine our last names to become "Lavisi." Our friends found this amusing and, in good humor, wrote a postcard addressed to "Dani and Jen Lavisi" at a fictional address in Lesbos, Greece. We stuck that postcard on our fridge, where it remained for five years, transforming from a lighthearted joke into a prophetic symbol of our future. Eventually, the same friend who wrote the postcard officiated our wedding, and we legally adopted the combined last name, Lavisi.

paragraph1: As you plan your weekend in São Paulo, consider starting your itinerary on a Friday at 3 p.m. with a visit to the Museu Afro Brasil in Ibirapuera Park. Here, you'll delve into the complex and often fraught history of Brazil's African roots, a legacy that continues to shape the country's identity. In 2021, a significant portion of the population identified as Black or mixed race, yet the nation's relationship with its African heritage remains multifaceted. The museum serves as both a celebration of the contributions of Black and mixed-race Brazilians and a poignant reminder of the country's painful history with slavery. For a mere 15 reais, approximately $3, you can explore exhibits like a restored slave ship and instruments of torture, a somber but essential experience.
paragraph2: On Friday, start your itinerary at 3 p.m. by exploring Brazil’s African roots. Fifty-six percent of Brazilians identified as Black or mixed race in 2021, and race relations here are as complex as they are in the United States, making the Museu Afro Brasil in the city’s glorious Ibirapuera Park a must-see. The museum is at once an exuberant celebration of the contributions that the majority and their ancestors have made to the artistic, intellectual and economic life of the country, and a searing reminder — with the restored remains of a slave ship, instruments of torture and photography of enslaved people — that Brazil was the last country in the Americas to fully abolish slavery, in 1888. Entry is 15 reais, or about $3.

paragraph1: In retrospect, James Cameron's 1986 blockbuster "Aliens" is a film that embodies many of the clichés that defined action movies of the era. Despite its enduring popularity, the movie's tough-talking characters, including a reluctant Ripley, feel like caricatures of '80s excess. The addition of a young girl in peril, played by Carrie Henn, and a soulless corporate villain, played by Paul Reiser, complete with a stereotypical 80s power suit, only add to the film's predictable nature. James Horner's bombastic score doesn't help, often overwhelming the on-screen action. And yet, the iconic confrontation between Ripley and the alien queen remains a masterclass in suspense and tension. Unfortunately, this standout moment is often lost amidst the film's otherwise heavy-handed approach, making "Aliens" feel like a product of its time, rather than a truly timeless classic.
paragraph2: 1986 ‘Aliens’ 👽👽 Written and directed by James Cameron, the first sequel to “Alien” is widely held as either the best or the second best movie in the series. But have you watched it recently? Because “Aliens” has aged badly. After 57 years in hypersleep, Ripley grudgingly agrees to help wipe out a nest of beasties threatening a settlement. “Aliens” bears many of the badges of dishonor of formulaic 1980s action: cartoonishly aggro toughies, a little girl in peril (Carrie Henn), a company tool with an upturned collar (Paul Reiser), a bombastically martial score (by James Horner) and, worst of all, an avalanche of hackneyed would-be catchphrases. Best: the confrontation between the alien queen (a major addition to the canon) and Ripley. Worst: almost everything else.

paragraph1: Headquarters insisted I see him as much as possible, so I volunteered where he volunteered, showed up at events where I knew he would be, scoured the internet for mentions of his name. I was able to work my public relations job for four and a half years and keep up with the delusion. But the delusion gods wanted me to go regularly to the psych ward, where I was loaded up with antipsychotics, zapped with electroconvulsive therapy, and where my diagnosis deteriorated from bipolar I (the manic kind) to schizoaffective disorder (halfway to schizophrenia). I had no choice but to go on disability. My irritation mounted each year. It was like being caught in a whirlpool, the same information going round and round. My beloved seemed clueless. He knew nothing of NASA’s plan to cryogenically freeze our bodies and launch us to a faraway galaxy. Was headquarters simply incompetent? Why was I getting mind-melds to propose if he was just going to turn me down? I needed less noise, more signal. Headquarters was always putting my beloved’s needs first, sending me vexing mind-melds that he needed to move into my house and have his own bedroom suite. How? Who would pay for the renovations? I felt like a querulous housewife. The honeymoon was long over and so were the big Os.
paragraph2: I find myself consumed by an obsession that devours every waking moment, centered on him—my beloved. My thoughts, my actions, my very existence revolve around the magnetic pull he exerts over me. I follow him, finding solace in his proximity, yet my mind spirals further into chaos. The doctors label it schizoaffective disorder, a term that feels like an ill-fitting suit, but necessary for explaining my descent into this fragmented reality. My deteriorating mental state has forced me onto disability, a painful admission of my inability to function in a world that increasingly feels alien. "Headquarters" dictates my actions, a phantom authority whispering bizarre plans involving NASA and mind-melds, leaving me frustrated by its nonsensical commands. I am trapped in a world of delusions that grow more overwhelming by the day. The lack of reciprocation from my beloved cuts deep, as if our connection, which exists solely in my mind, has failed like a crumbling relationship. The unrequited nature of my fixation leaves me hollow, yearning for a reality where my love is returned. I stand on the precipice, teetering between the whispers of "headquarters" and the harsh clarity of my unreturned affection, longing for release from this relentless cycle of obsession and despair.

paragraph1: In a remarkable display of scientific collaboration, researchers from 19 competing drug, biotech, and medical companies gathered at a Phoenix airport hotel to tackle a critical challenge in Alzheimer's research. Their mission was to develop collaborative strategies for testing anti-amyloid drugs as preventive measures in cognitively healthy individuals. Jessica Langbaum, senior director at the Banner institute, emphasized the crucial need for trial participants carrying the APOE4 gene variant, noting that "identifying individuals with this genetic marker is essential for our research, as they face an increased risk of developing Alzheimer's." The meeting's most pressing ethical consideration centered on whether to disclose genetic risk information to study participants. Dr. Robert Klitzman addressed this complex issue, stating, "Researchers face a significant conflict of interest when deciding whether to inform participants about their genetic status, as this knowledge could impact both the study's integrity and the participants' well-being." After careful deliberation, the assembled scientists reached a consensus that transparency should be paramount in their approach. They determined that participants must be fully informed about their genetic status and provided with comprehensive genetic counseling services. This unprecedented gathering demonstrated how competing entities could set aside their differences in pursuit of a greater scientific goal, potentially revolutionizing the approach to Alzheimer's prevention trials while maintaining ethical standards in human subject research.
paragraph2: The same year as the Honolulu conference, researchers from 19 drug, biotech and medical companies came together at a Phoenix airport hotel for a highly unusual meeting. Though fierce competitors, the scientists wanted to collaborate on strategies for Alzheimer’s research — specifically whether anti-amyloid drugs could prevent Alzheimer’s in people who were still cognitively normal, before the onset of decline. “You really needed people who might progress to cognitive impairment or start to develop symptoms of the disease in a relatively short period of time,” recalled Jessica Langbaum, a senior director at the Banner institute, which hosted the meeting. In other words, they needed trial subjects with a gene variant called APOE4 — people with a high genetic probability of developing Alzheimer’s. People with two copies of the gene variant constitute an estimated 2 to 3 percent of the general population and 15 to 20 percent of people with Alzheimer’s. Those with only one copy make up about half of Alzheimer’s patients. One question in Phoenix was how, or even if, these trial subjects should be told their grim genetic profiles, according to a written, contemporaneous account of the meeting. “Researchers unfortunately have an inherent conflict of interest,” said Dr. Robert Klitzman, director of the Masters of Bioethics Program at Columbia University. “They want people to be in their study, and there are researchers who feel, if I tell people the full facts and risks, they may not want to be in the study.” A general agreement emerged from the meeting around the importance of transparency; participants would be informed. To cope with this news, they would first undergo genetic counseling.

paragraph1: The squirrel's beady eyes bore into me as I sit here under the maple tree, my phone clutched in my hand like some kind of lifeline. Three hours, seventeen minutes, and still no text back. Mom says I'm too good for someone who can't even bother to cancel properly, and Sarah keeps insisting I need to "know my worth," but right now, all I know is this hollow feeling in my chest. It's funny how a simple unanswered message can make you question everything about yourself. The squirrel tilts its head, probably wondering why I'm still here, and honestly, I'm wondering the same thing.
paragraph2:
Under the Tree
This squirrel stared at me, wondering why I was sitting under its tree. I always come to this tree when I feel out of sorts. I was supposed to have a date that day but never got a text back. Friends say it has nothing to do with me. Mom says, “You need higher self-esteem.” I love myself, but I’m slowly unraveling, trying to see myself the way I know I should. Under the tree with the squirrel staring at me, I thought, “It’s nice to have other living things acknowledge me.” — Mia Mitchell

paragraph1: The Paper Moon Diner, a Baltimore institution near the Baltimore Museum of Art, is decorated floor to ceiling with retro toys. Dolls and Radio Flyer wagons are wedged between ceiling beams, the windows and tables are painted in bright primary colors, and walls are covered with a quirky collection of miniature robots, dart boards and the occasional tree branch. The menu of diner classics hits the mark with apple-smoked bacon, eggs Benedict and made-to-order omelets. Soak in the atmosphere over a bottomless cup of coffee. Breakfast for two, around $30.
paragraph2: Stepping into Baltimore's Paper Moon Diner feels like entering a whimsical time capsule where eclectic decor meets comfort food. The walls, splashed with vibrant hues, serve as a backdrop for an extraordinary collection of vintage treasures, from Radio Flyer wagons to miniature robots and an army of dolls watching diners from every corner. This retro wonderland complements the classic American fare, with apple-smoked bacon sizzling on plates alongside perfectly poached eggs Benedict and fluffy made-to-order omelets, while servers keep the coffee flowing endlessly in true diner tradition.

paragraph1: 8) 2:30 p.m. Après ski ritual With Japan’s volcanic landscape, there are ample onsens (geothermal hot springs) in Niseko; taking to the waters at a public bathhouse is both an essential ritual of Japanese culture and part of the ski experience. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, in a ryokan (traditional Japanese inn) in Annupuri. Know the Japanese etiquette, such as bringing your own little “modesty towel” and soap to cleanse thoroughly before dipping, naked (no bathing suits allowed), into a communal outdoor pool. Like most onsen, this one is separated by gender. The outdoor pool, under a wood pergola and surrounded by snow and boulders, features mineral water pumped from the base of Mount Annupuri. It may be cold outside, but you’re relaxing your body and soul in about 130 degree Fahrenheit, mineral-rich bubbling water. Folding and placing the towel on your head is a custom. Cost: 1,000 yen.
paragraph2: As you carve through the powdery slopes of Niseko, Japan, you'll want to cap off your day with a quintessential après-ski ritual: a soak in a geothermal hot spring, or onsen. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, a public bathhouse nestled within a ryokan in Annupuri, where you can unwind in a serene outdoor setting. But first, be sure to follow Japanese etiquette by bringing a modesty towel and soap, and cleansing thoroughly before entering the communal pool. Note that bathing suits are not allowed, and the onsen is gender-separated. As you settle into the 130-degree Fahrenheit mineral water, sourced from Mount Annupuri, you'll feel your muscles relax beneath the wooden pergola, surrounded by snow-covered boulders. For a mere 1,000 yen, you can indulge in this rejuvenating experience, a perfect way to round out a day on the slopes. So come and immerse yourself in this tranquil Japanese tradition.

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.

Paragraph 1:
8) 2:30 p.m. Après ski ritual With Japan’s volcanic landscape, there are ample onsens (geothermal hot springs) in Niseko; taking to the waters at a public bathhouse is both an essential ritual of Japanese culture and part of the ski experience. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, in a ryokan (traditional Japanese inn) in Annupuri. Know the Japanese etiquette, such as bringing your own little “modesty towel” and soap to cleanse thoroughly before dipping, naked (no bathing suits allowed), into a communal outdoor pool. Like most onsen, this one is separated by gender. The outdoor pool, under a wood pergola and surrounded by snow and boulders, features mineral water pumped from the base of Mount Annupuri. It may be cold outside, but you’re relaxing your body and soul in about 130 degree Fahrenheit, mineral-rich bubbling water. Folding and placing the towel on your head is a custom. Cost: 1,000 yen.

Paragraph 2:
As you carve through the powdery slopes of Niseko, Japan, you'll want to cap off your day with a quintessential après-ski ritual: a soak in a geothermal hot spring, or onsen. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, a public bathhouse nestled within a ryokan in Annupuri, where you can unwind in a serene outdoor setting. But first, be sure to follow Japanese etiquette by bringing a modesty towel and soap, and cleansing thoroughly before entering the communal pool. Note that bathing suits are not allowed, and the onsen is gender-separated. As you settle into the 130-degree Fahrenheit mineral water, sourced from Mount Annupuri, you'll feel your muscles relax beneath the wooden pergola, surrounded by snow-covered boulders. For a mere 1,000 yen, you can indulge in this rejuvenating experience, a perfect way to round out a day on the slopes. So come and immerse yourself in this tranquil Japanese tradition.

paragraph1: Authorities face significant challenges due to Telegram's distinct features and its lack of cooperation with law enforcement, which complicates their ability to investigate crimes. Telegram's steadfast refusal to share user data has been a major hindrance to criminal investigations, causing considerable frustration among law enforcement agencies. While the company has the capability to access messages unless users engage in secret chats that employ end-to-end encryption, it has consistently denied that its employees have access to any user data. This stance has led to serious legal repercussions, as evidenced by France charging Telegram's founder, Mr. Pavel Durov, with complicity in crimes, including trafficking child sexual imagery, due to the company's insufficient response to law enforcement's requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor in Germany, underscores that Telegram's lack of cooperation starkly contrasts with other social media platforms that work collaboratively with law enforcement. Despite these challenges, Telegram asserts that it is striving to strike a delicate balance between respecting legitimate requests from democratic nations and protecting the rights and privacy of its users.
paragraph2: Telegram’s features — coupled with its refusal to cooperate with the police — have stymied criminal investigations, increasingly frustrating the authorities. The company can gain access to messages unless users select a secret chat option with end-to-end encryption, according to two former employees. On at least two occasions, the company has retrieved the messages of former employees, one person said. But the company, which denied that employees had access to user data, has refused to share information with governments. France charged Mr. Durov with complicity in trafficking child sexual imagery, among other crimes, because of what the chief prosecutor called “an almost total lack of response” to requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor focused on illegal hate speech in Germany, said other major social media platforms had developed practices for working with law enforcement. But “we don’t get any cooperation from Telegram at all,” she said, adding, “I can’t recall one case.” Telegram said it was “now working hard to make sure we can process legitimate requests from democratic countries while still defending the rights of our users elsewhere.”

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Authorities face significant challenges due to Telegram's distinct features and its lack of cooperation with law enforcement, which complicates their ability to investigate crimes. Telegram's steadfast refusal to share user data has been a major hindrance to criminal investigations, causing considerable frustration among law enforcement agencies. While the company has the capability to access messages unless users engage in secret chats that employ end-to-end encryption, it has consistently denied that its employees have access to any user data. This stance has led to serious legal repercussions, as evidenced by France charging Telegram's founder, Mr. Pavel Durov, with complicity in crimes, including trafficking child sexual imagery, due to the company's insufficient response to law enforcement's requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor in Germany, underscores that Telegram's lack of cooperation starkly contrasts with other social media platforms that work collaboratively with law enforcement. Despite these challenges, Telegram asserts that it is striving to strike a delicate balance between respecting legitimate requests from democratic nations and protecting the rights and privacy of its users.

Paragraph 2:
Telegram’s features — coupled with its refusal to cooperate with the police — have stymied criminal investigations, increasingly frustrating the authorities. The company can gain access to messages unless users select a secret chat option with end-to-end encryption, according to two former employees. On at least two occasions, the company has retrieved the messages of former employees, one person said. But the company, which denied that employees had access to user data, has refused to share information with governments. France charged Mr. Durov with complicity in trafficking child sexual imagery, among other crimes, because of what the chief prosecutor called “an almost total lack of response” to requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor focused on illegal hate speech in Germany, said other major social media platforms had developed practices for working with law enforcement. But “we don’t get any cooperation from Telegram at all,” she said, adding, “I can’t recall one case.” Telegram said it was “now working hard to make sure we can process legitimate requests from democratic countries while still defending the rights of our users elsewhere.”

paragraph1: As schools continue to invest heavily in technology, artificial intelligence companies are aggressively marketing their products to educators, touting promises of enhanced student learning and streamlined administrative tasks. However, experts warn that the rush to adopt A.I. in educational settings poses significant risks, particularly when it comes to the use of taxpayer dollars. Concerns about student data privacy, the accuracy of A.I.-driven assessments, and the potential conflict with efforts to reduce children's screen time have raised red flags among educators and researchers. "Schools need to be cautious and critically assess the capabilities and limitations of A.I. before making significant investments," advises Natalie Milman, a professor of educational technology at George Washington University. Despite these concerns, companies like AllHere, which has developed an A.I.-powered attendance tracking system, are making inroads in schools across the country. Notably, AllHere did not respond to requests for interviews or written questions, fueling further skepticism about the transparency and accountability of A.I. companies operating in the education sector.
paragraph2: A.I. companies are heavily marketing themselves to schools, which spend tens of billions of dollars annually on technology. But AllHere’s sudden breakdown illustrates some of the risks of investing taxpayer dollars in artificial intelligence, a technology with enormous potential but little track record, especially when it comes to children. There are many complicated issues at play, including privacy of student data and the accuracy of any information offered via chatbots. And A.I. may also run counter to another growing interest for education leaders and parents — reducing children’s screen time. Natalie Milman, professor of educational technology at George Washington University, said she often advises schools to take a “wait and see” approach to purchasing new technology. While A.I. is worthy of use and testing, she said, she warned about schools “talking nebulously about this glorified tool. It has limitations, and we need to ensure we are being critical of what it can do, and its potential for harm and misinformation.” AllHere did not respond to interview requests or written questions.

"Schools need to be cautious and critically assess the capabilities and limitations of A.I. before making significant investments," advises Natalie Milman, a professor of educational technology at George Washington University. Despite these concerns, companies like AllHere, which has developed an A.I.-powered attendance tracking system, are making inroads in schools across the country. paragraph1: Toni Braxton, the Grammy-winning R&B singer and actress, has always been protective of her personal space. "I'm old school, I'm aloof," she admits, reflecting on her initial reluctance to reboot the reality show "Braxton Family Values," which she starred in alongside her sisters Traci, Towanda, Trina, and Tamar. However, after Traci's passing from esophageal cancer in 2022, Toni decided to participate in the new series, "The Braxtons," as a tribute to her sister's memory. "She wanted us to keep going, to keep the show alive," Toni explains. The new series, which premiered on We TV and ALLBLK, takes a more somber tone, exploring themes of grief and healing as the family navigates life without Traci. "It's different without her, it's just not the same," Toni notes, her voice tinged with sadness. Despite her reservations, Toni has continued to thrive in her career, with recent stints on Broadway and a Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer. As she looks to the future, Toni is determined to keep her sister's memory alive, both on and off screen. "I'm doing this for Traci," she says, her voice filled with conviction.
paragraph2: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. “Not that I don’t love hanging out with my sisters — I’m just not comfortable with people being in my space like that,” she said. “I’m old school. I’m a bit aloof.” She ultimately did it for Traci, who died of esophageal cancer in 2022 and who had been adamant that her sisters continue with the show. Grief and healing are the main themes in the all-new series “The Braxtons,” which airs on We TV and is available on the streaming service ALLBLK. It isn’t the same without Traci, Toni Braxton said. “Part of our DNA is missing. Everyone is trying figure out how to live in this heartache.” Besides “Braxton Family Values,” Braxton is known for her roles on Broadway (“Beauty and the Beast,” “Aida,” “After Midnight”) and for her many R&B hits, including “Breathe Again,” “Another Sad Love Song” and “Un-Break My Heart” — which she performs in “Love & Laughter,” her joint Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer.

paragraph1: Concerns are mounting over Project 2025, which aims to dismantle a climate agency, potentially jeopardizing critical climate data. Gretchen Gehrke, cofounder of the Environmental Data and Governance Initiative, voices apprehension about the threat this poses to the integrity and accessibility of environmental information. The project echoes former President Donald Trump's skepticism towards climate change, as he notoriously dismissed it as a hoax and sought to dismantle climate regulations during his tenure. When Trump assumed office, his administration was initially unaware of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). In a controversial move, he nominated Barry Lee Myers, former CEO of AccuWeather, to lead NOAA, despite Myers' history of advocating for the privatization of the Weather Service. However, Myers' nomination was eventually withdrawn due to health issues. The Heritage Foundation, which has ties to Project 2025, refused to comment on its objectives. Although Trump disavowed the project during his campaign, his transition team spokeswoman, Karoline Leavitt, clarified that no policy should be considered official unless it is directly endorsed by Trump himself, leaving the future of climate data uncertain.
paragraph2: “Climate data is absolutely at risk with Project 2025’s call to dissolve the agency,” said Gretchen Gehrke, cofounder of the Environmental Data and Governance Initiative, a small group formed in 2016 to back up climate information. Trump has called climate change a hoax and said he would rollback climate regulations, and, according to Lewis’s book, officials in the Trump White House did not know that NOAA existed or what it did when Trump took office in 2017. In 2017, Trump nominated Barry Lee Myers, then the chief executive of the for-profit weather company AccuWeather, to run NOAA even though Myers had spent decades pushing to privatize the Weather Service. After his appointment stalled in the Senate for two years, Myers withdrew his nomination, citing medical issues. The Heritage Foundation said in an email that it would not comment on questions about Project 2025 and climate data. Trump, for his part, disavowed Project 2025 during his campaign, and his transition team spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt said in an email that “no policy should be deemed official unless it comes directly from President Trump.”

paragraph1: Reddit's journey through the digital landscape is marked by both triumph and adversity. Alfred Lin, a partner at Sequoia Capital, recognizes Reddit's distinctive position as a digital hub, fostering a unique online community. In 2006, Condé Nast acquired Reddit for $10 million, catapulting its founders, Steve Huffman and Alexis Ohanian, into early millionaire status. Following their departure, a small, dedicated team of "Redditors" took the helm, staunchly resisting changes to the platform's appearance and functionality to preserve the experience for its core users. Their reluctance to innovate led to a delayed development of a mobile app and a general disinterest in monetizing the site. This laid-back approach to moderation also resulted in the proliferation of toxic subreddits, which posed significant challenges for advertisers wary of associating with controversial content. Furthermore, many within Reddit's ranks were opposed to data collection and invasive advertising methods, creating internal friction regarding the platform's growth strategies. Despite these challenges, Reddit remains a unique entity on the internet, continually navigating the delicate balance between community engagement and commercial viability.
paragraph2: “Reddit is one of those rare places on the internet where you find niche interests, and broad interests, all in the same place,” said Alfred Lin, a partner at Sequoia Capital, a venture capital firm that has invested in the company. In 2006, Condé Nast bought Reddit for $10 million, turning Mr. Huffman and Mr. Ohanian into young millionaires overnight. Both founders eventually departed, leaving Reddit in the hands of a small team of hardcore “Redditors” who were very protective of the site. That team was adamantly against evolving how Reddit looked and worked, out of fear it would alienate its core users. They resisted building a mobile application well into the rise of the iPhone era, and were largely disinterested and did not have the bandwidth to turn Reddit into a moneymaking business. Employees also had a laissez-faire attitude to moderating speech on the site, which sometimes landed the company in hot water. Some subreddits were toxic and devoted to racist themes or nonconsensual nude photos, the type of content that advertisers found repellent. Many employees were against data collection and more invasive forms of advertising.

Their reluctance to innovate led to a delayed development of a mobile app and a general disinterest in monetizing the site. This laid-back approach to moderation also resulted in the proliferation of toxic subreddits, which posed significant challenges for advertisers wary of associating with controversial content. Furthermore, many within Reddit's ranks were opposed to data collection and invasive advertising methods, creating internal friction regarding the platform's growth strategies. Despite these challenges, Reddit remains a unique entity on the internet, continually navigating the delicate balance between community engagement and commercial viability.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Ms. Reeves demonstrated a measured approach to fiscal policy while facing mounting pressure to boost Britain's public service funding. Her announcement outlined increased funding allocations over the coming years, with specific focus on teachers, defense, and local authorities, though she maintained strict control by capping day-to-day departmental spending growth at 1.3 percent annually from 2026, accounting for inflation. The Institute for Fiscal Studies' analysis suggested this conservative approach would create challenging financial constraints for certain departments. A notable aspect of her strategy included a substantial £100 billion increase in public investment over five years, targeting critical infrastructure such as school buildings and hospitals. The Office for Budget Responsibility's assessment indicated that while these measures would provide temporary economic support, they would not substantially alter the economy's size within five years, as growth was projected to decelerate below 2 percent annually. Nevertheless, they acknowledged that the increased public investment could potentially enhance the economy's capacity for long-term growth.
paragraph2: Still, Ms. Reeves showed some restraint in the face of pressure to inject a lot more cash into Britain’s struggling public services. She announced more money in the next few years, especially for teachers, defense and local authorities. But starting in 2026, day-to-day spending for government departments would grow on average 1.3 percent annually, after accounting for inflation, which analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies said would still leave some departments with very tight budgets. At the same time, Ms. Reeves also set to increase public investment. She said that over the next five years, the government would increase capital spending by £100 billion to invest in projects, such as school buildings, hospital beds and diagnostics centers. In all, Ms. Reeves’s measures will temporarily aid the economy but leave its size “largely unchanged” in five years, the Office for Budget Responsibility said. It forecast slightly higher growth for this year and next, but said growth would then slow to below 2 percent a year. However, a sustained increase in public investment would raise the supply potential of the economy, which could increase long-term growth, the budget responsibility office said.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies' analysis suggested this conservative approach would create challenging financial constraints for certain departments. A notable aspect of her strategy included a substantial £100 billion increase in public investment over five years, targeting critical infrastructure such as school buildings and hospitals. The Office for Budget Responsibility's assessment indicated that while these measures would provide temporary economic support, they would not substantially alter the economy's size within five years, as growth was projected to decelerate below 2 percent annually. Nevertheless, they acknowledged that the increased public investment could potentially enhance the economy's capacity for long-term growth.

Paragraph 2:
Still, Ms. Reeves showed some restraint in the face of pressure to inject a lot more cash into Britain’s struggling public services. She announced more money in the next few years, especially for teachers, defense and local authorities. But starting in 2026, day-to-day spending for government departments would grow on average 1.3 percent annually, after accounting for inflation, which analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies said would still leave some departments with very tight budgets. At the same time, Ms. Reeves also set to increase public investment. She said that over the next five years, the government would increase capital spending by £100 billion to invest in projects, such as school buildings, hospital beds and diagnostics centers. However, a sustained increase in public investment would raise the supply potential of the economy, which could increase long-term growth, the budget responsibility office said.

paragraph1: Virginia Foxx, the Republican committee chair from West Virginia, has taken a firm stance on the state of American higher education through her recent op-ed in The Washington Examiner. In her pointed message to universities across the nation, Foxx issued a stark warning about the need to address what she perceives as critical issues in academic institutions. Her primary concerns centered on the lack of ideological diversity and limitations on free expression within university campuses. Foxx's message carried particular weight as she suggested that failure to address these concerns could result in government intervention. Her position as a committee chair lends significant authority to these warnings, potentially signaling increased scrutiny of higher education institutions' policies and practices regarding intellectual diversity and freedom of expression.
paragraph2: The warning was not new. About two and half months earlier, the committee’s chair, Virginia Foxx, Republican of West Virginia, had suggested that America’s universities fix themselves — or else. “Have institutions, including the university system,” she wrote in an op-ed in The Washington Examiner, “been so thoroughly captured by anti-American and illiberal ideology that the government must step in to restore viewpoint diversity, free thought and free expression?” Thank you for your patience while we verify access. paragraph1: Daryl Dixon, portrayed by Norman Reedus, has undergone a remarkable transformation from a minor character in "The Walking Dead" to the central figure of a successful spinoff series. Set against the backdrop of France, this new series showcases Daryl's journey in a foreign land, providing a fresh perspective distinct from the original series that unfolded in Georgia. Reedus, deeply involved in the creative process, emphasizes how the incorporation of French elements and local writers has enriched the narrative, allowing for a unique storytelling experience that stands apart from its predecessor. The series' success is evident, with a second season already premiering and plans for future projects in Spain, further expanding its global footprint. Beyond his role as Daryl, Reedus is a man of many talents, engaging in film and photography, showcasing his versatility and passion for the arts. In his personal life, Reedus finds inspiration and influence from his young daughter, who has notably shaped his reading habits, offering a glimpse into the softer side of the actor whose on-screen persona is often seen navigating the harsh realities of a post-apocalyptic world.
paragraph2: When Daryl Dixon was introduced in the third episode of “The Walking Dead” in 2010, few viewers could have predicted this half-feral-looking character would end up leading the series. Or that Daryl, played by Norman Reedus, would headline a spinoff set in France. “We wanted to reinvent the show,” Reedus, 55, said in a video interview from Paris. “We just didn’t want to do the same storytelling as in Georgia,” he continued, referring to the location for most of the original series, “and we didn’t want to make an American tourist version of France. So we got French writers. We fought to have French as much as English.” Season 2 of “The Walking Dead: Daryl Dixon” premieres Sept. 29 on AMC, but the new franchise is so successful that Reedus (who also appeared this year in the film “The Bikeriders” and has a second career as a photographer) is already working on the next installment in Spain. He talked about his connection with rock, art and food, as well as his 5-year-old daughter’s influence on his reading. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.

paragraph1: The Whirlpool Jet Boat Tour facility in Niagara-on-the-Lake has temporarily suspended operations for the summer season due to elevated water levels impacting the dock infrastructure. While this location remains closed, adventure seekers are being directed to the company's alternative outlet in Niagara Falls, where they can still experience the exhilarating journey through the lower Niagara River's powerful rapids. The tour features specially designed vessels that navigate through the churning waters, offering visitors an unforgettable combination of scenic views and heart-pounding excitement. Adult tickets are available for purchase, while children meeting the minimum height requirement can participate at a reduced rate. Management anticipates reopening the Niagara-on-the-Lake facility next year once water levels return to normal, allowing them to resume operations at both locations.

Don’t miss the chance to ride on their custom-built vessels that navigate the strong rapids on the lower Niagara River, a seven-mile gorge carved out by the strong currents in the Niagara River. With hundreds of thousands of gallons of water flowing over the falls every minute, it is a journey like no other. Get wet on this wild ride to acclimate back to reality after the quiet of Niagara-on-the-Lake. Cost: 69.95 dollars for an adult and 44.95 dollars for children, who must be at least 40 inches tall.

paragraph1: As you plan your weekend in São Paulo, consider starting your itinerary on a Friday at 3 p.m. with a visit to the Museu Afro Brasil in Ibirapuera Park. Here, you'll delve into the complex and often fraught history of Brazil's African roots, a legacy that continues to shape the country's identity. In 2021, a significant portion of the population identified as Black or mixed race, yet the nation's relationship with its African heritage remains multifaceted. The museum serves as both a celebration of the contributions of Black and mixed-race Brazilians and a poignant reminder of the country's painful history with slavery. For a mere 15 reais, approximately $3, you can explore exhibits like a restored slave ship and instruments of torture, a somber but essential experience.
paragraph2: On Friday, start your itinerary at 3 p.m. by exploring Brazil’s African roots. Fifty-six percent of Brazilians identified as Black or mixed race in 2021, and race relations here are as complex as they are in the United States, making the Museu Afro Brasil in the city’s glorious Ibirapuera Park a must-see. The museum is at once an exuberant celebration of the contributions that the majority and their ancestors have made to the artistic, intellectual and economic life of the country, and a searing reminder — with the restored remains of a slave ship, instruments of torture and photography of enslaved people — that Brazil was the last country in the Americas to fully abolish slavery, in 1888. Entry is 15 reais, or about $3.

paragraph1: “It’s a sacrifice,” Mr. Lopez, who moved to the New Orleans area from Honduras, said in Spanish. He drove to Florida three days after Helene hit the state late last month. “But it’s worth it. We know that we’re going to get a lot of work and bring income to our families. And the biggest satisfaction is that we can help a city rebuild.” Mr. Lopez said he planned to ride out Hurricane Milton in Florida and would very likely remain there to assist in the recovery. The storm roared back to Category 5 strength on Tuesday afternoon, and the Tampa Bay region was bracing for what could be its first direct hit from a major storm since the 1920s. “If Milton stays on course and hits Tampa, that’s where everybody will go,” said Saket Soni, the founder and executive director of Resilience Force, a nonprofit that organizes disaster recovery workers and offers them safety training. “It’s just an enormously dense area that hasn’t faced a storm in a century. That’s where much of the rebuilding efforts will focus.”
paragraph2: As Hurricane Milton bears down on the Tampa Bay area, threatening to make landfall as a Category 5 storm, Mr. Lopez stands ready to lend a hand. The Honduras native, who now calls the New Orleans area home, traveled to Florida in the aftermath of Hurricane Helene, drawn by the promise of work and the opportunity to support his family while contributing to the city's recovery efforts. With Milton poised to deliver the region's first major direct hit in nearly a century, Mr. Lopez has no intention of leaving. Instead, he plans to stay and assist with the storm's aftermath, joining a growing army of disaster recovery workers organized and trained by Resilience Force, a nonprofit founded by Saket Soni. As the storm intensifies, Mr. Soni's organization is working tirelessly to prepare its workforce for the anticipated rebuilding efforts in the densely populated region, where the need for skilled and dedicated workers like Mr. Lopez will be greater than ever.

paragraph1: In the unsettling found footage horror film "Life of Belle," now streaming on Tubi, a family's security monitors capture the disturbing descent of a mother into erratic behavior. As she systematically removes food from the house, convinced it's poisoned, a sense of unease settles over the viewer. The ominous decision to leave the knives behind is a harbinger of the danger that's to come. Unlike its supernatural predecessors "Paranormal Activity" and "He's Watching," "Life of Belle" grounds its horror in the all-too-real issue of untreated mental illness. Director Shawn Robinson's decision to cast his own family members pays off, as they deliver naturalistic performances that add to the film's sense of unease. With its low-budget aesthetic and unflinching portrayal of a family in crisis, "Life of Belle" is a chilling reminder that sometimes the most terrifying monsters are the ones that lurk within.
paragraph2: ‘Life of Belle’ Stream it on Tubi. Security monitors also capture the mom’s increasingly erratic behavior, like when she empties the house of food, convinced it’s poison. What mom doesn’t remove are the knives — the first clue that the home will soon become a house of horrors. This feature debut from the writer-director Shawn Robinson looks a lot like other low-budget found footage horror films. Like “Paranormal Activity,” it’s set inside a house. Like “He’s Watching,” its leads are a brave young brother and sister. But in those films, otherworldly forces invade domestic space. Here, Robinson takes a disturbingly different path, using a parent’s real, untreated mental illness as the antagonistic force, forgoing metaphor. Far from being exploitative, the film extends compassion toward the suffering of both parent and child. The Robinson family is related in real life — and their performances are scary movie naturalism at its best.

paragraph1: Aldis Hodge — who is a producer of “Cross” — signed up for the show soon after reading Watkins’s script. He then threw himself into helping refine it. “From the beginning, Ben and I talked about where we were at as men in our lives, what we wanted for ourselves,” Hodge said. “That’s what fed the trajectory of how I portrayed Alex Cross.” Integral to the character’s psyche is the death of his wife, who is killed at the start of the first episode. Cross, who is described as having a hero complex that gives him a “compulsion to protect,” is burdened not only by loss but also by guilt at the thought that he failed her. “I want to create a character who is dealing with grief and making choices that are having a negative impact on the people around them,” Watkins said. “It’s an iconic detective, but your journey as a character is really going to be about you confronting your own emotional burdens and figuring out a way through them.”
paragraph2: For Aldis Hodge, the allure of "Cross" began with a single script, penned by Watkins, that would eventually draw him in as both a producer and actor on the show. "After reading the pilot, I knew I wanted to be a part of this story," Hodge recalled, noting that he was particularly drawn to the complexity of the titular character, Alex Cross. As Hodge delved deeper into the project, he found himself refining the script alongside Watkins, with the two engaging in candid conversations about their personal experiences and aspirations as men. These discussions would ultimately inform Hodge's portrayal of Cross, a character grappling with the devastating loss of his wife at the series' outset. "I wanted to explore the hero complex, the guilt, the grief - all the things that make us human," Watkins explained, his words echoing the show's thoughtful examination of Cross's emotional burdens. As the series navigates the dark aftermath of tragedy, Hodge and Watkins aim to craft a nuanced, deeply human character in Alex Cross, one whose journey towards healing is both deeply personal and universally relatable.

paragraph1: Authorities face significant challenges due to Telegram's distinct features and its lack of cooperation with law enforcement, which complicates their ability to investigate crimes. Telegram's steadfast refusal to share user data has been a major hindrance to criminal investigations, causing considerable frustration among law enforcement agencies. While the company has the capability to access messages unless users engage in secret chats that employ end-to-end encryption, it has consistently denied that its employees have access to any user data. This stance has led to serious legal repercussions, as evidenced by France charging Telegram's founder, Mr. Pavel Durov, with complicity in crimes, including trafficking child sexual imagery, due to the company's insufficient response to law enforcement's requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor in Germany, underscores that Telegram's lack of cooperation starkly contrasts with other social media platforms that work collaboratively with law enforcement. Despite these challenges, Telegram asserts that it is striving to strike a delicate balance between respecting legitimate requests from democratic nations and protecting the rights and privacy of its users.
paragraph2: Telegram’s features — coupled with its refusal to cooperate with the police — have stymied criminal investigations, increasingly frustrating the authorities. The company can gain access to messages unless users select a secret chat option with end-to-end encryption, according to two former employees. On at least two occasions, the company has retrieved the messages of former employees, one person said. But the company, which denied that employees had access to user data, has refused to share information with governments. France charged Mr. Durov with complicity in trafficking child sexual imagery, among other crimes, because of what the chief prosecutor called “an almost total lack of response” to requests for assistance. Svenja Meininghaus, a state prosecutor focused on illegal hate speech in Germany, said other major social media platforms had developed practices for working with law enforcement. But “we don’t get any cooperation from Telegram at all,” she said, adding, “I can’t recall one case.” Telegram said it was “now working hard to make sure we can process legitimate requests from democratic countries while still defending the rights of our users elsewhere.”
