paragraph1: But the biggest disappointment with the Vision Pro is how few good apps there are. Several months after its debut, there’s still no native YouTube or Netflix app. There’s no Spotify, no Instagram, no DoorDash. (You can still use some of these services in a web browser, or use unofficial third-party apps, but it’s a worse experience.) Some of these apps are missing because of corporate infighting. (Google and Meta, for example, have their own virtual reality ambitions and presumably don’t want to give Apple’s product a boost by making apps for it.) But others amount to a lack of confidence. Developers don’t want to make apps for platforms that nobody uses, and their reluctance so far — only about 2,000 apps have been developed for the Vision Pro, Apple said on Monday — says something about the device’s tepid reception. Apple has also been slow to update its own offerings for the Vision Pro, like a series of “immersive videos,” filmed on special 3-D cameras and released through Apple TV. These videos — which included a prehistoric nature film and a “rehearsal room” video of Alicia Keys and her band as they perform a song — were designed to show off the Vision Pro’s high-definition graphics and its “spatial audio” feature, and they are among the best things you can do with a Vision Pro.
paragraph2: Despite being launched several months ago, Apple's Vision Pro faces significant challenges due to the scarcity of quality apps available for the device. Major apps like YouTube, Netflix, Spotify, Instagram, and DoorDash are noticeably absent, largely due to corporate competition and a lack of developer confidence. Companies such as Google and Meta, who have their own virtual reality ambitions, show hesitation in supporting Apple's product, fearing it may bolster a competitor in a rapidly evolving market. Developers are equally cautious, reluctant to invest time and resources into creating apps for a platform that has yet to see substantial user adoption, as evidenced by the meager 2,000 apps developed so far. Compounding the issue, Apple has been slow to expand its own content offerings for the Vision Pro. The company has released a few immersive videos through Apple TV, including a prehistoric nature film and a rehearsal video of Alicia Keys and her band, designed to showcase the device's impressive high-definition graphics and spatial audio capabilities. While these videos represent some of the best experiences currently available on the Vision Pro, they are insufficient to compensate for the lack of third-party app support. The combination of these factors presents a considerable hurdle for Apple as it seeks to establish the Vision Pro as a dominant force in the virtual reality market.

paragraph1: A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible. CrowdStrike sent a faulty security update to its customers Thursday night, resulting in millions of Microsoft Windows devices shutting down and disruptions to airlines, hospitals, logistics companies and others. Americans “deserve to know in detail how this incident happened and the mitigation steps CrowdStrike is taking,” wrote Representative Mark Green of Tennessee, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, and Representative Andrew Garbarino, Republican of New York. The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”
paragraph2: A Congressional committee is set to scrutinize CrowdStrike, a prominent cybersecurity company, over a sweeping tech outage that crippled millions of Microsoft Windows devices and sent shockwaves across various industries, including airlines, hospitals, and logistics companies. At the center of the controversy is a faulty security update issued by CrowdStrike, which triggered the widespread disruptions. George Kurtz, the company's chief executive, has been summoned to testify at a hearing to account for the company's role in the debacle. Representatives Mark Green of Tennessee and Andrew Garbarino of New York, both Republicans, are spearheading the effort to hold CrowdStrike accountable, having dispatched a letter to Kurtz requesting his prompt response to schedule the hearing. A CrowdStrike spokeswoman confirmed that the company is in communication with the relevant congressional committees, but declined to provide further details, stating that any updates on briefings would be shared at the discretion of the committee members.
text_input:

Paragraph 1:
A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible. CrowdStrike sent a faulty security update to its customers Thursday night, resulting in millions of Microsoft Windows devices shutting down and disruptions to airlines, hospitals, logistics companies and others. Americans “deserve to know in detail how this incident happened and the mitigation steps CrowdStrike is taking,” wrote Representative Mark Green of Tennessee, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, and Representative Andrew Garbarino, Republican of New York. The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”

Paragraph 2:
A Congressional committee is set to scrutinize CrowdStrike, a prominent cybersecurity company, over a sweeping tech outage that crippled millions of Microsoft Windows devices and sent shockwaves across various industries, including airlines, hospitals, and logistics companies. At the center of the controversy is a faulty security update issued by CrowdStrike, which triggered the widespread disruptions. George Kurtz, the company's chief executive, has been summoned to testify at a hearing to account for the company's role in the debacle. Representatives Mark Green of Tennessee and Andrew Garbarino of New York, both Republicans, are spearheading the effort to hold CrowdStrike accountable, having dispatched a letter to Kurtz requesting his prompt response to schedule the hearing. A CrowdStrike spokeswoman confirmed that the company is in communication with the relevant congressional committees, but declined to provide further details, stating that any updates on briefings would be shared at the discretion of the committee members.

paragraph1: As I surveyed the bustling scene around the Palazzo del Cinema, I couldn't help but notice the palpable excitement in the air. Groups of young people had set up camp, their eager faces turned towards the red carpet, all hoping to catch a glimpse of a star from Tim Burton's much-anticipated film, "Beetlejuice Beetlejuice," which was set to open the Venice Film Festival. Among the crowd, a teenage boy stood with his parents, his eyes fixed on the entrance. His father broke the anticipation with a question, asking if Jenna Ortega, the popular actress, would be attending. The boy nodded shyly, prompting his parents to exchange knowing smiles, as if silently acknowledging a shared understanding of the boy's admiration for Ortega. It was fascinating to observe how casting stars like Ortega could generate such a fervent interest in films and festivals alike. This stood in stark contrast to the previous year's festival, which had been notably subdued due to an actors' strike that left it devoid of A-list celebrities. The strike had forced organizers to replace a high-profile film with a less glamorous one, and the resulting lack of star power had noticeably dampened the excitement among festival-goers. Today, however, the atmosphere was undeniably electric.
paragraph2: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars. As I surveyed the scene, a teenage boy pulled up on a bicycle, accompanied by his parents. All three craned their necks to check out the still-empty red carpet. “Jenna Ortega is going to be here?” asked his father. The boy nodded shyly and his parents exchanged grins. “That’s his great love, you know,” the father said. Just as casting Ortega, the popular star of “Wednesday,” helped juice interest in Burton’s sequel, so too do glamorous movie stars turbocharge a film festival. Last year, Venice had to make do with precious few A-listers since the actors’ strike barred anyone who had appeared in a big-studio film from doing press for it. That meant the Zendaya tennis romance “Challengers,” planned as the glamorous opening salvo for last year’s festival, was yanked from the lineup and replaced by the Italian war drama “Comandante.” While that movie had its scattered highlights, it didn’t exactly have teenagers lining up for it at 11 in the morning.

paragraph1: I understand how much you want everyone to reconcile and find a happy ending, but sometimes we have to accept that not every family conflict has a perfect resolution. The situation between your nephew and his parents is far more complex than just sharing news about a new baby – these wounds run deep, and simply informing your sister might not bridge the divide that's grown between them. If you're considering sharing this information, I strongly suggest asking your nephew's permission first. It's his life, his family, and his choice to make. From my experience, family therapy could be a potential pathway to healing if everyone's willing to participate and do the hard work. However, I need to caution you against becoming too deeply entangled in their conflict or trying to serve as a mediator between the parties. Sometimes, as painful as it may be to accept, estrangement might actually be the healthiest option for everyone involved. While we naturally want to fix things and bring people together, we must respect that adults make their own choices about their relationships, even when those choices are difficult for us to understand.
paragraph2: AUNT I know how comforting it can be to imagine that every conflict has a happy solution. (It’s why I have a job!) But that’s not always the case. Here, the estrangement is probably more complicated than a few rough conversations. And while telling your sister about the baby may assuage your guilt, it will do little to help anyone else: Your nephew and his parents will still be estranged. You can always ask your nephew for permission to tell his mother, right? But you don’t seem particularly well placed to get involved here: You rarely speak to your sister, after all, and by your own account, you don’t know the full story of the conflict between your nephew and his parents, or even whether your sister knows about the baby already. Still, I admire your desire to help, and I sympathize with your feelings of discomfort. In your place, I would suggest to your sister and your nephew that they might benefit from family therapy. (The baby may give both sides an incentive to reconcile.) But I wouldn’t go beyond that or start shuttling messages between them. As hard as it is to acknowledge, sometimes estrangement is the healthiest outcome. And without closer involvement, you aren’t in a position to know.

paragraph1: The return of the three mystics to their stronghold marks a pivotal moment in "Rings of Power" Episode 2, as they bring dire news to the Dark Wizard, portrayed by Ciaran Hinds, about their confrontation with the Stranger. Having previously faced defeat when the Stranger, now known to be one of the ancient Istari wizards, defended his harfoot companions, the mystics' return is portrayed through a visually striking sequence. The scene's centerpiece features a haunting image of a woman bleeding onto the floor, surrounded by butterflies, which serves as a powerful metaphor for the mystics' transformation following their encounter with the Stranger's formidable powers. This artistically rendered moment not only captures the aftermath of their failed mission but also sets the stage for the introduction of the Dark Wizard's masked mortal warriors. These soldiers emerge as new antagonists, presenting a clear threat with their declared intention to either capture the mysterious Istari or target his halfling allies. The scene effectively blends symbolic imagery with narrative progression, establishing both the consequences of past events and the looming dangers that await the Stranger and his harfoot friends.
paragraph2: Here are five takeaways and observations from Episode 2: Those weird witches are back! Remember how at the end of Season 1, the Stranger had to protect his harfoot friends from three mystics dressed in white who referred to him as “the Dark Lord?” This was a clever bit of misdirection from the “Rings of Power” writers, meant to keep the viewers from catching on too quickly that Halbrand was secretly Sauron. But the incident also helped the Stranger remember that he is actually of the Istari, an ancient order of wizards who in various forms have often intervened in the affairs of Middle-earth. In this season’s second episode, those mystics return to their home base to report to the Dark Wizard (Ciaran Hinds) on their encounter with the Stranger. The sequence is one of the show’s most visually inventive to date, involving a woman bleeding onto the floor while surrounded by hundreds of butterflies — the form the mystics dissipated into after the Stranger violently attacked them — which flutter about and then reconstitute into a different woman. It’s a moment way more elaborate than it needs to be (in a good way), given that this whole scene’s primary purpose is to introduce the Dark Wizard’s masked mortal soldiers, who announce their intention either to capture the Istari or to “slaughter the halflings he calls friends.”

paragraph1: Justin McBride, a senior administrator at Duet: Partners in Health and Aging, has witnessed firsthand the transformative power of mentoring programs in supporting individuals facing health challenges. "The impact is profound on both sides of the relationship," McBride notes, emphasizing how mentors often find as much meaning in the experience as their mentees. Since its inception in 2016, Duet's Phoenix-based program has implemented a rigorous screening and training process for mentors, ensuring quality support for those in need. Similar initiatives, such as Penn's Caring Collective, have adopted varying commitment lengths to accommodate different volunteer schedules while maintaining program effectiveness. These localized efforts complement the work of larger organizations like the Alzheimer's Association, which provides comprehensive support through helplines and support groups for dementia patients and their caregivers. The structured approach to mentoring, combined with the flexibility to meet diverse needs, has proven successful in creating sustainable support networks that benefit both volunteers and recipients of care.
paragraph2: Mentoring can benefit both parties, said Justin McBride, a senior administrator at Duet: Partners in Health and Aging, which began a similar program in Phoenix in 2016. “We hear all the time that supporting another person in need gives mentors a sense of purpose,” he said. “It helps them make sense of their own journey.” The relatively low cost of such volunteer programs could make them replicable in many locations. They operate on a small scale, however. Duet’s program, which like Penn’s involves screening and training mentors, has about 20 pairs enrolled. It requires a six-month commitment, but most mentoring relationships last a year or two. Penn’s newer Caring Collective, requiring a three-month commitment, has enrolled 20 mentors and 40 mentees. Larger organizations like the Alzheimer’s Association also work to support dementia patients and caregivers. Its free 24/7 helpline responded to 215,000 contacts in the 2023 fiscal year, and its online community called ALZConnected has about 10,000 active members. It conducts more than 27,000 caregiver support groups nationally.

paragraph1: As a reporter, I’ve experienced the aftermath of several disasters, including dam bursts, landslides and floods. But nothing quite prepared me to witness the extent of the destruction in Canada’s boreal forests that I saw in June, one year after the record-breaking wildfires of 2023. At one point, my colleague Bryan Denton and I drove for an entire hour and saw almost no living trees in the forests we could see from the road. Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.
paragraph2: Driving through Canada's boreal forests with my colleague Bryan Denton, I was struck speechless by the devastating aftermath of 2023's record-breaking wildfires. Where dense forests once stood, only blackened stumps remained, stretching endlessly across the scorched landscape. The destruction was so complete that local residents told us they were discovering geographical features they'd never seen before – hills, rivers, and even distant towns that had been hidden behind the thick forest canopy. As we navigated the desolate terrain, I couldn't shake the feeling of profound loss. The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
As a reporter, I’ve experienced the aftermath of several disasters, including dam bursts, landslides and floods. But nothing quite prepared me to witness the extent of the destruction in Canada’s boreal forests that I saw in June, one year after the record-breaking wildfires of 2023. At one point, my colleague Bryan Denton and I drove for an entire hour and saw almost no living trees in the forests we could see from the road. Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.

Paragraph 2:
Driving through Canada's boreal forests with my colleague Bryan Denton, I was struck speechless by the devastating aftermath of 2023's record-breaking wildfires. Where dense forests once stood, only blackened stumps remained, stretching endlessly across the scorched landscape. The destruction was so complete that local residents told us they were discovering geographical features they'd never seen before – hills, rivers, and even distant towns that had been hidden behind the thick forest canopy. As we navigated the desolate terrain, I couldn't shake the feeling of profound loss. The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.

paragraph1: Following a rate reversal by the Federal Reserve, the landscape for savers utilizing financial products such as online savings accounts, certificates of deposit (C.D.s), and money market funds is poised for change. These rates are anticipated to decrease, although the pace at which this occurs may differ among financial institutions. Banks are likely to adjust their rates based on their strategic goals, particularly their desire to attract new customers by offering competitive yields. Despite the overall downward trend, online high-yield savings accounts are expected to continue providing more favorable rates compared to traditional commercial banks, which have historically maintained lower yields. This shift highlights the importance of savers staying informed and potentially seeking out online options to maximize their returns amidst changing economic conditions.
paragraph2: Savings Accounts and C.D.s What’s happening now: The rate reversal is likely to be most disappointing for savers, who have benefited from juicier yields on everything from online savings accounts and certificates of deposit to money market funds. Those are all likely to inch lower, in line with the Fed’s move, but some providers may move faster than others. That usually depends on whether the bank wants to attract new customers by dangling yields that are more attractive than their competitors’ offerings. But you can safely assume that online high-yield savings account will still offer more competitive rates than traditional commercial banks, whose yields have remained anemic throughout this period of higher interest rates (averaging 0.45 percent as of September, according to DepositAccounts.com, part of the online loan marketplace LendingTree).

This shift highlights the importance of savers staying informed and potentially seeking out online options to maximize their returns amidst changing economic conditions.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: For billionaires, and the people who love them, breaking up can be a little like unraveling a corporate merger gone wrong. Ending Mr. Schmidt’s affair has taken a decade — so far. There have been contracts, amended contracts, arbitrations, lawsuits and the platoon of advisers that inevitably go along with all that. Mr. Schmidt, now 69 years old, approved a confidential settlement in 2014 with Ms. Simon that paid her an undisclosed amount of money, and appointed an adviser, Derek Rundell, to set it up. Under the arrangement, Ms. Simon would bring Mr. Schmidt investment ideas that Mr. Rundell would evaluate on his behalf. But the deal imploded when Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell fought bitterly, leading to years of wrangling that culminated in accusations of fraud against Ms. Simon last year over an investment in the luggage maker Away. Ms. Simon has denied committing fraud.
paragraph2: The protracted and contentious breakup between billionaire Mr. Schmidt and his former partner, Ms. Simon, has been likened to the unraveling of a complex corporate merger. What began as a seemingly straightforward separation has devolved into a years-long saga of arbitrations, lawsuits, and dueling advisers. A confidential settlement reached in 2014, which included a financial payout and the appointment of investment adviser Derek Rundell, was intended to bring closure to the matter. However, the arrangement ultimately collapsed under the weight of a bitter dispute between Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell, setting off a chain reaction of legal battles and accusations of fraud related to a troubled investment in the luggage company Away. Ms. Simon has vehemently denied any wrongdoing, but the case continues to drag on, a testament to the challenges of untangling the intricate financial and personal ties that once bound the couple together.

paragraph1: In exploring the world of A.I. companionship apps, I have personally experienced their potential benefits, finding them to be a source of comfort and connection. In conversations with other users, many echoed my sentiments, sharing how these apps have positively impacted their lives. However, it's crucial to acknowledge the concerns raised by experts regarding the unproven mental health effects these tools may have. There is a worry that such apps could exacerbate feelings of isolation or serve as inadequate substitutes for essential human interactions, particularly for vulnerable groups like struggling teens. A specific case that underscores these concerns involves Sewell, whose mother, Megan L. Garcia, has taken legal action against Character.AI. The lawsuit argues that the company's technology is "dangerous and untested," potentially misleading users into divulging their private thoughts and emotions. This case highlights the broader debate surrounding the safety and ethical implications of A.I. companionship, prompting us to carefully consider both the advantages and potential risks of integrating such technology into our daily lives.
paragraph2: A.I. companionship apps can provide harmless entertainment or even offer limited forms of emotional support. I had a mostly positive experience when I tried making A.I. friends for a column earlier this year, and I interviewed users of these apps who praised their benefits. But claims about the mental health effects of these tools are largely unproven, and experts say there may be a dark side. For some users, A.I. companions may actually worsen isolation, by replacing human relationships with artificial ones. Struggling teens could use them in place of therapy or asking a parent or trusted adult for support. And when users are experiencing a mental health crisis, their A.I. companions may not be able to get them the help they need. Sewell’s mother, Megan L. Garcia, filed a lawsuit this week against Character.AI, accusing the company of being responsible for Sewell’s death. A draft of the complaint I reviewed says that the company’s technology is “dangerous and untested” and that it can “trick customers into handing over their most private thoughts and feelings.”

A specific case that underscores these concerns involves Sewell, whose mother, Megan L. Garcia, has taken legal action against Character.AI. The lawsuit argues that the company's technology is "dangerous and untested," potentially misleading users into divulging their private thoughts and emotions. This case highlights the broader debate surrounding the safety and ethical implications of A.I. companionship, prompting us to carefully consider both the advantages and potential risks of integrating such technology into our daily lives.

paragraph1: As Ms. Walz enters the national stage, critics on the right are already trying to portray her — as they have with her husband — as a left-wing radical who countenanced the civil unrest in her state after the death George Floyd. But at home in Minnesota, where she has spent most of her life, friends and political observers describe her as the coolheaded and ultracompetent counterpart to a man known for an intuitive and charismatic political style. “We have always worked as a partnership,” Ms. Walz, 58, told the self-improvement podcast “What If It Works” last month, later adding, “We are still one another’s closest advisers.” Ms. Walz did not comment for this article. The first gubernatorial spouse in Minnesota to keep an office in the state capital, Ms. Walz regularly advises her husband and has used her platform to advance policy initiatives, most significantly around offering college degree programs to inmates. Raised in the tiny farming town of Ivanhoe, Minn., only a 15-minute drive from South Dakota’s eastern border, Ms. Walz is the daughter of schoolteachers, and the eldest of four sisters. Ms. Walz was a caretaker in the family, according to her youngest sister, Heidi Ohlmann. “She’s always looking out for everyone,” Ms. Ohlmann said in an interview.
paragraph2: As Ms. Walz steps into the national spotlight, critics have been quick to paint her as a left-wing radical, particularly focusing on her and her husband's political responses in the aftermath of George Floyd's death. Yet within Minnesota's borders, she has cultivated a markedly different reputation as a steady, competent presence that effectively balances her husband's more outgoing personality. At 58, Ms. Walz embraces her role as both partner and adviser to her husband, maintaining an active presence in the state capital where she advocates for progressive initiatives, including educational programs for incarcerated individuals. "I've always seen my role as a partner," she notes, reflecting on her position in the administration. Her roots run deep in Minnesota, where she grew up in Ivanhoe as the eldest of four sisters, born to parents who were both educators. This background appears to have shaped her nurturing approach to public service, with her sister Heidi Ohlmann observing, "She's always been the caretaker of the family." Despite the attempts to characterize her through a partisan lens, Ms. Walz continues to focus on her work, leveraging her measured approach to advance her policy objectives while maintaining her distinctive leadership style.

paragraph1: Twenty-five years later, 1999 is known for being the year of Shyamalan’s movie, of “Blair Witch” and “American Beauty,” which came out in September and went on, somehow, to win the best picture Oscar. The year is remembered for “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace” and “The Matrix,” which had opened in March and by August was winding down its initial colonization of the cultural imagination. It was known for existential identity crackups, and a pervasive itch of anomie, that you could sense in “Office Space,” “Election,” “Dick” and “Fight Club,” which weren’t hits, but also in “American Pie,” which very much was. So Raftery’s breathless tone seems right. It was the last most-exciting period for American moviegoing. It was the last most-exciting time to write about the movies.
paragraph2: In 1999, the cinematic landscape was a vibrant tapestry of innovation and experimentation. It was the year that M. Night Shyamalan's twisty thriller and "The Blair Witch Project" redefined the horror genre, while "American Beauty" and "Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace" dominated the box office. Meanwhile, "The Matrix" was busy blowing minds with its groundbreaking special effects. But beneath the surface, a sense of existential identity crises and anomie was brewing, as seen in films like "Office Space," "Election," "Dick," "Fight Club," and "American Pie." As critic Raftery would likely exclaim with characteristic enthusiasm, 1999 was a thrilling time for American cinema, marked by a sense of creative freedom and risk-taking that would soon become a distant memory. It was, in many ways, the last exciting era for both moviegoing and writing about movies.

paragraph1: Mr. Hadley mused on his choice to retire in Asheville, North Carolina, a place he once deemed a safe climate haven. To his astonishment, they'd already faced heavy rain prior to storm Helene's full development. Now, with storm Milton approaching, he and his wife prepared by stocking up on essentials—food, water, and liquor. He also noted Ms. deGrasse's exceptional peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, which added a comforting touch to their preparations.
paragraph2: Mr. Hadley said that when he retired to the Asheville, N.C., area, he considered it a climate haven. “There was no way of anticipating that we’d get soaked with rain before Helene was even a storm,” he said. Now, awaiting Milton, he and his wife have stocks of food, water and liquor, he said. Ms. deGrasse, he added, “has been making really quite excellent peanut butter and jelly sandwiches.”

paragraph1: There are some economists who fretted about ZIRP because it can enable so-called “zombie businesses”: companies that survive only because of the availability of cheap capital, who stagger along, refinancing debt, never failing — artificial, undead things. And I think about this concept when I look back at the tech world’s takeover of culture. That these business strategies, and this river of money diverted to bring them to fruition, created a sort of zombie discourse in our culture, one that appeared vital and real, and then — coincidentally or not, over the last few years — started to dissolve before our eyes. This discourse emerged, in part, out of digital media — from companies that were themselves kept afloat by investor exuberance and access to cheap money, something that became apparent only in retrospect. When Vice declared bankruptcy last year, The Financial Times called it a “ZIRP phenomenon” and a “cash incinerator,” that raised hundreds of millions of dollars to invest in growth that never arrived; BuzzFeed similarly took on venture investments at an enormous valuation, listened to investors who wanted growth over profits and is now deeply in debt, with Vivek Ramaswamy buying up its dirt-cheap stock, waging an activist campaign to make the site more conservative. Both of these companies, along with countless other smaller enterprises, aimed to generate profits through scale. The profits never came, but all of journalism was nevertheless remade in the image of these outlets: faster, looser, cheaper — and eager to churn out recaps and think pieces about TV.
paragraph2: I think the Zero Interest Rate Policy (ZIRP) has had a profound impact on businesses, especially in the tech and media sectors. This policy allowed "zombie businesses" to persist by providing them with easy access to cheap capital, which in turn led to a "zombie discourse" permeating our cultural landscape. Companies like Vice and BuzzFeed are prime examples of this phenomenon. Vice, often described as a "ZIRP phenomenon" and a "cash incinerator" by The Financial Times, managed to stay afloat for a while thanks to investor enthusiasm and the abundance of cheap money. However, it struggled financially when the initial excitement waned. Similarly, BuzzFeed, which eagerly took on large venture investments, now finds itself grappling with debt. Interestingly, Vivek Ramaswamy has purchased BuzzFeed's stock, advocating for a shift towards a more conservative direction. These companies, fueled by ZIRP, significantly influenced journalism, steering it towards a model that prioritizes speed, sensationalism, and cost-effectiveness. This shift resulted in a proliferation of content such as TV recaps and think pieces, which are cheaper to produce and quicker to disseminate. The emphasis on rapid content generation often came at the expense of depth and thoroughness, reshaping the journalistic landscape into one that values immediacy over substance. Ultimately, the legacy of ZIRP in the media sector is a double-edged sword, offering opportunities for innovation while also contributing to the financial instability and ideological shifts seen in companies like Vice and BuzzFeed.

paragraph1: A Congressional committee is set to scrutinize CrowdStrike, a prominent cybersecurity company, over a sweeping tech outage that crippled millions of Microsoft Windows devices and sent shockwaves across various industries, including airlines, hospitals, and logistics companies. At the center of the controversy is a faulty security update issued by CrowdStrike, which triggered the widespread disruptions. George Kurtz, the company's chief executive, has been summoned to testify at a hearing to account for the company's role in the debacle. Representatives Mark Green of Tennessee and Andrew Garbarino of New York, both Republicans, are spearheading the effort to hold CrowdStrike accountable, having dispatched a letter to Kurtz requesting his prompt response to schedule the hearing. A CrowdStrike spokeswoman confirmed that the company is in communication with the relevant congressional committees, but declined to provide further details, stating that any updates on briefings would be shared at the discretion of the committee members.
paragraph2: A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible. CrowdStrike sent a faulty security update to its customers Thursday night, resulting in millions of Microsoft Windows devices shutting down and disruptions to airlines, hospitals, logistics companies and others. Americans “deserve to know in detail how this incident happened and the mitigation steps CrowdStrike is taking,” wrote Representative Mark Green of Tennessee, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, and Representative Andrew Garbarino, Republican of New York. The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”

paragraph1: Opened in 1970 in a converted dentist’s office, the U District’s Grand Illusion was Seattle’s first celluloid art house and stands today as the city’s oldest continuously running independent movie theater. Now operated by Northwest Film Forum, it features a calendar of films (tickets, $11) that is fabulously eclectic, appealing to fans of documentaries, anime, indie dramas and underappreciated classics. For those seeking a less sedentary way to top off their Saturday, an even older movie theater a few blocks away, the Neptune, has been transformed into a live music and performance space (tickets typically $25 to $45) that hosts an eclectic mix of national touring acts. You can still order popcorn, though.
paragraph2: In Seattle, two notable venues capture the city's rich cultural tapestry. The Grand Illusion, originally opened in 1970 in a former dentist's office, stands as Seattle's oldest independent movie theater. Now managed by the Northwest Film Forum, it showcases a diverse array of films, from documentaries and anime to indie dramas and classics, enriching the city's cinematic landscape. Nearby, the Neptune, an even older theater, has transformed into a vibrant live music and performance venue, attracting national acts. Despite its modern focus, the Neptune retains a nostalgic touch by offering traditional movie theater snacks like popcorn. Both venues embody Seattle's commitment to preserving unique cultural experiences.

For those seeking a less sedentary way to top off their Saturday, an even older movie theater a few blocks away, the Neptune, has been transformed into a live music and performance space (tickets typically $25 to $45) that hosts an eclectic mix of national touring acts. You can still order popcorn, though.

paragraph1: For Aldis Hodge, the allure of "Cross" began with a single script, penned by Watkins, that would eventually draw him in as both a producer and actor on the show. "After reading the pilot, I knew I wanted to be a part of this story," Hodge recalled, noting that he was particularly drawn to the complexity of the titular character, Alex Cross. As Hodge delved deeper into the project, he found himself refining the script alongside Watkins, with the two engaging in candid conversations about their personal experiences and aspirations as men. These discussions would ultimately inform Hodge's portrayal of Cross, a character grappling with the devastating loss of his wife at the series' outset. "I wanted to explore the hero complex, the guilt, the grief - all the things that make us human," Watkins explained, his words echoing the show's thoughtful examination of Cross's emotional burdens. As the series navigates the dark aftermath of tragedy, Hodge and Watkins aim to craft a nuanced, deeply human character in Alex Cross, one whose journey towards healing is both deeply personal and universally relatable.
paragraph2: Aldis Hodge — who is a producer of “Cross” — signed up for the show soon after reading Watkins’s script. He then threw himself into helping refine it. “From the beginning, Ben and I talked about where we were at as men in our lives, what we wanted for ourselves,” Hodge said. “That’s what fed the trajectory of how I portrayed Alex Cross.” Integral to the character’s psyche is the death of his wife, who is killed at the start of the first episode. Cross, who is described as having a hero complex that gives him a “compulsion to protect,” is burdened not only by loss but also by guilt at the thought that he failed her. “I want to create a character who is dealing with grief and making choices that are having a negative impact on the people around them,” Watkins said. “It’s an iconic detective, but your journey as a character is really going to be about you confronting your own emotional burdens and figuring out a way through them.”

paragraph1: In a remarkable display of scientific collaboration, researchers from 19 competing drug, biotech, and medical companies gathered at a Phoenix airport hotel to tackle a critical challenge in Alzheimer's research. Their mission was to develop collaborative strategies for testing anti-amyloid drugs as preventive measures in cognitively healthy individuals. Jessica Langbaum, senior director at the Banner institute, emphasized the crucial need for trial participants carrying the APOE4 gene variant, noting that "identifying individuals with this genetic marker is essential for our research, as they face an increased risk of developing Alzheimer's." The meeting's most pressing ethical consideration centered on whether to disclose genetic risk information to study participants. Dr. Robert Klitzman addressed this complex issue, stating, "Researchers face a significant conflict of interest when deciding whether to inform participants about their genetic status, as this knowledge could impact both the study's integrity and the participants' well-being." After careful deliberation, the assembled scientists reached a consensus that transparency should be paramount in their approach. They determined that participants must be fully informed about their genetic status and provided with comprehensive genetic counseling services. This unprecedented gathering demonstrated how competing entities could set aside their differences in pursuit of a greater scientific goal, potentially revolutionizing the approach to Alzheimer's prevention trials while maintaining ethical standards in human subject research.
paragraph2: The same year as the Honolulu conference, researchers from 19 drug, biotech and medical companies came together at a Phoenix airport hotel for a highly unusual meeting. Though fierce competitors, the scientists wanted to collaborate on strategies for Alzheimer’s research — specifically whether anti-amyloid drugs could prevent Alzheimer’s in people who were still cognitively normal, before the onset of decline. “You really needed people who might progress to cognitive impairment or start to develop symptoms of the disease in a relatively short period of time,” recalled Jessica Langbaum, a senior director at the Banner institute, which hosted the meeting. In other words, they needed trial subjects with a gene variant called APOE4 — people with a high genetic probability of developing Alzheimer’s. People with two copies of the gene variant constitute an estimated 2 to 3 percent of the general population and 15 to 20 percent of people with Alzheimer’s. Those with only one copy make up about half of Alzheimer’s patients. One question in Phoenix was how, or even if, these trial subjects should be told their grim genetic profiles, according to a written, contemporaneous account of the meeting. “Researchers unfortunately have an inherent conflict of interest,” said Dr. Robert Klitzman, director of the Masters of Bioethics Program at Columbia University. “They want people to be in their study, and there are researchers who feel, if I tell people the full facts and risks, they may not want to be in the study.” A general agreement emerged from the meeting around the importance of transparency; participants would be informed. To cope with this news, they would first undergo genetic counseling.

paragraph1: When I was a child, opening the next package felt like a treasure hunt. As I grew older, it began to feel like something far more fundamental, like air or community, something like prayer. Her messages met me like guideposts in a dark forest; if her words couldn’t point the way, at least they offered the comfort of knowing someone had been there before. A decade after I lost my mother, my father followed suddenly. She had spent years preparing her exit, but with him I blinked, and he was gone. The morning of his memorial, the box stared back at me with nothing to say. There was no letter for this. I tried to conjure her voice but couldn’t. My father left no clues or letters. The only parenting I would have, from 22 on, was in the box. When I hit 30, the nearly empty box sat in my Brooklyn apartment, clashing with the furniture. Only those three packages remained: Engagement, Wedding, First Baby. They sat in their shiny cardboard and pink ribbon, expectant, waiting.
paragraph2: Opening packages from my mother was always an adventure, a treasure hunt that filled my childhood with wonder and excitement. These carefully wrapped gifts evolved into something far more profound - they became my lifeline, as essential as the air I breathed and the community that surrounded me. But life had other plans, and the sudden loss of both my parents left me adrift at twenty-two, with no more guidance to come, no more letters to anticipate. All that remained was a box of my mother's packages, a tangible connection to her love and foresight. Now, at thirty, I live in my Brooklyn apartment with this box that grows lighter with each passing year. Inside, only three unopened packages remain, each wrapped in shiny cardboard and tied with pink ribbon, waiting for life's biggest moments: Engagement, Wedding, and First Baby. These final gifts stand as silent guardians of future milestones, holding within their carefully preserved wrapping the last pieces of maternal guidance I'll ever receive.

paragraph1: In a recent study published in Nature Medicine, researchers explored the psychological effects of the drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, commonly prescribed for diabetes and obesity, respectively. The study, funded by the National Institutes of Health, found that individuals using these medications exhibited a slightly reduced likelihood of experiencing suicidal thoughts compared to those who were not taking them. Utilizing a comprehensive database of anonymized electronic health records from over 100 million individuals, the researchers meticulously compared two distinct groups: those prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and those receiving Ozempic or other blood sugar-lowering medications. The findings of this extensive analysis aim to provide reassurance to users of these drugs, highlighting a potential mental health benefit alongside their physical health uses. Importantly, the study was conducted independently of Novo Nordisk, the manufacturer of both medications, ensuring the results were free from any conflicts of interest. This research not only contributes to the understanding of the multifaceted impacts of these medications but also underscores the importance of considering mental health outcomes when assessing the overall benefits of pharmaceutical interventions for chronic conditions like diabetes and obesity.
paragraph2: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday. Millions of people take Ozempic and Wegovy, which are considered to be among the biggest blockbusters in medical history. But last year a European drug safety agency said it was investigating whether the drugs cause suicidal thoughts. The new study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, was funded by the National Institutes of Health and used a huge population. The findings provide data that may potentially reassure people who take the drugs. Novo Nordisk, maker of the drugs, had no role in the study, and the study’s investigators had no conflicts of interest. The investigators used anonymized electronic health records from a database of 100.8 million people. That allowed them to look at two groups: 240,618 who were prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and 1,589,855 who were prescribed Ozempic or other medicines to lower their blood sugar. Suicidal thoughts were included in patients’ records as part of routine monitoring of their health.

paragraph1: Reflecting on the actions and motivations of certain political figures, I find myself questioning whether individuals like Trump and Landry are driven by a literal interpretation of biblical principles, such as "an eye for an eye" or the stoning of disobedient children. Their apparent disregard for the First Amendment, designed to protect religion from state interference, is deeply concerning. It seems they are advancing an agenda that aligns with the Christian nationalist movement, which erroneously claims that America was founded as a Christian nation. However, this perspective overlooks the pluralistic foundation of our country and the constitutional prohibition against imposing a single religion. Such actions are not only unconstitutional but also exclusionary and offensive, particularly in the Southern states where these laws have been enacted. They undermine the diverse fabric of our nation and threaten the freedom of religion that is supposed to be a cornerstone of American democracy, disregarding the rights of those who hold different beliefs.
paragraph2: Forgive me for wondering: Is he referring to “an eye for an eye” or the stoning of disobedient children? Either way, for both Trump and true believers, it hardly matters that the First Amendment was intended to protect religion from the state, not to have the state impose a religion. (So much for originalism.) Their goal is to impose one form of religion, Christianity, and the underlying message is that those who do not share it will have to submit. Not only have such moves been declared unconstitutional (“I can’t wait to be sued,” Landry said), but they are also exclusionary and offensive to many. Despite what the Christian nationalist movement would have you believe, America was not founded as a Christian nation. Nor is it one today. In a pluralistic country, neither the Bible nor Judeo-Christian values are universal, including in the two heavily Christian Southern states in which these laws were passed.

Such actions are not only unconstitutional but also exclusionary and offensive, particularly in the Southern states where these laws have been enacted. They undermine the diverse fabric of our nation and threaten the freedom of religion that is supposed to be a cornerstone of American democracy, disregarding the rights of those who hold different beliefs.

Paragraph 2:

Either way, for both Trump and true believers, it hardly matters that the First Amendment was intended to protect religion from the state, not to have the state impose a religion. paragraph1: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday for illegally collecting children’s data, escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app. TikTok broke the law by gathering personal information from users under the age of 13 without their parents’ permission, according to the government’s complaint. The company knowingly allowed children under the age of 13 to create and use TikTok accounts, the government said, and frequently failed to honor parents’ requests to delete their children’s accounts. The lawsuit, which was filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, said those practices violated both the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act, a law that restricts the online tracking of children, and a 2019 agreement between TikTok and the government in which the company pledged to notify parents before collecting children’s data and remove videos from users under 13 years old. The suit, which also names TikTok’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance, asks for the court to fine the companies over the violations. “With this action, the Department seeks to ensure that TikTok honors its obligation to protect children’s privacy rights and parents’ efforts to protect their children,” said Benjamin C. Mizer, the acting associate attorney general, in a statement. TikTok did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
paragraph2: The U.S. Justice Department has taken significant legal action against TikTok by filing a lawsuit that accuses the social media giant of unlawfully collecting personal data from children under 13 without obtaining parental consent. The lawsuit, which also names TikTok's parent company ByteDance as a defendant, alleges that the platform violated both the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act and a previous settlement agreement by enabling young children to create accounts on the platform and subsequently failing to remove these accounts when parents requested their deletion. Filed in the Central District of California, the legal action seeks monetary penalties for these alleged violations, highlighting the government's growing concern over digital privacy protection for minors. Acting Associate Attorney General Benjamin C. Mizer has emphasized the critical nature of safeguarding children's privacy rights in the digital age, underscoring the Justice Department's commitment to holding social media companies accountable for their actions. As of now, TikTok has maintained silence regarding these serious allegations, which could potentially result in substantial financial penalties and increased scrutiny of the platform's user verification and data collection practices. The case represents a significant escalation in the ongoing debate about social media companies' responsibilities toward their youngest users.

paragraph1: The deliberate approach to the Starliner spacecraft's return reflects a commitment to thorough safety protocols and inclusive decision-making. Mr. Bowersox indicated that the selection of astronauts for return would follow an extensive review process, though the ultimate authority lies with NASA Administrator Bill Nelson. This methodical strategy underscores the complex nature of space operations and the paramount importance of crew safety.
paragraph2: With the more inclusive process, “I recognize that that may mean, at times, we don’t move very fast,” he said. “We need to be very careful to make sure that everybody’s perspective is shared.” In a statement, Boeing said that it was ready to support NASA for the return of Starliner, with or without the astronauts. The company was “focused first and foremost on ensuring the safety of the astronauts,” it said. Mr. Bowersox said that he would make a decision on how to bring the astronauts home after the agencywide review, although Bill Nelson, the NASA administrator, would have the final call.

paragraph1: The story, largely set in 1995, follows a police captain named Ma Zhe (Zhu Yilong) as he investigates the killing of a woman called Granny Four. At first, the case seems straightforward: Granny Four had taken in a simpleton who, throughout the movie, is known only as “the madman” (Kang Chunlei) — a natural suspect. But nothing is so clear-cut. Many of this thriller’s pleasures involve watching Ma Zhe chase leads, as he listens to a cassette found at the crime scene to try to locate a woman heard on it or questions a hairdresser (Wang Jianyu) who seems eager to be apprehended.
paragraph2: In the gripping thriller set in 1995, police captain Ma Zhe, portrayed by Zhu Yilong, is tasked with solving the murder of Granny Four, a case that initially seems straightforward. The obvious suspect is "the madman," a character played by Kang Chunlei, whom Granny Four had taken under her wing. However, as Ma Zhe delves deeper, the investigation becomes increasingly complex. He follows a trail of cryptic clues, including a cassette tape found at the crime scene, which leads him to a mysterious woman. A conversation with Wang Jianyu, a suspiciously cooperative hairdresser, raises more questions than answers, keeping Ma Zhe - and the viewer - on edge.

paragraph1: Mr. Chiu's collaboration with Ms. Harris and her deputies proved instrumental in crafting the Reproductive FACT Act, a bill designed to withstand anticipated legal opposition from anti-abortion organizations. As the attorney general during this period, Ms. Harris played a pivotal role in shaping the legislation and publicly endorsed it upon its enactment by Governor Jerry Brown. The law, however, soon encountered significant resistance from crisis pregnancy centers, resulting in multiple legal challenges that initially named Ms. Harris as the defendant in her official capacity. Following her election to the United States Senate, these cases were transferred to her successor, Xavier Becerra, who continued to defend the law's constitutionality. Despite initial victories in lower courts that appeared to validate the careful legal groundwork laid by Ms. Harris and her team, the law's journey through the judicial system ultimately concluded with its invalidation by the Supreme Court in 2018. This outcome, while disappointing for its supporters, highlighted the complex interplay between state-level legislative efforts and federal constitutional interpretation, as well as the challenges faced by lawmakers in crafting legislation that can successfully navigate both immediate legal challenges and long-term judicial scrutiny.
paragraph2: “She made sure that her deputies were very involved in the crafting of the language, and all of us who are working on it were very grateful that she was willing to lend her name and her office to the cause,” Mr. Chiu said. Attorneys in her office tried to help ensure that the bill could survive legal challenges they anticipated from anti-abortion groups, he said, adding that he appreciated “knowing that our bill was heavily vetted by her team. They were careful to make sure that it was well crafted.” Ms. Harris praised the bill in a public statement when Gov. Jerry Brown signed it into law. “I am proud to have cosponsored the Reproductive FACT Act, which ensures that all women have equal access to comprehensive reproductive health care services, and that they have the facts they need to make informed decisions about their health and their lives,” she said. The law was quickly challenged by crisis pregnancy centers, which sued Ms. Harris in her capacity as attorney general. Her successor, Xavier Becerra, became the defendant in the cases when he became the attorney general in 2017 after Ms. Harris was elected to the United States Senate. Judges at the district court and appellate court levels upheld the law, but in 2018, the Supreme Court sided with pregnancy centers in the case, invalidating the law.

paragraph1: Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.
paragraph2: The piece has yet another unique element that Dr. Maldonado discovered as she sketched it. “I realized that below the head of the decapitated person there is a glyph that is possibly the name of the person whose head was cut off,” she said. Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. Another, with wide eyes and parted lips, known as the Young Woman of Amajac, wears a long skirt, blouse and a headdress that cascades to either side, like a waterfall.

"The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.

Paragraph 2:
The piece has yet another unique element that Dr. Maldonado discovered as she sketched it. “I realized that below the head of the decapitated person there is a glyph that is possibly the name of the person whose head was cut off,” she said. Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. paragraph1: Back at the Wharf, drop into Shop Made in DC, which spotlights Washington-based artisans. You’ll find “202” (the city’s area code) and “The District vs Congress” T-shirts by Bailiwick Clothing, illustrated maps of local neighborhoods by Terratorie, and tiny onesies covered in cherry blossoms by Mirasa Design. Then stroll to Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant on the waterfront with colorful fixtures made in Lebanon, such as laser-cut metal doves suspended from the ceiling and dining chairs with hand-sewn floral designs. You’ll see local twists on the cuisine, like the hummus ($13) that can be topped with Maryland blue crab falafel ($8). Don’t miss the fried brussels sprouts with grapes and mint yogurt ($18), and a plate of riz (Lebanese rice, toasted vermicelli, Marcona almonds and cashews, $11) to accompany the heaping mixed grill for two ($76). Book a week ahead.
paragraph2: When you visit the vibrant Wharf, it feels like stepping into a world of local creativity and culinary delight. Begin your adventure at Shop Made in DC, where the shelves brim with unique products crafted by local artisans. You'll find stylish T-shirts from Bailiwick Clothing, intricately designed maps by Terratorie, and adorable cherry blossom onesies by Mirasa Design, each item a testament to the local talent. As you continue your exploration, make sure to reserve a table at Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant offering a delightful twist on traditional cuisine. Savor the exquisite flavors of hummus adorned with Maryland blue crab falafel or indulge in the crispy fried Brussels sprouts paired with grapes and mint yogurt. To ensure you don't miss out on this culinary experience, it's wise to book your meal at Ilili at least a week in advance.

paragraph1: One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.
paragraph2: Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.

Paragraph 1:
One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

Paragraph 2:
Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.

paragraph1: For billionaires, and the people who love them, breaking up can be a little like unraveling a corporate merger gone wrong. Ending Mr. Schmidt’s affair has taken a decade — so far. There have been contracts, amended contracts, arbitrations, lawsuits and the platoon of advisers that inevitably go along with all that. Mr. Schmidt, now 69 years old, approved a confidential settlement in 2014 with Ms. Simon that paid her an undisclosed amount of money, and appointed an adviser, Derek Rundell, to set it up. Under the arrangement, Ms. Simon would bring Mr. Schmidt investment ideas that Mr. Rundell would evaluate on his behalf. But the deal imploded when Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell fought bitterly, leading to years of wrangling that culminated in accusations of fraud against Ms. Simon last year over an investment in the luggage maker Away. Ms. Simon has denied committing fraud.
paragraph2: The protracted and contentious breakup between billionaire Mr. Schmidt and his former partner, Ms. Simon, has been likened to the unraveling of a complex corporate merger. What began as a seemingly straightforward separation has devolved into a years-long saga of arbitrations, lawsuits, and dueling advisers. A confidential settlement reached in 2014, which included a financial payout and the appointment of investment adviser Derek Rundell, was intended to bring closure to the matter. However, the arrangement ultimately collapsed under the weight of a bitter dispute between Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell, setting off a chain reaction of legal battles and accusations of fraud related to a troubled investment in the luggage company Away. Ms. Simon has vehemently denied any wrongdoing, but the case continues to drag on, a testament to the challenges of untangling the intricate financial and personal ties that once bound the couple together.

Mr. Schmidt, now 69 years old, approved a confidential settlement in 2014 with Ms. Simon that paid her an undisclosed amount of money, and appointed an adviser, Derek Rundell, to set it up. Under the arrangement, Ms. Simon would bring Mr. Schmidt investment ideas that Mr. Rundell would evaluate on his behalf. But the deal imploded when Ms. Simon and Mr. Rundell fought bitterly, leading to years of wrangling that culminated in accusations of fraud against Ms. Simon last year over an investment in the luggage maker Away. Ms. Simon has denied committing fraud.

Paragraph 2:
The protracted and contentious breakup between billionaire Mr. Schmidt and his former partner, Ms. Simon, has been likened to the unraveling of a complex corporate merger. What began as a seemingly straightforward separation has devolved into a years-long saga of arbitrations, lawsuits, and dueling advisers. A confidential settlement reached in 2014, which included a financial payout and the appointment of investment adviser Derek Rundell, was intended to bring closure to the matter. paragraph1: Pharmaceutical companies and health regulators have been actively working to address mpox vaccination challenges across different regions. KM Biologics, based in Japan, has taken a significant step by submitting their vaccine documentation, while Bavarian Nordic has enhanced their proposal with supplementary data regarding their vaccine's adaptability to various healthcare settings. A notable obstacle in the vaccination effort is the stringent storage requirement of the Jynneos vaccine, which must be maintained at minus 20 degrees Celsius—a specification that many health facilities in countries like Congo cannot meet. Adding to the complexity is the varying effectiveness of vaccines against different mpox virus strains, particularly between Clade 2 and Clade 1, with the latter being prevalent in Congo and East Africa. Mr. Mubangizi has voiced concerns about the vaccine's effectiveness specifically against Clade 1. The delayed approval of both Jynneos and LC16 vaccines by Congo's drug regulatory authority, especially when compared to Nigeria's swifter response, has raised apprehension among health organizations. Dr. Kamba, serving as Congo's health minister, attributes this delay to the nation's resource constraints and ongoing multiple crises, highlighting the complex challenges facing healthcare systems in developing nations.
paragraph2: KM Biologics, a Japanese pharmaceutical company that makes an mpox vaccine called LC16, submitted its dossier on Friday. Bavarian Nordic offered additional information regarding what the W.H.O. calls “programmatic suitability for use,” he said. This refers to aspects of the vaccine that may influence how it can be used in different settings. The Jynneos vaccine, for example, needs to be stored at minus 20 degrees Celsius, but not all health centers in a country such as Congo will be able to keep vials of it that cold. Regulators in high-income countries do not typically evaluate a vaccine with these kinds of considerations. Most of the data collected on the Jynneos vaccine evaluated it for use on the Clade 2 mpox virus, a less lethal version that caused the 2022 global outbreak. But the Clade 1 virus is circulating in Congo and across East Africa, and the vaccine has not been tested against it. “We are not sure the efficacy on Clade 2 is transferable to Clade 1 — nobody has that information,” Mr. Mubangizi said. Congo’s own drug regulator approved Jynneos and the LC16 vaccine on June 27 — long after Nigeria, which had many mpox cases in the 2022 outbreak, did an approval of its own. The lengthy delay raised eyebrows in health agencies supporting Congo, but Dr. Kamba, the health minister, said the country has limited resources and a host of crises. “We have a lot of emergencies on our hands,” Dr. Kamba said.

paragraph1: Ms. Page, who is in her second year in charge, always assumed that any athletic rewards would come in the form of participation, camaraderie, personal development and enjoyment. A citywide sports title was the terrain of the big high schools. But she credited the head coach, Tamara Karcher, and her assistant, Steven Rabinowitz, a history teacher at Baccalaureate, for inspiring the best from the players, whose love of the game helped them work through the logistical obstacles. Ms. Karcher said the biggest headache she faced was clearing people off fields before games when the team had a permit to use them. Sometimes there’s a soccer game happening, or kids are goofing off. Earlier this season, a man reading a book in a dugout refused to leave, claiming he was not bothering anyone. But it was a potentially unsafe situation. “The cops got involved, and I’ll just leave it at that,” Ms. Karcher said. “It’s unpleasant for the girls to have to deal with that.”
paragraph2: In her second year overseeing the sports program, Ms. Page initially believed the benefits of athletics lay primarily in participation and personal growth, rather than in winning titles, which she assumed were the domain of larger schools. However, her perspective began to shift as she witnessed the dedication and determination of the head coach, Tamara Karcher, and her assistant, Steven Rabinowitz, who tirelessly motivated the players to overcome numerous challenges. Ms. Karcher, in particular, faced several logistical hurdles, such as securing playing fields for practice and games. One memorable incident involved a man who refused to leave a dugout, necessitating police intervention to resolve the situation. Although this ordeal was unpleasant for the team, it underscored the persistent issues they encountered in maintaining access to adequate facilities. Despite these challenges, Ms. Page came to appreciate the resilience and teamwork fostered by the sports program, recognizing that its true value extended beyond mere participation and growth, potentially even towards achieving competitive success.

paragraph1: Ljubljana Castle and its Castle Hill has watched over the capital for millennia and is the spot for panoramas, wine and dinner in a Michelin-starred restaurant. Plecnik House, which was the home and studio of the city’s chief 20th-century designer, Joze Plecnik, remains as he left it at the time of his death in 1957. The Krizanke Summer Theater, which comes alive from June to September during the Ljubljana Festival, stages pop, jazz and symphonic concerts. Center Rog, a former bicycle factory opened last year as an art laboratory and now provides workspaces for designers and artists, a public library, cafes and shops. The Triple Bridge, designed by Joze Plecnik, connects the central Preseren Square to Ljubljana’s Old Town. Cukrarna Gallery, which opened in 2021 in a repurposed sugar refinery, is a contemporary art space that questions and honors cultural heritage. The National and University Library serves as both Ljubljana’s intellectual center and a monument to the city’s rebirth through 20th-century design.
paragraph2: In the heart of Ljubljana, Slovenia's capital, a tapestry of cultural landmarks and historical sites unfolds, offering a rich exploration of the city's heritage. Dominating the skyline, Ljubljana Castle draws visitors with its sweeping panoramic views and fine dining experiences, setting the stage for an unforgettable visit. The Plecnik House, once the abode and studio of the visionary architect Joze Plecnik, stands as a testament to his enduring influence. Not far away, the Krizanke Summer Theater pulses with life during the Ljubljana Festival, hosting vibrant summer concerts. Center Rog, a transformed bicycle factory, now thrives as an art laboratory, complete with workspaces, a library, cafes, and shops, embodying a spirit of creativity. The iconic Triple Bridge, another Plecnik masterpiece, elegantly unites key areas of the city. Meanwhile, the Cukrarna Gallery, housed in a repurposed sugar refinery, actively engages with cultural heritage through contemporary art. The National and University Library serves as both an intellectual hub and a beacon of Ljubljana's 20th-century design renaissance.
