paragraph1: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. “Not that I don’t love hanging out with my sisters — I’m just not comfortable with people being in my space like that,” she said. “I’m old school. I’m a bit aloof.” She ultimately did it for Traci, who died of esophageal cancer in 2022 and who had been adamant that her sisters continue with the show. Grief and healing are the main themes in the all-new series “The Braxtons,” which airs on We TV and is available on the streaming service ALLBLK. It isn’t the same without Traci, Toni Braxton said. “Part of our DNA is missing. Everyone is trying figure out how to live in this heartache.” Besides “Braxton Family Values,” Braxton is known for her roles on Broadway (“Beauty and the Beast,” “Aida,” “After Midnight”) and for her many R&B hits, including “Breathe Again,” “Another Sad Love Song” and “Un-Break My Heart” — which she performs in “Love & Laughter,” her joint Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer.
paragraph2: Toni Braxton, the Grammy-winning R&B singer and actress, has always been protective of her personal space. "I'm old school, I'm aloof," she admits, reflecting on her initial reluctance to reboot the reality show "Braxton Family Values," which she starred in alongside her sisters Traci, Towanda, Trina, and Tamar. However, after Traci's passing from esophageal cancer in 2022, Toni decided to participate in the new series, "The Braxtons," as a tribute to her sister's memory. "She wanted us to keep going, to keep the show alive," Toni explains. The new series, which premiered on We TV and ALLBLK, takes a more somber tone, exploring themes of grief and healing as the family navigates life without Traci. "It's different without her, it's just not the same," Toni notes, her voice tinged with sadness. Despite her reservations, Toni has continued to thrive in her career, with recent stints on Broadway and a Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer. As she looks to the future, Toni is determined to keep her sister's memory alive, both on and off screen. "I'm doing this for Traci," she says, her voice filled with conviction.
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. “Not that I don’t love hanging out with my sisters — I’m just not comfortable with people being in my space like that,” she said. “I’m old school. I’m a bit aloof.” She ultimately did it for Traci, who died of esophageal cancer in 2022 and who had been adamant that her sisters continue with the show. Grief and healing are the main themes in the all-new series “The Braxtons,” which airs on We TV and is available on the streaming service ALLBLK. It isn’t the same without Traci, Toni Braxton said. “Part of our DNA is missing. Everyone is trying figure out how to live in this heartache.” Besides “Braxton Family Values,” Braxton is known for her roles on Broadway (“Beauty and the Beast,” “Aida,” “After Midnight”) and for her many R&B hits, including “Breathe Again,” “Another Sad Love Song” and “Un-Break My Heart” — which she performs in “Love & Laughter,” her joint Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer.

Paragraph 2:
Toni Braxton, the Grammy-winning R&B singer and actress, has always been protective of her personal space. "I'm old school, I'm aloof," she admits, reflecting on her initial reluctance to reboot the reality show "Braxton Family Values," which she starred in alongside her sisters Traci, Towanda, Trina, and Tamar. However, after Traci's passing from esophageal cancer in 2022, Toni decided to participate in the new series, "The Braxtons," as a tribute to her sister's memory. "She wanted us to keep going, to keep the show alive," Toni explains. The new series, which premiered on We TV and ALLBLK, takes a more somber tone, exploring themes of grief and healing as the family navigates life without Traci. "It's different without her, it's just not the same," Toni notes, her voice tinged with sadness. Despite her reservations, Toni has continued to thrive in her career, with recent stints on Broadway and a Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer. As she looks to the future, Toni is determined to keep her sister's memory alive, both on and off screen. "I'm doing this for Traci," she says, her voice filled with conviction.

paragraph1: In 1999, the cinematic landscape was a vibrant tapestry of innovation and experimentation. It was the year that M. Night Shyamalan's twisty thriller and "The Blair Witch Project" redefined the horror genre, while "American Beauty" and "Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace" dominated the box office. Meanwhile, "The Matrix" was busy blowing minds with its groundbreaking special effects. But beneath the surface, a sense of existential identity crises and anomie was brewing, as seen in films like "Office Space," "Election," "Dick," "Fight Club," and "American Pie." As critic Raftery would likely exclaim with characteristic enthusiasm, 1999 was a thrilling time for American cinema, marked by a sense of creative freedom and risk-taking that would soon become a distant memory. It was, in many ways, the last exciting era for both moviegoing and writing about movies.
paragraph2: Twenty-five years later, 1999 is known for being the year of Shyamalan’s movie, of “Blair Witch” and “American Beauty,” which came out in September and went on, somehow, to win the best picture Oscar. The year is remembered for “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace” and “The Matrix,” which had opened in March and by August was winding down its initial colonization of the cultural imagination. It was known for existential identity crackups, and a pervasive itch of anomie, that you could sense in “Office Space,” “Election,” “Dick” and “Fight Club,” which weren’t hits, but also in “American Pie,” which very much was. So Raftery’s breathless tone seems right. It was the last most-exciting period for American moviegoing. It was the last most-exciting time to write about the movies.

paragraph1:
Under the Tree
This squirrel stared at me, wondering why I was sitting under its tree. I always come to this tree when I feel out of sorts. I was supposed to have a date that day but never got a text back. Friends say it has nothing to do with me. Mom says, “You need higher self-esteem.” I love myself, but I’m slowly unraveling, trying to see myself the way I know I should. Under the tree with the squirrel staring at me, I thought, “It’s nice to have other living things acknowledge me.” — Mia Mitchell
paragraph2: The squirrel's beady eyes bore into me as I sit here under the maple tree, my phone clutched in my hand like some kind of lifeline. Three hours, seventeen minutes, and still no text back. Mom says I'm too good for someone who can't even bother to cancel properly, and Sarah keeps insisting I need to "know my worth," but right now, all I know is this hollow feeling in my chest. It's funny how a simple unanswered message can make you question everything about yourself. The squirrel tilts its head, probably wondering why I'm still here, and honestly, I'm wondering the same thing.

paragraph1: As Hurricane Milton bears down on the Tampa Bay area, threatening to make landfall as a Category 5 storm, Mr. Lopez stands ready to lend a hand. The Honduras native, who now calls the New Orleans area home, traveled to Florida in the aftermath of Hurricane Helene, drawn by the promise of work and the opportunity to support his family while contributing to the city's recovery efforts. With Milton poised to deliver the region's first major direct hit in nearly a century, Mr. Lopez has no intention of leaving. Instead, he plans to stay and assist with the storm's aftermath, joining a growing army of disaster recovery workers organized and trained by Resilience Force, a nonprofit founded by Saket Soni. As the storm intensifies, Mr. Soni's organization is working tirelessly to prepare its workforce for the anticipated rebuilding efforts in the densely populated region, where the need for skilled and dedicated workers like Mr. Lopez will be greater than ever.
paragraph2: “It’s a sacrifice,” Mr. Lopez, who moved to the New Orleans area from Honduras, said in Spanish. He drove to Florida three days after Helene hit the state late last month. “But it’s worth it. We know that we’re going to get a lot of work and bring income to our families. And the biggest satisfaction is that we can help a city rebuild.” Mr. Lopez said he planned to ride out Hurricane Milton in Florida and would very likely remain there to assist in the recovery. The storm roared back to Category 5 strength on Tuesday afternoon, and the Tampa Bay region was bracing for what could be its first direct hit from a major storm since the 1920s. “If Milton stays on course and hits Tampa, that’s where everybody will go,” said Saket Soni, the founder and executive director of Resilience Force, a nonprofit that organizes disaster recovery workers and offers them safety training. “It’s just an enormously dense area that hasn’t faced a storm in a century. That’s where much of the rebuilding efforts will focus.”

paragraph1: As you carve through the powdery slopes of Niseko, Japan, you'll want to cap off your day with a quintessential après-ski ritual: a soak in a geothermal hot spring, or onsen. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, a public bathhouse nestled within a ryokan in Annupuri, where you can unwind in a serene outdoor setting. But first, be sure to follow Japanese etiquette by bringing a modesty towel and soap, and cleansing thoroughly before entering the communal pool. Note that bathing suits are not allowed, and the onsen is gender-separated. As you settle into the 130-degree Fahrenheit mineral water, sourced from Mount Annupuri, you'll feel your muscles relax beneath the wooden pergola, surrounded by snow-covered boulders. For a mere 1,000 yen, you can indulge in this rejuvenating experience, a perfect way to round out a day on the slopes. So come and immerse yourself in this tranquil Japanese tradition.
paragraph2: 8) 2:30 p.m. Après ski ritual With Japan’s volcanic landscape, there are ample onsens (geothermal hot springs) in Niseko; taking to the waters at a public bathhouse is both an essential ritual of Japanese culture and part of the ski experience. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, in a ryokan (traditional Japanese inn) in Annupuri. Know the Japanese etiquette, such as bringing your own little “modesty towel” and soap to cleanse thoroughly before dipping, naked (no bathing suits allowed), into a communal outdoor pool. Like most onsen, this one is separated by gender. The outdoor pool, under a wood pergola and surrounded by snow and boulders, features mineral water pumped from the base of Mount Annupuri. It may be cold outside, but you’re relaxing your body and soul in about 130 degree Fahrenheit, mineral-rich bubbling water. Folding and placing the towel on your head is a custom. Cost: 1,000 yen.

paragraph1: We’re sometimes too preoccupied nowadays with the question of epistemic privacy — with preventing others from having access to facts about us. Plenty of people will inevitably end up knowing plenty about your daughter as she grows up; her kindergarten teacher, her schoolmates and their parents will certainly know just the sorts of facts that you might be contemplating sharing with her biological half siblings. You ask about the ethics of sharing “her identity and some personal information.” But what — aside from the fact that she is the child of a sperm donor — does that really mean? Her name, her age, the state where she resides? How does someone knowing those things pose a threat to her that she might reasonably complain about later?
paragraph2: As I consider your concerns about sharing information about your daughter with her biological half-siblings, I find myself questioning what exactly constitutes the private aspects of her identity. While I understand your protective instinct, I wonder if basic facts like her name, age, or where she lives truly compromise her epistemic privacy. Having worked with many families in similar situations, I've observed that children often benefit from knowing about their biological connections, even if maintained at arm's length. Your daughter's identity is more than just these basic facts – it's her experiences, her personality, and the life you've built together. Perhaps we could find a middle ground that respects both her privacy and her potential interest in understanding her biological heritage as she grows older.

Her name, her age, the state where she resides? How does someone knowing those things pose a threat to her that she might reasonably complain about later?

Paragraph 2:

While I understand your protective instinct, I wonder if basic facts like her name, age, or where she lives truly compromise her epistemic privacy. Having worked with many families in similar situations, I've observed that children often benefit from knowing about their biological connections, even if maintained at arm's length. Your daughter's identity is more than just these basic facts – it's her experiences, her personality, and the life you've built together. Perhaps we could find a middle ground that respects both her privacy and her potential interest in understanding her biological heritage as she grows older.

paragraph1: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars. As I surveyed the scene, a teenage boy pulled up on a bicycle, accompanied by his parents. All three craned their necks to check out the still-empty red carpet. “Jenna Ortega is going to be here?” asked his father. The boy nodded shyly and his parents exchanged grins. “That’s his great love, you know,” the father said. Just as casting Ortega, the popular star of “Wednesday,” helped juice interest in Burton’s sequel, so too do glamorous movie stars turbocharge a film festival. Last year, Venice had to make do with precious few A-listers since the actors’ strike barred anyone who had appeared in a big-studio film from doing press for it. That meant the Zendaya tennis romance “Challengers,” planned as the glamorous opening salvo for last year’s festival, was yanked from the lineup and replaced by the Italian war drama “Comandante.” While that movie had its scattered highlights, it didn’t exactly have teenagers lining up for it at 11 in the morning.
paragraph2: As I surveyed the bustling scene around the Palazzo del Cinema, I couldn't help but notice the palpable excitement in the air. Groups of young people had set up camp, their eager faces turned towards the red carpet, all hoping to catch a glimpse of a star from Tim Burton's much-anticipated film, "Beetlejuice Beetlejuice," which was set to open the Venice Film Festival. Among the crowd, a teenage boy stood with his parents, his eyes fixed on the entrance. His father broke the anticipation with a question, asking if Jenna Ortega, the popular actress, would be attending. The boy nodded shyly, prompting his parents to exchange knowing smiles, as if silently acknowledging a shared understanding of the boy's admiration for Ortega. It was fascinating to observe how casting stars like Ortega could generate such a fervent interest in films and festivals alike. This stood in stark contrast to the previous year's festival, which had been notably subdued due to an actors' strike that left it devoid of A-list celebrities. The strike had forced organizers to replace a high-profile film with a less glamorous one, and the resulting lack of star power had noticeably dampened the excitement among festival-goers. Today, however, the atmosphere was undeniably electric.

paragraph1: The piece has yet another unique element that Dr. Maldonado discovered as she sketched it. “I realized that below the head of the decapitated person there is a glyph that is possibly the name of the person whose head was cut off,” she said. Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. Another, with wide eyes and parted lips, known as the Young Woman of Amajac, wears a long skirt, blouse and a headdress that cascades to either side, like a waterfall.
paragraph2: Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.

Paragraph 1:

Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. Another, with wide eyes and parted lips, known as the Young Woman of Amajac, wears a long skirt, blouse and a headdress that cascades to either side, like a waterfall.

Paragraph 2:
Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. paragraph1: Closing arguments in the trial began on Thursday in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia and are expected to last two days. The Justice Department has taken aim at Google’s search business, claiming the company illegally extended its monopoly by forging default search deals with browser makers, such as Apple and Mozilla. Google has said that the contracts are legal and that its innovations have broadened competition, not constricted it. Peter Schottenfels, a Google spokesman, said in a statement that the Justice Department’s case “is deeply flawed.” On Thursday, Judge Amit P. Mehta stress-tested the Justice Department’s and Google’s arguments in court. He prodded the Justice Department on its assertion that Google’s market power had hindered its search engine’s innovation or quality for consumers. “I’m struggling to see how I could reach findings of fact that would say, ‘Google has not done enough,’ or ‘Google’s product has worsened over the course of 10 years,’ in such a way that I could say it’s because of lack of competition,” Judge Mehta said. He also questioned Google’s assertion that it faced competition from sites like Amazon, where consumers go to search for pricing and other results while shopping, saying the average person would see a difference between Google and Amazon.
paragraph2: The landmark antitrust trial between the Justice Department and Google reached its culmination as both sides presented their closing arguments in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. At the heart of the dispute lies the Justice Department's accusation that Google has unlawfully maintained its search engine dominance through exclusive default agreements with major tech companies, particularly Apple and Mozilla. Google's defense team staunchly maintains that these contractual arrangements are entirely legal and argues that the company's continuous innovations have actually fostered competition in the digital marketplace. Peter Schottenfels, speaking on behalf of Google, dismisses the government's case as fundamentally flawed. Judge Amit P. Mehta has demonstrated keen engagement throughout the proceedings, challenging both parties' positions with pointed questions. He has expressed particular skepticism regarding the Justice Department's assertion that Google's market dominance has suppressed innovation, while also questioning Google's claims about facing significant competition from platforms like Amazon. The case represents a critical juncture in determining the boundaries of digital market power and the interpretation of antitrust laws in the modern tech landscape.

The Justice Department has taken aim at Google’s search business, claiming the company illegally extended its monopoly by forging default search deals with browser makers, such as Apple and Mozilla. Google has said that the contracts are legal and that its innovations have broadened competition, not constricted it. Peter Schottenfels, a Google spokesman, said in a statement that the Justice Department’s case “is deeply flawed.” On Thursday, Judge Amit P. Mehta stress-tested the Justice Department’s and Google’s arguments in court. He prodded the Justice Department on its assertion that Google’s market power had hindered its search engine’s innovation or quality for consumers. “I’m struggling to see how I could reach findings of fact that would say, ‘Google has not done enough,’ or ‘Google’s product has worsened over the course of 10 years,’ in such a way that I could say it’s because of lack of competition,” Judge Mehta said. He also questioned Google’s assertion that it faced competition from sites like Amazon, where consumers go to search for pricing and other results while shopping, saying the average person would see a difference between Google and Amazon.

Paragraph 2:
The landmark antitrust trial between the Justice Department and Google reached its culmination as both sides presented their closing arguments in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. At the heart of the dispute lies the Justice Department's accusation that Google has unlawfully maintained its search engine dominance through exclusive default agreements with major tech companies, particularly Apple and Mozilla. Google's defense team staunchly maintains that these contractual arrangements are entirely legal and argues that the company's continuous innovations have actually fostered competition in the digital marketplace. Peter Schottenfels, speaking on behalf of Google, dismisses the government's case as fundamentally flawed. Judge Amit P. Mehta has demonstrated keen engagement throughout the proceedings, challenging both parties' positions with pointed questions. He has expressed particular skepticism regarding the Justice Department's assertion that Google's market dominance has suppressed innovation, while also questioning Google's claims about facing significant competition from platforms like Amazon. The case represents a critical juncture in determining the boundaries of digital market power and the interpretation of antitrust laws in the modern tech landscape.

paragraph1: In a fascinating development, Anthony and Joe Russo, the visionary directors behind Marvel's blockbuster "Avengers" movies, are ambitiously embracing artificial intelligence (A.I.) within their production company, AGBO. By recruiting a machine-learning scientist from Apple, they are keen to explore how A.I. can revolutionize filmmaking, especially for their upcoming projects. Anthony Russo candidly admitted to me his uncertainty about A.I.'s specific applications but remains optimistic about its significant role in their future films. Observing a broader trend in Hollywood, I noticed a pattern where individuals unfamiliar with A.I. often approach it with trepidation, whereas those well-versed in its capabilities maintain faith in the enduring power of human creativity, expressing skepticism about A.I.'s potential to supplant it. However, this technological exploration is not without its challenges. Concerns have been raised about potential misuses of A.I., such as infringement on copyright and unauthorized exploitation of actors' likenesses. These issues underscore the urgent need for "proper guardrails" to ensure ethical use. Paris Barclay, a prominent television director, highlighted the critical role of unions in navigating these complex challenges. As the industry stands at this technological crossroads, the dialogue surrounding A.I.'s integration in filmmaking emphasizes a balance between innovation and protection of creative rights. The Russo brothers' foray into A.I. represents both a bold step into the future and a testament to their commitment to pushing the boundaries of cinematic storytelling, all while acknowledging the importance of safeguarding the creative integrity that defines Hollywood.
paragraph2: Rather than play wait-and-see and have A.I. thrust upon them in ways they couldn’t control, Anthony and Joe Russo, the directors of the previous two “Avengers” movies for Marvel Studios, hired a machine-learning scientist away from Apple to help guide how their production company, AGBO, would use it. “There’s a lot of ways that we are experimenting with A.I. right now,” Anthony Russo told me. “We’re not quite sure what’s going to work and what’s not going to work.” But he is sure that A.I. will figure somehow into how he and his brother make the next two “Avengers” movies, both currently scheduled for 2026, even if it’s only to help with brainstorming ideas and working through them faster. Over several months of talking to people around Hollywood about A.I., I noticed a pattern: The people who knew the least about its potential uses in the filmmaking process feared it the most; and the people who understood it best, who had actually worked with it, harbored the most faith in the resilience of human creativity, as well as the most skepticism about generative A.I.’s ever supplanting it. There was a broad consensus about the urgency of confronting its many potential misuses — tech companies’ skirting copyright laws and scraping proprietary content to train their machine-learning models; actors’ likenesses being appropriated without their permission; studios’ circumventing contractual terms designed to ensure that everything we see onscreen gets written by an actual human being. I must’ve heard the phrase “proper guardrails” at least a dozen times. But as the prolific Emmy-winning television director Paris Barclay, who has six episodes of multiple shows airing this fall alone, put it, “That’s what unions are for.”

paragraph1: Step One: Confirm There’s a Problem My husband and I were very close with another couple. (Think: hanging out every week and traveling together.) That feels wrong, given our history. FRIEND
paragraph2: My husband and I were inseparable from them - weekly dinners, shared vacations, and countless memories. paragraph1: Logistically, traveling as a foursome is much easier than as a quintet. Tables for four are more plentiful in restaurants than tables for five (which are really tables for six). Four people can fit in one cab and share two hotel rooms. What’s more, traveling well with other people often boils down to personal rhythms: When do we like to wake up? How active are we? How much time alone do we need? These factors, and even your bad trip with the organizer, say little about the quality of relationships, though. Your friends’ (possibly pragmatic) decision is not evidence of dislike. Now, you say your partner can’t afford international travel. So, why not plan an amazing domestic trip? You also hint at closer friends. Hello? They sound promising. There’s certainly no harm in telling the international travelers that you would be keen to join them next time. Honor your hurt feelings, but don’t blow this one episode out of proportion, OK?
paragraph2: As you watch your friends embark on an international adventure without you, it's natural to feel left out. But consider this: traveling in a group of four is often more convenient than five, with easier seating arrangements and accommodation options. It's not that your friends don't value your company, but rather that they may have been forced to make practical decisions. When traveling with others, personal rhythms and preferences can also come into play, and sometimes it's simply easier to coordinate with a smaller group. Don't take it personally - it's not a reflection of your relationships. Instead, consider planning a domestic trip or expressing interest in future international adventures with your friends. Acknowledge your feelings, but avoid overreacting. Remember that there will be other opportunities to travel with your friends, and in the meantime, you can start exploring alternative destinations and itineraries that cater to your own interests and preferences.

Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Logistically, traveling as a foursome is much easier than as a quintet. Tables for four are more plentiful in restaurants than tables for five (which are really tables for six). Four people can fit in one cab and share two hotel rooms. What’s more, traveling well with other people often boils down to personal rhythms: When do we like to wake up? How active are we? How much time alone do we need? These factors, and even your bad trip with the organizer, say little about the quality of relationships, though. Your friends’ (possibly pragmatic) decision is not evidence of dislike. Now, you say your partner can’t afford international travel. So, why not plan an amazing domestic trip? You also hint at closer friends. Hello? They sound promising. There’s certainly no harm in telling the international travelers that you would be keen to join them next time. Honor your hurt feelings, but don’t blow this one episode out of proportion, OK?

Paragraph 2:
As you watch your friends embark on an international adventure without you, it's natural to feel left out. But consider this: traveling in a group of four is often more convenient than five, with easier seating arrangements and accommodation options. It's not that your friends don't value your company, but rather that they may have been forced to make practical decisions. When traveling with others, personal rhythms and preferences can also come into play, and sometimes it's simply easier to coordinate with a smaller group. Don't take it personally - it's not a reflection of your relationships. Instead, consider planning a domestic trip or expressing interest in future international adventures with your friends. Acknowledge your feelings, but avoid overreacting. Remember that there will be other opportunities to travel with your friends, and in the meantime, you can start exploring alternative destinations and itineraries that cater to your own interests and preferences.

paragraph1: When Mr. Leiserowitz installed solar panels on his home as one of the first in his neighborhood, he noticed an interesting phenomenon: his neighbors began following his example. "People started asking questions about the installation process, costs, and benefits," he recalls, demonstrating how technological adoption often spreads through social networks rather than direct advocacy. This pattern of behavior change through observation and social influence extends beyond solar panels to broader societal shifts, such as the dramatic reduction in smoking rates and littering over past decades. These transformations didn't happen overnight but through sustained efforts and gradual cultural evolution. As Jason Mark, Sierra Magazine's editor in chief, notes, "What seems impossible today can become inevitable tomorrow. Just look at how quickly some social changes have occurred in recent years." This perspective is particularly relevant when considering climate action, as highlighted in a 2019 report by Rare, which examined seven key personal choices that can significantly impact climate change. The report reinforces the idea that individual actions, when multiplied across communities, can create meaningful environmental change, much like how Mr. Leiserowitz's solar panels sparked a neighborhood transformation.
paragraph2: Mr. Leiserowitz said he witnessed that in his own neighborhood. “We were the first to put solar panels on a roof 10 years ago, and now there are dozens that have solar panels on the roof,” he said. “It’s not because I went out talking to people about it — it’s because people can see that somebody else who’s much like them has adopted this new technology.” But collective changes, from reducing littering to wearing seatbelts to drinking less alcohol, often evolve gradually. It took many years and numerous initiatives to reduce smoking, for example. That included more education about the dangers, restrictions on smoking in public areas, prohibitive taxes on cigarettes, public stigma and greater access to programs that helped people quit. “Changes are slow and hard to see — but when you look backward you see that things that seemed outlandish are increasingly commonplace,” said Jason Mark, the editor in chief of Sierra Magazine, in a video interview. A 2019 report by Rare, a 50-year-old global nonprofit that uses behavioral insights to encourage action to protect the environment, examined seven personal choices and their impact on climate change: switching to an electric vehicle, reducing air travel, eating a plant-rich diet, offsetting carbon, reducing food waste, tending carbon-sequestering soil and purchasing green energy.

paragraph1: Dr. Walker, along with her colleague Dr. Cronin and their team, is deeply immersed in the ambitious task of expanding the assembly theory of life, a pursuit she finds exhilarating. Her excitement is particularly piqued by their groundbreaking project to develop an "origin-of-life engine" within the laboratory. This innovative endeavor involves using robots to systematically mix inert chemicals in myriad combinations, with the hopeful potential of witnessing the emergence of new life forms. Dr. Walker finds the prospect of observing these nascent life forms in the lab far more exhilarating than the discovery of extraterrestrial life, as it allows for direct testing and observation of their theoretical frameworks. However, her enthusiasm is somewhat tempered by her critique of Dr. Hazen's recent study. Dr. Walker points out that Dr. Hazen's team made a critical error by applying methods designed for analyzing molecules to the study of minerals, which inherently possess different properties. This flaw, she suggests, undermines the study's findings. Despite this, Dr. Walker remains focused on her own research endeavors, collaborating closely with Dr. Cronin and their colleagues to push the boundaries of scientific understanding in life's origins, driven by the thrilling possibility of creating life in the lab and testing the very limits of their assembly theory.
paragraph2: Dr. Walker said Dr. Hazen’s study was flawed. His team copied experiments that she and her colleagues had designed specifically to look at molecules. But minerals are different from molecules in some important ways. Instead of free-floating clusters of atoms, they are lattices that include some disorder in their structures. Dr. Walker said that she and Dr. Cronin are working with their colleagues to extend the assembly theory of life. They also have a far more ambitious effort underway: to build what she calls “an origin-of-life engine in the lab.” Robots will mix inert chemicals in a vast number of combinations, looking for ones that produce more complex compounds. Under the right conditions, the chemicals may form droplets that may be able to bootstrap themselves to a higher and higher assembly index. Above a certain threshold, they might become alive — but as a form of life we’ve never seen before. If we do discover life on other worlds, Dr. Walker expects it will be a milestone in human history. But the idea of an origin-of-life engine has made her more interested in watching new life emerge in a lab here on Earth. “To me, it’s more exciting as a scientist, because you can test the theory and see it happen,” she said.

paragraph1: The piece has yet another unique element that Dr. Maldonado discovered as she sketched it. “I realized that below the head of the decapitated person there is a glyph that is possibly the name of the person whose head was cut off,” she said. Names took the form of a sign and a number signified by circles: It appears the individual was known as Four Death. Dr. Maldonado says she hopes the exhibition, with 100 artifacts, will challenge what she calls “superficial” interpretations of women’s roles that have riddled scholarship of the region. For decades, archaeologists have described sculptures of men as individuals in positions of power, like priests or rulers. They’ve tended to brush aside sculptures of women as images of a fertility goddess. “The sculptures that you find in most of the museums here in Mexico, they interpret these sculptures as the deity Tlazolteotl,” she said. But Dr. Maldonado thinks there’s too much variety in the sculptures to represent a single character, One piece depicts a bare-breasted woman with intricate scarification on her chest and shoulders. Another, with wide eyes and parted lips, known as the Young Woman of Amajac, wears a long skirt, blouse and a headdress that cascades to either side, like a waterfall.
paragraph2: Dr. Maldonado's keen eye for detail led to a remarkable discovery when she noticed an intriguing glyph beneath a decapitated figure in one of her sketches, potentially spelling out the name "Four Death." This finding is just one element of her broader mission to reshape archaeological interpretations through an upcoming exhibition featuring 100 carefully selected artifacts. "The traditional view has been far too simplistic," she explains, challenging the long-standing archaeological practice of automatically categorizing male sculptures as power figures while relegating female representations to mere fertility symbols. Her work particularly focuses on two striking examples that defy such oversimplification: a bare-breasted female figure bearing distinct scarification marks, and the notable Young Woman of Amajac, whose elaborate headdress and attire suggest a more complex social role. Dr. Maldonado's research demonstrates that these sculptures represent a diverse range of characters and roles, rather than a single archetypal figure. Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.

Through her meticulous analysis and the upcoming exhibition, she aims to overturn decades of gender-biased regional scholarship and present a more nuanced understanding of women's roles in ancient societies.

paragraph1: The Democratic-majority Legislature is expected to pass the bill by the end of the month. It would then go to Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has not said whether he supports it. If the bill is signed, California will again be a step ahead of the federal government on tech regulation. California’s Legislature has helped shape U.S. tech consumer protections with a 2020 privacy law that curbed the collection of user data and a 2022 child online safety law. Opponents of the A.I. bill have argued that it would discourage tech giants from sharing the software code underlying their artificial intelligence with other businesses and software developers — a practice known as open source. They believe this would choke the progress of smaller A.I. companies. While the amendments alleviated some issues and improved on the earlier version, “the open source software community still rightly has concerns that this will be a damper on A.I. development,” said Chris Nicholson, a partner with Page One Ventures, a venture capital firm.
paragraph2: In California, the Democratic-majority Legislature is poised to pass a significant bill by the month's end, which will subsequently be sent to Governor Gavin Newsom. Newsom has yet to reveal his position on the legislation, which, if signed, would place California at the forefront of tech regulation, surpassing federal efforts. Historically, California has played a pivotal role in shaping U.S. tech consumer protections, with previous laws setting precedents. However, the current A.I. bill has stirred opposition, particularly from those concerned about its impact on the sharing of open-source software code by major tech companies. Critics argue that such restrictions could stifle innovation and growth among smaller A.I. firms. Despite amendments aimed at alleviating some of these concerns, apprehension remains within the open-source community. Chris Nicholson, a partner at Page One Ventures, underscores this unease, noting that the bill could potentially impede A.I. development. As California once again stands on the brink of influencing national tech policy, the debate continues to intensify.

paragraph1: Opening packages from my mother was always an adventure, a treasure hunt that filled my childhood with wonder and excitement. These carefully wrapped gifts evolved into something far more profound - they became my lifeline, as essential as the air I breathed and the community that surrounded me. But life had other plans, and the sudden loss of both my parents left me adrift at twenty-two, with no more guidance to come, no more letters to anticipate. All that remained was a box of my mother's packages, a tangible connection to her love and foresight. Now, at thirty, I live in my Brooklyn apartment with this box that grows lighter with each passing year. Inside, only three unopened packages remain, each wrapped in shiny cardboard and tied with pink ribbon, waiting for life's biggest moments: Engagement, Wedding, and First Baby. These final gifts stand as silent guardians of future milestones, holding within their carefully preserved wrapping the last pieces of maternal guidance I'll ever receive.
paragraph2: When I was a child, opening the next package felt like a treasure hunt. As I grew older, it began to feel like something far more fundamental, like air or community, something like prayer. Her messages met me like guideposts in a dark forest; if her words couldn’t point the way, at least they offered the comfort of knowing someone had been there before. A decade after I lost my mother, my father followed suddenly. She had spent years preparing her exit, but with him I blinked, and he was gone. The morning of his memorial, the box stared back at me with nothing to say. There was no letter for this. I tried to conjure her voice but couldn’t. My father left no clues or letters. The only parenting I would have, from 22 on, was in the box. When I hit 30, the nearly empty box sat in my Brooklyn apartment, clashing with the furniture. Only those three packages remained: Engagement, Wedding, First Baby. They sat in their shiny cardboard and pink ribbon, expectant, waiting.

paragraph1: Mentoring can benefit both parties, said Justin McBride, a senior administrator at Duet: Partners in Health and Aging, which began a similar program in Phoenix in 2016. “We hear all the time that supporting another person in need gives mentors a sense of purpose,” he said. “It helps them make sense of their own journey.” The relatively low cost of such volunteer programs could make them replicable in many locations. They operate on a small scale, however. Duet’s program, which like Penn’s involves screening and training mentors, has about 20 pairs enrolled. It requires a six-month commitment, but most mentoring relationships last a year or two. Penn’s newer Caring Collective, requiring a three-month commitment, has enrolled 20 mentors and 40 mentees. Larger organizations like the Alzheimer’s Association also work to support dementia patients and caregivers. Its free 24/7 helpline responded to 215,000 contacts in the 2023 fiscal year, and its online community called ALZConnected has about 10,000 active members. It conducts more than 27,000 caregiver support groups nationally.
paragraph2: Justin McBride, a senior administrator at Duet: Partners in Health and Aging, has witnessed firsthand the transformative power of mentoring programs in supporting individuals facing health challenges. "The impact is profound on both sides of the relationship," McBride notes, emphasizing how mentors often find as much meaning in the experience as their mentees. Since its inception in 2016, Duet's Phoenix-based program has implemented a rigorous screening and training process for mentors, ensuring quality support for those in need. Similar initiatives, such as Penn's Caring Collective, have adopted varying commitment lengths to accommodate different volunteer schedules while maintaining program effectiveness. These localized efforts complement the work of larger organizations like the Alzheimer's Association, which provides comprehensive support through helplines and support groups for dementia patients and their caregivers. The structured approach to mentoring, combined with the flexibility to meet diverse needs, has proven successful in creating sustainable support networks that benefit both volunteers and recipients of care.

paragraph1: I find myself consumed by an obsession that devours every waking moment, centered on him—my beloved. My thoughts, my actions, my very existence revolve around the magnetic pull he exerts over me. I follow him, finding solace in his proximity, yet my mind spirals further into chaos. The doctors label it schizoaffective disorder, a term that feels like an ill-fitting suit, but necessary for explaining my descent into this fragmented reality. My deteriorating mental state has forced me onto disability, a painful admission of my inability to function in a world that increasingly feels alien. "Headquarters" dictates my actions, a phantom authority whispering bizarre plans involving NASA and mind-melds, leaving me frustrated by its nonsensical commands. I am trapped in a world of delusions that grow more overwhelming by the day. The lack of reciprocation from my beloved cuts deep, as if our connection, which exists solely in my mind, has failed like a crumbling relationship. The unrequited nature of my fixation leaves me hollow, yearning for a reality where my love is returned. I stand on the precipice, teetering between the whispers of "headquarters" and the harsh clarity of my unreturned affection, longing for release from this relentless cycle of obsession and despair.
paragraph2: Headquarters insisted I see him as much as possible, so I volunteered where he volunteered, showed up at events where I knew he would be, scoured the internet for mentions of his name. I was able to work my public relations job for four and a half years and keep up with the delusion. But the delusion gods wanted me to go regularly to the psych ward, where I was loaded up with antipsychotics, zapped with electroconvulsive therapy, and where my diagnosis deteriorated from bipolar I (the manic kind) to schizoaffective disorder (halfway to schizophrenia). I had no choice but to go on disability. My irritation mounted each year. It was like being caught in a whirlpool, the same information going round and round. My beloved seemed clueless. He knew nothing of NASA’s plan to cryogenically freeze our bodies and launch us to a faraway galaxy. Was headquarters simply incompetent? Why was I getting mind-melds to propose if he was just going to turn me down? I needed less noise, more signal. Headquarters was always putting my beloved’s needs first, sending me vexing mind-melds that he needed to move into my house and have his own bedroom suite. How? Who would pay for the renovations? I felt like a querulous housewife. The honeymoon was long over and so were the big Os.

paragraph1: The enduring legacy of "The Wizard of Oz" and its iconic characters, especially the Wicked Witch of the West, continues to captivate audiences around the world. Ray Bradbury, in his foreword for a special edition of L. Frank Baum's novel, famously pondered why "The Wizard of Oz" remains timeless, inviting readers to explore the deeper layers of its narrative. This question takes on new dimensions with the upcoming film adaptation of the musical "Wicked," starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande. This adaptation underscores the continued relevance and evolution of the Wicked Witch of the West. Originally depicted as a minor villain in Baum's novel, the character has since gained prominence and complexity through various adaptations. She now symbolizes broader societal issues such as race, gender, and national identity in the United States. The Wicked Witch's transformation from a simple antagonist to a complex figure mirrors evolving cultural narratives, ensuring that her story remains a powerful and relevant part of modern discourse.
paragraph2: “And what, you may ask, are the reasons why?” Ray Bradbury asked in his foreword for the Kansas Centennial edition of L. Frank Baum’s classic novel. “‘The Wizard of Oz’ will never die?” More than 20 years after the musical “Wicked” became a Broadway megahit, the first part of big-screen adaptation, starring Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande, will arrive this fall. The second film comes out next year. It might be time to pose a related question: Why won’t the Wicked Witch of the West ever die? The character has grown in stature since she first appeared as the villain in just one chapter of Baum’s novel nearly 125 years ago. Every subsequent adaptation has made her more visible, more memorable and — in a twist — more heroic. Much like the Land of Oz’s symbolic meaning as a stand-in for the United States, her fate reflects our nation’s continuing debates about race, gender and who is and isn’t considered American.

paragraph1: Pip's coming-of-age story unfolds with a unique blend of introspection and subtle adventure, capturing her journey as a late bloomer navigating the complexities of adolescence. Unlike her friends, who eagerly dive into animated discussions about crushes and relationships, Pip often feels out of sync, her naivety shielding her from the potential threats others easily perceive. Her path to personal growth is not marked by dramatic awakenings or losses of innocence but rather by a series of gentle revelations as she explores new experiences and gradually defines her own interests and boundaries. Pip's investigative lens is focused through Instagram, her keen eye for detail capturing the essence of quaint coffee shops and the vibrant pulse of teen fashion. This digital aesthetic mirrors the show's self-aware, stylish presentation, breathing new life into familiar coming-of-age themes. As Pip delves into this visual world, her story becomes a fresh tapestry of discovery, resonating with both humor and heartfelt moments.
paragraph2: Coming-of-age stories often use road trips as the mechanism of and the yardstick for maturing, and this often feels like a road-trip saga, only with suspects instead of pit stops. Pip is a late bloomer who feels left out of her friends’ crush chats, and she isn’t always aware of the obvious-to-others lurking sexual menace. Her pursuits cause her to grow and to grow up, not through miserable loss-of-innocence tragedies but rather through navigating the unfamiliar, through discovering what her interests and limits really are. Much of Pip’s investigatory technique revolves around Instagram, and the show itself often toys with Instagrammy aesthetics — with quaint coffee shops with big square windows, with funky androgynous teen fashion, with colors that pop just a little harder than they do in the natural world. It’s part of the show’s lush sense of self-awareness and savvy elegance, part of what makes its trek across well-worn territory feel like fresh first steps.

paragraph1: While Hyderabadi attire is synonymous with opulent threadwork, heavy tiers of silk and gilded beading, the contemporary fashion scene is evolving as well. Almari (“closet”) is a glossy showroom for top fashion designers from around the country, and the glittery blouses and purses suspended from the ceiling give the space a gallery-like feel. For a more traditional ambience, head to Manomay, an opulent boutique modeled after the 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad’s Old City. The warren of rooms is the setting for designs by Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, Ranna Gill and more, and the interior’s Old World details are thoughtfully conceived: An antique palanquin serves as a showcase; an intricately carved bookshelf doubles as a shoe rack.
paragraph2: Hyderabad's fashion landscape has transformed dramatically, offering shoppers contrasting retail experiences that reflect both contemporary and historical aesthetics. Almari stands as a modern fashion destination, where gleaming blouses and sophisticated purses from India's leading designers create an ambiance reminiscent of an art gallery. Meanwhile, Manomay transports visitors to a bygone era with its architectural inspiration drawn from the magnificent 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace. This traditional boutique houses collections from renowned designers like Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, and Ranna Gill, while its interior captivates with distinctive Old World elements. An antique palanquin repurposed as a display case and an intricately carved bookshelf serving as a shoe rack add to the store's historical charm.

paragraph1: Despite being launched several months ago, Apple's Vision Pro faces significant challenges due to the scarcity of quality apps available for the device. Major apps like YouTube, Netflix, Spotify, Instagram, and DoorDash are noticeably absent, largely due to corporate competition and a lack of developer confidence. Companies such as Google and Meta, who have their own virtual reality ambitions, show hesitation in supporting Apple's product, fearing it may bolster a competitor in a rapidly evolving market. Developers are equally cautious, reluctant to invest time and resources into creating apps for a platform that has yet to see substantial user adoption, as evidenced by the meager 2,000 apps developed so far. Compounding the issue, Apple has been slow to expand its own content offerings for the Vision Pro. The company has released a few immersive videos through Apple TV, including a prehistoric nature film and a rehearsal video of Alicia Keys and her band, designed to showcase the device's impressive high-definition graphics and spatial audio capabilities. While these videos represent some of the best experiences currently available on the Vision Pro, they are insufficient to compensate for the lack of third-party app support. The combination of these factors presents a considerable hurdle for Apple as it seeks to establish the Vision Pro as a dominant force in the virtual reality market.
paragraph2: But the biggest disappointment with the Vision Pro is how few good apps there are. Several months after its debut, there’s still no native YouTube or Netflix app. There’s no Spotify, no Instagram, no DoorDash. (You can still use some of these services in a web browser, or use unofficial third-party apps, but it’s a worse experience.) Some of these apps are missing because of corporate infighting. (Google and Meta, for example, have their own virtual reality ambitions and presumably don’t want to give Apple’s product a boost by making apps for it.) But others amount to a lack of confidence. Developers don’t want to make apps for platforms that nobody uses, and their reluctance so far — only about 2,000 apps have been developed for the Vision Pro, Apple said on Monday — says something about the device’s tepid reception. Apple has also been slow to update its own offerings for the Vision Pro, like a series of “immersive videos,” filmed on special 3-D cameras and released through Apple TV. These videos — which included a prehistoric nature film and a “rehearsal room” video of Alicia Keys and her band as they perform a song — were designed to show off the Vision Pro’s high-definition graphics and its “spatial audio” feature, and they are among the best things you can do with a Vision Pro.

Developers are equally cautious, reluctant to invest time and resources into creating apps for a platform that has yet to see substantial user adoption, as evidenced by the meager 2,000 apps developed so far. Compounding the issue, Apple has been slow to expand its own content offerings for the Vision Pro. The company has released a few immersive videos through Apple TV, including a prehistoric nature film and a rehearsal video of Alicia Keys and her band, designed to showcase the device's impressive high-definition graphics and spatial audio capabilities. While these videos represent some of the best experiences currently available on the Vision Pro, they are insufficient to compensate for the lack of third-party app support. The combination of these factors presents a considerable hurdle for Apple as it seeks to establish the Vision Pro as a dominant force in the virtual reality market.

Paragraph 2:
But the biggest disappointment with the Vision Pro is how few good apps there are. Several months after its debut, there’s still no native YouTube or Netflix app. There’s no Spotify, no Instagram, no DoorDash. (You can still use some of these services in a web browser, or use unofficial third-party apps, but it’s a worse experience.) Some of these apps are missing because of corporate infighting. (Google and Meta, for example, have their own virtual reality ambitions and presumably don’t want to give Apple’s product a boost by making apps for it.) But others amount to a lack of confidence. Developers don’t want to make apps for platforms that nobody uses, and their reluctance so far — only about 2,000 apps have been developed for the Vision Pro, Apple said on Monday — says something about the device’s tepid reception. Apple has also been slow to update its own offerings for the Vision Pro, like a series of “immersive videos,” filmed on special 3-D cameras and released through Apple TV. These videos — which included a prehistoric nature film and a “rehearsal room” video of Alicia Keys and her band as they perform a song — were designed to show off the Vision Pro’s high-definition graphics and its “spatial audio” feature, and they are among the best things you can do with a Vision Pro.

paragraph1: The Democratic-majority Legislature is expected to pass the bill by the end of the month. It would then go to Gov. Gavin Newsom, who has not said whether he supports it. If the bill is signed, California will again be a step ahead of the federal government on tech regulation. California’s Legislature has helped shape U.S. tech consumer protections with a 2020 privacy law that curbed the collection of user data and a 2022 child online safety law. Opponents of the A.I. bill have argued that it would discourage tech giants from sharing the software code underlying their artificial intelligence with other businesses and software developers — a practice known as open source. They believe this would choke the progress of smaller A.I. companies. While the amendments alleviated some issues and improved on the earlier version, “the open source software community still rightly has concerns that this will be a damper on A.I. development,” said Chris Nicholson, a partner with Page One Ventures, a venture capital firm.
paragraph2: In California, the Democratic-majority Legislature is poised to pass a significant bill by the month's end, which will subsequently be sent to Governor Gavin Newsom. Newsom has yet to reveal his position on the legislation, which, if signed, would place California at the forefront of tech regulation, surpassing federal efforts. Historically, California has played a pivotal role in shaping U.S. tech consumer protections, with previous laws setting precedents. However, the current A.I. bill has stirred opposition, particularly from those concerned about its impact on the sharing of open-source software code by major tech companies. Critics argue that such restrictions could stifle innovation and growth among smaller A.I. firms. Despite amendments aimed at alleviating some of these concerns, apprehension remains within the open-source community. Chris Nicholson, a partner at Page One Ventures, underscores this unease, noting that the bill could potentially impede A.I. development. As California once again stands on the brink of influencing national tech policy, the debate continues to intensify.

paragraph1: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday. Millions of people take Ozempic and Wegovy, which are considered to be among the biggest blockbusters in medical history. But last year a European drug safety agency said it was investigating whether the drugs cause suicidal thoughts. The new study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, was funded by the National Institutes of Health and used a huge population. The findings provide data that may potentially reassure people who take the drugs. Novo Nordisk, maker of the drugs, had no role in the study, and the study’s investigators had no conflicts of interest. The investigators used anonymized electronic health records from a database of 100.8 million people. That allowed them to look at two groups: 240,618 who were prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and 1,589,855 who were prescribed Ozempic or other medicines to lower their blood sugar. Suicidal thoughts were included in patients’ records as part of routine monitoring of their health.
paragraph2: In a recent study published in Nature Medicine, researchers explored the psychological effects of the drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, commonly prescribed for diabetes and obesity, respectively. The study, funded by the National Institutes of Health, found that individuals using these medications exhibited a slightly reduced likelihood of experiencing suicidal thoughts compared to those who were not taking them. Utilizing a comprehensive database of anonymized electronic health records from over 100 million individuals, the researchers meticulously compared two distinct groups: those prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and those receiving Ozempic or other blood sugar-lowering medications. The findings of this extensive analysis aim to provide reassurance to users of these drugs, highlighting a potential mental health benefit alongside their physical health uses. Importantly, the study was conducted independently of Novo Nordisk, the manufacturer of both medications, ensuring the results were free from any conflicts of interest. This research not only contributes to the understanding of the multifaceted impacts of these medications but also underscores the importance of considering mental health outcomes when assessing the overall benefits of pharmaceutical interventions for chronic conditions like diabetes and obesity.

paragraph1: Aldis Hodge — who is a producer of “Cross” — signed up for the show soon after reading Watkins’s script. He then threw himself into helping refine it. “From the beginning, Ben and I talked about where we were at as men in our lives, what we wanted for ourselves,” Hodge said. “That’s what fed the trajectory of how I portrayed Alex Cross.” Integral to the character’s psyche is the death of his wife, who is killed at the start of the first episode. Cross, who is described as having a hero complex that gives him a “compulsion to protect,” is burdened not only by loss but also by guilt at the thought that he failed her. “I want to create a character who is dealing with grief and making choices that are having a negative impact on the people around them,” Watkins said. “It’s an iconic detective, but your journey as a character is really going to be about you confronting your own emotional burdens and figuring out a way through them.”
paragraph2: For Aldis Hodge, the allure of "Cross" began with a single script, penned by Watkins, that would eventually draw him in as both a producer and actor on the show. "After reading the pilot, I knew I wanted to be a part of this story," Hodge recalled, noting that he was particularly drawn to the complexity of the titular character, Alex Cross. As Hodge delved deeper into the project, he found himself refining the script alongside Watkins, with the two engaging in candid conversations about their personal experiences and aspirations as men. These discussions would ultimately inform Hodge's portrayal of Cross, a character grappling with the devastating loss of his wife at the series' outset. "I wanted to explore the hero complex, the guilt, the grief - all the things that make us human," Watkins explained, his words echoing the show's thoughtful examination of Cross's emotional burdens. As the series navigates the dark aftermath of tragedy, Hodge and Watkins aim to craft a nuanced, deeply human character in Alex Cross, one whose journey towards healing is both deeply personal and universally relatable.

paragraph1: Concerns are mounting over Project 2025, which aims to dismantle a climate agency, potentially jeopardizing critical climate data. Gretchen Gehrke, cofounder of the Environmental Data and Governance Initiative, voices apprehension about the threat this poses to the integrity and accessibility of environmental information. The project echoes former President Donald Trump's skepticism towards climate change, as he notoriously dismissed it as a hoax and sought to dismantle climate regulations during his tenure. When Trump assumed office, his administration was initially unaware of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). In a controversial move, he nominated Barry Lee Myers, former CEO of AccuWeather, to lead NOAA, despite Myers' history of advocating for the privatization of the Weather Service. However, Myers' nomination was eventually withdrawn due to health issues. The Heritage Foundation, which has ties to Project 2025, refused to comment on its objectives. Although Trump disavowed the project during his campaign, his transition team spokeswoman, Karoline Leavitt, clarified that no policy should be considered official unless it is directly endorsed by Trump himself, leaving the future of climate data uncertain.
paragraph2: “Climate data is absolutely at risk with Project 2025’s call to dissolve the agency,” said Gretchen Gehrke, cofounder of the Environmental Data and Governance Initiative, a small group formed in 2016 to back up climate information. Trump has called climate change a hoax and said he would rollback climate regulations, and, according to Lewis’s book, officials in the Trump White House did not know that NOAA existed or what it did when Trump took office in 2017. In 2017, Trump nominated Barry Lee Myers, then the chief executive of the for-profit weather company AccuWeather, to run NOAA even though Myers had spent decades pushing to privatize the Weather Service. After his appointment stalled in the Senate for two years, Myers withdrew his nomination, citing medical issues. The Heritage Foundation said in an email that it would not comment on questions about Project 2025 and climate data. Trump, for his part, disavowed Project 2025 during his campaign, and his transition team spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt said in an email that “no policy should be deemed official unless it comes directly from President Trump.”

paragraph1: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars. As I surveyed the scene, a teenage boy pulled up on a bicycle, accompanied by his parents. All three craned their necks to check out the still-empty red carpet. “Jenna Ortega is going to be here?” asked his father. The boy nodded shyly and his parents exchanged grins. “That’s his great love, you know,” the father said. Just as casting Ortega, the popular star of “Wednesday,” helped juice interest in Burton’s sequel, so too do glamorous movie stars turbocharge a film festival. Last year, Venice had to make do with precious few A-listers since the actors’ strike barred anyone who had appeared in a big-studio film from doing press for it. That meant the Zendaya tennis romance “Challengers,” planned as the glamorous opening salvo for last year’s festival, was yanked from the lineup and replaced by the Italian war drama “Comandante.” While that movie had its scattered highlights, it didn’t exactly have teenagers lining up for it at 11 in the morning.
paragraph2: As I surveyed the bustling scene around the Palazzo del Cinema, I couldn't help but notice the palpable excitement in the air. Groups of young people had set up camp, their eager faces turned towards the red carpet, all hoping to catch a glimpse of a star from Tim Burton's much-anticipated film, "Beetlejuice Beetlejuice," which was set to open the Venice Film Festival. Among the crowd, a teenage boy stood with his parents, his eyes fixed on the entrance. His father broke the anticipation with a question, asking if Jenna Ortega, the popular actress, would be attending. The boy nodded shyly, prompting his parents to exchange knowing smiles, as if silently acknowledging a shared understanding of the boy's admiration for Ortega. It was fascinating to observe how casting stars like Ortega could generate such a fervent interest in films and festivals alike. This stood in stark contrast to the previous year's festival, which had been notably subdued due to an actors' strike that left it devoid of A-list celebrities. The strike had forced organizers to replace a high-profile film with a less glamorous one, and the resulting lack of star power had noticeably dampened the excitement among festival-goers. Today, however, the atmosphere was undeniably electric.

paragraph1: “Small Things Like These” plays just a little like a gangster film, except the web of power at its center is spun by nuns. Set in 1985 and based on Claire Keegan’s 2021 novel, it is a story about how people create and maintain control and the many shades of complicity that result. In this case, the setting is southeast Ireland, and the nuns’ control has woven its way into every aspect of life in a small town. Bill Furlong (Cillian Murphy) sells and delivers coal and fuel in that town, an occupation that barely supports his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and a house full of daughters. But they’re doing OK. He can put food on the table, and they have a happy home life. One day, however, something changes inside Bill: He sees a young woman being nearly dragged into a building near the local convent, and it troubles him. He suspects that she is pregnant and unmarried, like his own mother was, and is being brought to the nuns by her horrified family. She is, quite literally, kicking and screaming. Bill can’t stop thinking about her.
paragraph2: In the quiet, rural landscape of southeast Ireland in 1985, a subtle yet profound transformation is underway in the life of Bill Furlong, a humble coal and fuel seller. Played with nuanced intensity by Cillian Murphy, Bill navigates the intricate web of relationships in his small town, where the nuns wield considerable influence over the community. At home, Bill finds comfort in the loving companionship of his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and their daughters, their modest means notwithstanding. However, the tranquility of Bill's existence is disrupted when he witnesses a disturbing scene: a young woman, suspected to be unmarried and pregnant, is forcibly taken into a building near the local convent. The woman's desperate resistance and evident distress leave an indelible mark on Bill, stirring a deep sense of empathy and recognition. As he grapples with the implications of what he has seen, Bill's thoughts turn to his own mother's past, and the seeds of a quiet rebellion are sown.

paragraph1: The Whirlpool Jet Boat Tour facility in Niagara-on-the-Lake has temporarily suspended operations for the summer season due to elevated water levels impacting the dock infrastructure. While this location remains closed, adventure seekers are being directed to the company's alternative outlet in Niagara Falls, where they can still experience the exhilarating journey through the lower Niagara River's powerful rapids. The tour features specially designed vessels that navigate through the churning waters, offering visitors an unforgettable combination of scenic views and heart-pounding excitement. Adult tickets are available for purchase, while children meeting the minimum height requirement can participate at a reduced rate. Management anticipates reopening the Niagara-on-the-Lake facility next year once water levels return to normal, allowing them to resume operations at both locations.
paragraph2: 12) 11 a.m. Jet off Though closed this summer, because of the high water level affecting the dock, the Whirlpool Jet Boat Tour facility in Niagara-on-the-Lake should be open next year (this season customers are being sent to their other outlet at Niagara Falls). Don’t miss the chance to ride on their custom-built vessels that navigate the strong rapids on the lower Niagara River, a seven-mile gorge carved out by the strong currents in the Niagara River. With hundreds of thousands of gallons of water flowing over the falls every minute, it is a journey like no other.
