paragraph1: Rather than play wait-and-see and have A.I. thrust upon them in ways they couldn’t control, Anthony and Joe Russo, the directors of the previous two “Avengers” movies for Marvel Studios, hired a machine-learning scientist away from Apple to help guide how their production company, AGBO, would use it. “There’s a lot of ways that we are experimenting with A.I. right now,” Anthony Russo told me. “We’re not quite sure what’s going to work and what’s not going to work.” But he is sure that A.I. will figure somehow into how he and his brother make the next two “Avengers” movies, both currently scheduled for 2026, even if it’s only to help with brainstorming ideas and working through them faster. Over several months of talking to people around Hollywood about A.I., I noticed a pattern: The people who knew the least about its potential uses in the filmmaking process feared it the most; and the people who understood it best, who had actually worked with it, harbored the most faith in the resilience of human creativity, as well as the most skepticism about generative A.I.’s ever supplanting it. There was a broad consensus about the urgency of confronting its many potential misuses — tech companies’ skirting copyright laws and scraping proprietary content to train their machine-learning models; actors’ likenesses being appropriated without their permission; studios’ circumventing contractual terms designed to ensure that everything we see onscreen gets written by an actual human being. I must’ve heard the phrase “proper guardrails” at least a dozen times. But as the prolific Emmy-winning television director Paris Barclay, who has six episodes of multiple shows airing this fall alone, put it, “That’s what unions are for.”
paragraph2: In a fascinating development, Anthony and Joe Russo, the visionary directors behind Marvel's blockbuster "Avengers" movies, are ambitiously embracing artificial intelligence (A.I.) within their production company, AGBO. By recruiting a machine-learning scientist from Apple, they are keen to explore how A.I. can revolutionize filmmaking, especially for their upcoming projects. Anthony Russo candidly admitted to me his uncertainty about A.I.'s specific applications but remains optimistic about its significant role in their future films. Observing a broader trend in Hollywood, I noticed a pattern where individuals unfamiliar with A.I. often approach it with trepidation, whereas those well-versed in its capabilities maintain faith in the enduring power of human creativity, expressing skepticism about A.I.'s potential to supplant it. However, this technological exploration is not without its challenges. Concerns have been raised about potential misuses of A.I., such as infringement on copyright and unauthorized exploitation of actors' likenesses. These issues underscore the urgent need for "proper guardrails" to ensure ethical use. Paris Barclay, a prominent television director, highlighted the critical role of unions in navigating these complex challenges. As the industry stands at this technological crossroads, the dialogue surrounding A.I.'s integration in filmmaking emphasizes a balance between innovation and protection of creative rights. The Russo brothers' foray into A.I. represents both a bold step into the future and a testament to their commitment to pushing the boundaries of cinematic storytelling, all while acknowledging the importance of safeguarding the creative integrity that defines Hollywood.

paragraph1: But it doesn’t mean cudgeling her with them. Once you’ve said your piece and listened to what she has to say in her defense, repeating the same arguments over and over would be the act of a bully. Citizens, let alone family members, shouldn’t be eager to direct vitriol against people whose political views they don’t share. If the rest of your family wants to go on doing that, you should tell them that they’re being unkind and unhelpful. Partyism is a morally debased form of political discourse. A friend of mine who is active in progressive politics and served in the Biden administration has a mother who voted for Trump. The mother, who is Black, Southern and religiously devout, is a single-issue voter: She’s fervently opposed to abortion. My friend deeply disagrees with her mother’s position but finds it intelligible. They’ve made their peace.
paragraph2: Political disagreements within families can strain relationships, making it crucial to maintain respectful dialogue rather than resorting to hostile exchanges. When family members repeatedly attack each other over political views, it crosses into bullying territory, creating deep wounds that can be difficult to heal. A notable example is the relationship between a former Biden administration official and her mother, whose story illustrates how complex family political dynamics can be navigated successfully. Despite being Black, Southern, and deeply religious, the mother voted for Trump primarily due to her strong anti-abortion stance. Her daughter, though actively involved in progressive politics, chose to understand rather than condemn her mother's position. Their ability to reach a mutual understanding, despite fundamentally different political views, demonstrates how families can maintain loving relationships even when they disagree on significant issues. This approach of empathy and respect proves far more constructive than perpetual conflict and antagonism.

paragraph1: But the truth is that my circumstances were different from my mother’s and grandmother’s. First, we never got married. We met when I was 19, tending bar at an on-campus performing arts center. I gave him a free drink, and he took out my recycling. He was so handsome that he should have been vain, but he wasn’t, and he liked animals more than people. We merged our lives and moved to a new state. We adopted a hound puppy and named him Mansfield, after the town where we fell in love. Early on, my partner bought a ring and then returned it, correctly assuming that I wasn’t ready for marriage. He didn’t mention this until years later when he had three jalapeño margaritas on vacation and confessed, sputtering, “Did I never tell you that?” By the time I was 30, most of our friends were married, but it had never felt like the right time for us. When people asked him why we hadn’t tied the knot, he would say that he was waiting for me to propose. I’d cite economics and feminism while harboring a feeling I admitted to no one: Things had gotten hard at times, and someday I might need an out. Our life was beautiful but not without its shadows, a fact that I hid behind a veneer of professional success and witty banter.
paragraph2: I met my partner when I was just nineteen, serving drinks at a local bar where life seemed simpler than it is now. Unlike my mother and grandmother, who followed the traditional path of early marriage and settled domesticity, our relationship took a different turn. We fell hard and fast, young and fearless enough to pack our lives into boxes and move to a new state, where we adopted our beloved puppy, Mansfield, who became our first shared responsibility. There was a time when marriage seemed inevitable – my partner even bought a ring – but I wasn't ready then, and somehow, the right moment never came again. Sometimes I wonder if I've disappointed my family by not following in their conventional footsteps, but our love story has written its own rules. Society's expectations weigh heavily at times, whispering doubts about the legitimacy of a partnership without marriage certificates and shared last names. Yet, I've learned to navigate these waters with a practiced smile and well-timed jokes, masking the complexity of our chosen path. Behind my carefully curated image of success and contentment lies a deeper truth: that love doesn't always need traditional validation to be real, even if explaining that to others remains a constant challenge.

paragraph1: As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.
paragraph2: MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?

Paragraph 1:
As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.

Paragraph 2:
MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?

paragraph1: The day she was named co-anchor of the “CBS Evening News” alongside Dan Rather, Connie Chung felt that she had reached the pinnacle of broadcast journalism. “Thursday, May 14, 1993, was the best day of my professional life. … I had my dream job,” she writes in an entertaining and revealing memoir that traces the triumphs and disappointments of her prominent career. The anchor appointment meant even more because she was a Chinese American woman, brought up by strict parents; in accordance with tradition, she lived with them until she was nearly 30, even as she was climbing the ladder — often wearing stiletto heels.
paragraph2: Connie Chung's appointment as co-anchor of the "CBS Evening News" alongside Dan Rather represents a landmark achievement in her broadcast journalism career. This role marked a significant milestone, both personally and culturally, as she became one of the few Chinese American women to reach such heights in the industry. Raised by strict parents who held traditional family expectations, Chung navigated her path to success with determination and resilience. Reflecting on this achievement in her memoir, she writes, "It was a dream realized, a testament to perseverance." Her success not only underscores her professional dedication but also serves as an inspiring narrative of breaking barriers and redefining possibilities for future generations.

paragraph1: In the ongoing legal saga surrounding Purdue Pharma and the Sackler family, Judge Sean H. Lane, who presides over the Purdue bankruptcy cases, has opted to maintain a pause on lawsuits against both Purdue and the Sacklers during a designated mediation period. This pause comes amidst strategic legal maneuvers by a government-appointed committee representing the creditors, who have taken significant steps by filing a claim against the Sacklers. They accuse the family of illicitly transferring $11.5 billion from Purdue Pharma in an effort to shield these assets from potential litigation, a move commonly referred to as fraudulent conveyance. This tactic is frequently employed in bankruptcy cases as creditors strive to reclaim funds they contend were improperly reallocated. The committee's filing is comprehensive, including a request for a jury trial and a meticulously crafted draft complaint. Notably, Purdue Pharma itself is not directly advancing this claim; however, the company has shown its endorsement of the creditors' actions. Purdue has indicated that should mediation not yield a resolution, litigation will become an inevitable course, with the creditors' committee being optimally positioned to manage these claims. This expression of support underscores the intricate legal dynamics at play, as the stakeholders navigate a complex landscape of mediation and potential litigation to address the contentious financial maneuvers executed by the Sackler family amidst Purdue's bankruptcy proceedings.
paragraph2: Groups of plaintiffs had long been planning for this outcome. On Tuesday, Judge Sean H. Lane of the U. S. Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, N.Y., who oversees the Purdue cases, said the lawsuits against Purdue and the Sacklers would continue to be paused during the mediation period. The intent of the recent spate of filings is to paint a vivid picture of the legal onslaught that the Sacklers would be likely to face should the short window of time for allotted mediation slam shut without a deal. A filing this week from a government-appointed committee representing a broad group of creditors argues that the Sacklers illegally siphoned $11.5 billion from Purdue in less than a decade to wall off the money from potential litigation. That kind of claim, known as fraudulent conveyance, is a standard move in bankruptcy court in which creditors can seek to reclaim money they believe has been illegally squirreled away and should be included in distributions to them. The creditors’ filing included both a request to bring the case and a 200-page draft of their prospective complaint, in which they requested a jury trial. Although Purdue is not directly pursuing this claim against its owners, the company said on Tuesday that it supported the action. “If a consensual resolution is not reached through mediation, however, litigation will be necessary, and we believe the creditors’ committee is the party best situated to prosecute these claims,” Purdue said in a statement.

paragraph1: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday for illegally collecting children’s data, escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app. TikTok broke the law by gathering personal information from users under the age of 13 without their parents’ permission, according to the government’s complaint. The company knowingly allowed children under the age of 13 to create and use TikTok accounts, the government said, and frequently failed to honor parents’ requests to delete their children’s accounts. The lawsuit, which was filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, said those practices violated both the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act, a law that restricts the online tracking of children, and a 2019 agreement between TikTok and the government in which the company pledged to notify parents before collecting children’s data and remove videos from users under 13 years old. The suit, which also names TikTok’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance, asks for the court to fine the companies over the violations. “With this action, the Department seeks to ensure that TikTok honors its obligation to protect children’s privacy rights and parents’ efforts to protect their children,” said Benjamin C. Mizer, the acting associate attorney general, in a statement. TikTok did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
paragraph2: The U.S. Justice Department has taken significant legal action against TikTok by filing a lawsuit that accuses the social media giant of unlawfully collecting personal data from children under 13 without obtaining parental consent. The lawsuit, which also names TikTok's parent company ByteDance as a defendant, alleges that the platform violated both the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act and a previous settlement agreement by enabling young children to create accounts on the platform and subsequently failing to remove these accounts when parents requested their deletion. Filed in the Central District of California, the legal action seeks monetary penalties for these alleged violations, highlighting the government's growing concern over digital privacy protection for minors. Acting Associate Attorney General Benjamin C. Mizer has emphasized the critical nature of safeguarding children's privacy rights in the digital age, underscoring the Justice Department's commitment to holding social media companies accountable for their actions. As of now, TikTok has maintained silence regarding these serious allegations, which could potentially result in substantial financial penalties and increased scrutiny of the platform's user verification and data collection practices. The case represents a significant escalation in the ongoing debate about social media companies' responsibilities toward their youngest users.

As of now, TikTok has maintained silence regarding these serious allegations, which could potentially result in substantial financial penalties and increased scrutiny of the platform's user verification and data collection practices. The case represents a significant escalation in the ongoing debate about social media companies' responsibilities toward their youngest users.

paragraph1: The day she was named co-anchor of the “CBS Evening News” alongside Dan Rather, Connie Chung felt that she had reached the pinnacle of broadcast journalism. “Thursday, May 14, 1993, was the best day of my professional life. … I had my dream job,” she writes in an entertaining and revealing memoir that traces the triumphs and disappointments of her prominent career. paragraph2: Connie Chung's appointment as co-anchor of the "CBS Evening News" alongside Dan Rather represents a landmark achievement in her broadcast journalism career. Raised by strict parents who held traditional family expectations, Chung navigated her path to success with determination and resilience. Reflecting on this achievement in her memoir, she writes, "It was a dream realized, a testament to perseverance." Her success not only underscores her professional dedication but also serves as an inspiring narrative of breaking barriers and redefining possibilities for future generations.

paragraph1: In the early days of my relationship with Jen, we found ourselves enjoying drinks with another couple. In a playful moment, I suggested that if we ever got married, we should combine our last names to become "Lavisi." Our friends found this amusing and, in good humor, wrote a postcard addressed to "Dani and Jen Lavisi" at a fictional address in Lesbos, Greece. We stuck that postcard on our fridge, where it remained for five years, transforming from a lighthearted joke into a prophetic symbol of our future. Eventually, the same friend who wrote the postcard officiated our wedding, and we legally adopted the combined last name, Lavisi.
paragraph2: Postcard From the Future Months into dating, my girlfriend and I sat across from another couple and drank margaritas. “If we ever get married,” I said, “we’re going to combine our last names to create a new one: Lavisi.” Our friends laughed at our plan, made so early in our relationship. One of them addressed the free postcard that came with our check to our future selves: “Dani and Jen Lavisi, 123 Lesbian Lane, Lesbos, Greece.” It hung on our fridge for five years — a joke that became a prophecy when that same friend married us and we legally changed our names. — Danielle Lavisi

paragraph1: The anime industry is also trying to capitalize on the interest from athletes. Crunchyroll, a streaming service dedicated to anime, enlisted the N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson to serve as an awards show presenter and teamed with the N.B.A. on clothing. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, said athletes with large followings were great ambassadors for the genre as it continued to push into the mainstream. “All of those old myths and concerns about, ‘What will people think if I tell them that I watch anime?’ go away because if this person that is a celebrity and really famous athlete is talking about it, then it’s OK for every one of us to talk about it,” Purini said. “It’s a very important thing for the medium.” While Turner was a rookie with the Rams last year, he watched anime on team flights and proudly wore “Jujutsu Kaisen” shirts. Although it is rare for defensive linemen to reach the end zone, he is still planning additional ways to celebrate his off-field interests. “The ones that know it, they’ll pick up on it and it’ll be super-cool,” said Turner, who plans to act out Naruto’s “shadow clone jutsu” if he ever scores a touchdown. After he makes a cross signal with his fingers, two teammates will pop out behind him, mimicking the character’s mystical ability to spawn doppelgängers.
paragraph2: The anime industry is increasingly tapping into the star power of athletes to broaden its appeal and reach new audiences. Leveraging their massive followings, these sports figures are becoming influential ambassadors for anime, dissolving outdated stereotypes and helping to mainstream the genre. Crunchyroll, a leading anime streaming service, exemplifies this strategy by involving prominent athletes in their promotional efforts. For instance, N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson has been featured as a presenter at an awards show, while the platform has also collaborated with the N.B.A. to create exclusive clothing lines. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, emphasizes the effectiveness of these partnerships, noting that athletes can connect with diverse audiences who may not traditionally engage with anime. Turner, a rookie with the Rams, embodies this trend with his unabashed enthusiasm for anime. He frequently sports "Jujutsu Kaisen" shirts and is eager to bring his passion to the field. Turner plans to celebrate any future touchdowns by performing Naruto's iconic "shadow clone jutsu," a testament to his dedication and the cultural crossover between anime and sports. Through these collaborations, the anime industry is not only expanding its fanbase but is also reshaping perceptions, proving that anime can be a mainstream cultural phenomenon embraced by fans and athletes alike.

paragraph1: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, is set to close its San Francisco office in the coming weeks, according to an internal email sent by the company's chief executive, Linda Yaccarino. The decision, outlined in the email to employees, will involve relocating staff to existing offices in San Jose, California. Additionally, a new engineering-focused office will be established in Palo Alto, California, which will be shared with xAI, another Musk-owned company. Ms. Yaccarino emphasized that while the move will have an impact, it is a strategic decision that will ultimately benefit the company in the long term. The closure marks a significant shift for X, as it consolidates its Bay Area presence.
paragraph2: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, plans to shut its San Francisco office “over the next few weeks,” according to an internal email obtained by The New York Times. In the email, which X’s chief executive, Linda Yaccarino, sent to employees on Monday, the company said workers would move to existing offices in San Jose, Calif. X will also open an engineering-focused office in Palo Alto, Calif., which it will share with xAI, the artificial intelligence outfit owned by Mr. Musk, the email said. “This is an important decision that impacts many of you, but it is the right one for our company in the long term,” Ms. Yaccarino wrote to employees.

The closure marks a significant shift for X, as it consolidates its Bay Area presence.

X will also open an engineering-focused office in Palo Alto, Calif., which it will share with xAI, the artificial intelligence outfit owned by Mr. Musk, the email said. “This is an important decision that impacts many of you, but it is the right one for our company in the long term,” Ms. Yaccarino wrote to employees.

paragraph1: During the production of Season 2, the television series navigated a multitude of challenges, both logistical and creative, which significantly shaped the final product. The relocation of filming from New Zealand to Britain marked a pivotal shift, compounded by the disruptions caused by Covid lockdowns and a writers' strike. These obstacles necessitated innovative solutions from the team, led by showrunners McKay and J.D. Payne. Amidst these challenges, McKay highlighted the evolving relationship between two central characters, describing it as a "fresh flavor" infused with Hitchcockian elements and a dark, toxic dynamic that added depth to the narrative. Actor Edwards, who portrayed Celebrimbor, found a unique connection between his character and Shakespeare's Richard II, noting their mutual vulnerability to flattery. This thematic exploration was further enriched by Edwards' commitment to authenticity, as he learned the intricate art of ring forging for a crucial scene. When the writers' strike forced McKay and Payne to pause their involvement, they entrusted the completion of production to director Brandstrom and executive producer Lindsey Weber, who were not bound by union restrictions. With much of the writing already completed, Brandstrom and Weber skillfully navigated the remaining hurdles, ensuring that the season maintained its creative vision despite the turbulent production process.
paragraph2: The pair’s relationship, a key story line in Season 2, is a “fresh flavor” for the show, McKay said: “It’s like a little Hitchcock in there. And also the sense of a descent and a very dark, toxic relationship.” Edwards, a prolific stage actor, said he was struck by the similarities between the character of Celebrimbor and Shakespeare’s Richard II, whom he has played onstage — including the smith’s susceptibility to flattery. Edwards learned how to forge a ring, with the help of a jeweler (there is a ringmaking scene where this came in handy). The series, which moved its base from New Zealand to Britain for Season 2, has weathered production disruptions, like much of Hollywood. Covid lockdowns stopped filming for its first season, and then, three weeks before the end of shooting this season, according to the showrunners, the union for writers in Hollywood went on strike. “That was one of the most challenging moments for us as showrunners on this show,” McKay said. “But we had to stand with our guild and had to step away.” At that point, much of the writing for Season 2 was complete, according to J.D. Payne, the other showrunner, and the pair charged Brandstrom, the director, and Lindsey Weber, one of the show’s executive producers — neither of whom were in the writing union — with finishing production.

paragraph1: Still, Ms. Reeves showed some restraint in the face of pressure to inject a lot more cash into Britain’s struggling public services. She announced more money in the next few years, especially for teachers, defense and local authorities. But starting in 2026, day-to-day spending for government departments would grow on average 1.3 percent annually, after accounting for inflation, which analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies said would still leave some departments with very tight budgets. At the same time, Ms. Reeves also set to increase public investment. She said that over the next five years, the government would increase capital spending by £100 billion to invest in projects, such as school buildings, hospital beds and diagnostics centers. In all, Ms. Reeves’s measures will temporarily aid the economy but leave its size “largely unchanged” in five years, the Office for Budget Responsibility said. It forecast slightly higher growth for this year and next, but said growth would then slow to below 2 percent a year. However, a sustained increase in public investment would raise the supply potential of the economy, which could increase long-term growth, the budget responsibility office said.
paragraph2: Ms. Reeves demonstrated a measured approach to fiscal policy while facing mounting pressure to boost Britain's public service funding. Her announcement outlined increased funding allocations over the coming years, with specific focus on teachers, defense, and local authorities, though she maintained strict control by capping day-to-day departmental spending growth at 1.3 percent annually from 2026, accounting for inflation. The Institute for Fiscal Studies' analysis suggested this conservative approach would create challenging financial constraints for certain departments. A notable aspect of her strategy included a substantial £100 billion increase in public investment over five years, targeting critical infrastructure such as school buildings and hospitals. The Office for Budget Responsibility's assessment indicated that while these measures would provide temporary economic support, they would not substantially alter the economy's size within five years, as growth was projected to decelerate below 2 percent annually. Nevertheless, they acknowledged that the increased public investment could potentially enhance the economy's capacity for long-term growth.

paragraph1: In 1999, the cinematic landscape was a vibrant tapestry of innovation and experimentation. It was the year that M. Night Shyamalan's twisty thriller and "The Blair Witch Project" redefined the horror genre, while "American Beauty" and "Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace" dominated the box office. Meanwhile, "The Matrix" was busy blowing minds with its groundbreaking special effects. But beneath the surface, a sense of existential identity crises and anomie was brewing, as seen in films like "Office Space," "Election," "Dick," "Fight Club," and "American Pie." As critic Raftery would likely exclaim with characteristic enthusiasm, 1999 was a thrilling time for American cinema, marked by a sense of creative freedom and risk-taking that would soon become a distant memory. It was, in many ways, the last exciting era for both moviegoing and writing about movies.
paragraph2: Twenty-five years later, 1999 is known for being the year of Shyamalan’s movie, of “Blair Witch” and “American Beauty,” which came out in September and went on, somehow, to win the best picture Oscar. The year is remembered for “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace” and “The Matrix,” which had opened in March and by August was winding down its initial colonization of the cultural imagination. It was known for existential identity crackups, and a pervasive itch of anomie, that you could sense in “Office Space,” “Election,” “Dick” and “Fight Club,” which weren’t hits, but also in “American Pie,” which very much was. So Raftery’s breathless tone seems right. It was the last most-exciting period for American moviegoing. It was the last most-exciting time to write about the movies.

Twenty-five years later, 1999 is known for being the year of Shyamalan’s movie, of “Blair Witch” and “American Beauty,” which came out in September and went on, somehow, to win the best picture Oscar. The year is remembered for “Star Wars: Episode I — The Phantom Menace” and “The Matrix,” which had opened in March and by August was winding down its initial colonization of the cultural imagination. It was known for existential identity crackups, and a pervasive itch of anomie, that you could sense in “Office Space,” “Election,” “Dick” and “Fight Club,” which weren’t hits, but also in “American Pie,” which very much was. So Raftery’s breathless tone seems right. It was the last most-exciting period for American moviegoing. It was the last most-exciting time to write about the movies.

paragraph1: The New York Times has filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, alleging copyright infringement related to news content used in AI systems. OpenAI, a company that provides AI tools capable of generating social media posts, images, and computer programs, similar to industry giants Google and Meta, has seen its technology utilized in influence campaigns worldwide. Notably, a Russian campaign dubbed Doppelganger leveraged OpenAI's tools to create anti-Ukraine comments in multiple languages, as well as translate and edit pro-Russian articles into English and French, converting them into Facebook posts. Similarly, a Chinese campaign known as Spamouflage has also employed OpenAI's technology. The lawsuit marks a significant development in the ongoing debate over the use of AI-generated content and its implications for media outlets and intellectual property rights.
paragraph2: (The New York Times has sued OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, claiming copyright infringement of news content related to A.I. systems.) Like Google, Meta and Microsoft, OpenAI offers online chatbots and other A.I. tools that can write social media posts, generate photorealistic images and write computer programs. In its report, the company said its tools had been used in influence campaigns that researchers had tracked for years, including a Russian campaign called Doppelganger and a Chinese campaign called Spamouflage. The Doppelganger campaign used OpenAI’s technology to generate anti-Ukraine comments that were posted on X in English, French, German, Italian and Polish, OpenAI said. The company’s tools were also used to translate and edit articles that supported Russia in the war in Ukraine into English and French, and to convert anti-Ukraine news articles into Facebook posts.

paragraph1: The U.S. Justice Department has taken significant legal action against TikTok by filing a lawsuit that accuses the social media giant of unlawfully collecting personal data from children under 13 without obtaining parental consent. The lawsuit, which also names TikTok's parent company ByteDance as a defendant, alleges that the platform violated both the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act and a previous settlement agreement by enabling young children to create accounts on the platform and subsequently failing to remove these accounts when parents requested their deletion. Filed in the Central District of California, the legal action seeks monetary penalties for these alleged violations, highlighting the government's growing concern over digital privacy protection for minors. Acting Associate Attorney General Benjamin C. Mizer has emphasized the critical nature of safeguarding children's privacy rights in the digital age, underscoring the Justice Department's commitment to holding social media companies accountable for their actions. As of now, TikTok has maintained silence regarding these serious allegations, which could potentially result in substantial financial penalties and increased scrutiny of the platform's user verification and data collection practices. The case represents a significant escalation in the ongoing debate about social media companies' responsibilities toward their youngest users.
paragraph2: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday for illegally collecting children’s data, escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app. TikTok broke the law by gathering personal information from users under the age of 13 without their parents’ permission, according to the government’s complaint. The company knowingly allowed children under the age of 13 to create and use TikTok accounts, the government said, and frequently failed to honor parents’ requests to delete their children’s accounts. The lawsuit, which was filed in the United States District Court for the Central District of California, said those practices violated both the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act, a law that restricts the online tracking of children, and a 2019 agreement between TikTok and the government in which the company pledged to notify parents before collecting children’s data and remove videos from users under 13 years old. The suit, which also names TikTok’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance, asks for the court to fine the companies over the violations. “With this action, the Department seeks to ensure that TikTok honors its obligation to protect children’s privacy rights and parents’ efforts to protect their children,” said Benjamin C. Mizer, the acting associate attorney general, in a statement. TikTok did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

paragraph1: It appears that my sibling’s spouse also has limited interest in providing for their children. I surely don’t want to hand over anything to my sibling’s spouse, but to give it to the children directly would be a way of enabling the spouse to skirt the obligation to care for them. I could continue to make charitable contributions in my sibling’s name, but what right do I have to use money belonging to others? (What I have already done may not have been entirely proper.) I could put funds in trust for the kids but would rather gift them a nontaxable amount annually. Or I could just wait until the kids need help with something critical. Turning any funds over to my sibling’s spouse would turn my stomach. Name Withheld
paragraph2: I've been losing sleep over how to help my sister's kids without inadvertently supporting her husband's irresponsible behavior. Every time I see them struggling, my heart aches, but simply handing over money feels like enabling his chronic neglect of their needs. I've explored several options, from establishing a trust fund to making annual gifts within the tax-free limit, but each solution comes with its own complications. Making charitable donations in my sister's name could indirectly benefit the children, yet I worry it's not enough. The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.

The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.

paragraph1: The two of you could tell them, during an adults’ evening together, that the heavy demands of work and raising children and running a house don’t lend themselves to impromptu visits. You need a few days’ notice. One of you could add that it would be a big help if they sometimes took the kids out when they visited — to a museum, for instance, or for ice cream — so you could catch up on other work. Now, your husband may be unwilling, initially, to establish this new (but totally reasonable) boundary with his parents. Many people dislike friction. In that case, tell him you will do so yourself, but it may create more antagonism that way. Still, let’s hope your husband rises to the occasion: Having a busy job does not entitle people to foist their parents onto others.
paragraph2: You and your husband need to have an honest conversation with his parents about establishing clear boundaries for their visits. While you understand their desire to spend time with the family, it's essential to explain how you're juggling work commitments, childcare responsibilities, and household management. Request that they provide advance notice before dropping by, which will help you better plan and prepare for their visits. Consider suggesting that they could occasionally take the grandchildren out for activities, providing you with some breathing space while fostering their relationship with the kids. Though your husband might be hesitant to address this issue due to his aversion to conflict, it's crucial that he takes the lead in this conversation rather than leaving it to you. Having him communicate directly with his parents will prevent potential resentment and ensure a healthier family dynamic moving forward.

Having him communicate directly with his parents will prevent potential resentment and ensure a healthier family dynamic moving forward.

paragraph1: As I look back on 1999, I recall a time when the line between truth and fiction was blissfully clear. We'd enter a movie theater, suspend our disbelief, and for two hours, contradictory realities coexisted. But as the credits rolled, we'd exit into a shared world, collectively acknowledging the fantasy we'd just witnessed. Fast forward to today, and it's as if we've never left the theater. Each of us now inhabits a bespoke reality, making it increasingly disorienting to find common ground. Your truth, my truth – the notion of a shared reality feels like a relic of the past.
paragraph2: In 1999, the gray area between truth and fiction, where the person seated to your left believed the opposite of the person seated to your right, was contained safely with the movie’s run time. And as we all left the theater, we collectively realized it was all a ride. Now, in a way, that ride never ends. And perhaps most unnerving is the knowledge that each one of us is living in an increasingly unique version of the world, making reality less of a communal experience than ever.

paragraph1: In 2013, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum unveiled an exhibition to honor the 40th anniversary of martial arts legend Bruce Lee's untimely death at 32. This captivating display showcases an array of memorabilia from Lee's illustrious life, celebrating his multifaceted talents and enduring legacy. Visitors can marvel at footage of Lee's impressive cha-cha dance moves, examine his punching bags, and explore his meticulously planned training schedules. The exhibition also features his 1970s sweaters and the iconic yellow tracksuit from "Game of Death." For those eager to delve into Lee's world, bus 170 offers the most convenient transport option from Causeway Bay to the museum, ensuring easy access to this remarkable tribute.
paragraph2: Hong Kong has produced plenty of film stars, but few have left as indelible a mark on the city as Bruce Lee, the martial arts legend. To mark the 40th anniversary of Lee’s untimely death at 32, the Hong Kong Heritage Museum opened an excellent exhibition on his life in 2013, gathering memorabilia from his early years (including footage of his smooth cha-cha dance moves), along with his well-worn punching bags, old training schedules, skintight 1970s sweaters, and the famous yellow tracksuit he wore in “Game of Death,” which Lee was filming when he died. The best transport option is bus 170, which connects directly to Causeway Bay.

paragraph1: Opened in 1970 in a converted dentist’s office, the U District’s Grand Illusion was Seattle’s first celluloid art house and stands today as the city’s oldest continuously running independent movie theater. Now operated by Northwest Film Forum, it features a calendar of films (tickets, $11) that is fabulously eclectic, appealing to fans of documentaries, anime, indie dramas and underappreciated classics. For those seeking a less sedentary way to top off their Saturday, an even older movie theater a few blocks away, the Neptune, has been transformed into a live music and performance space (tickets typically $25 to $45) that hosts an eclectic mix of national touring acts. You can still order popcorn, though.
paragraph2: In Seattle, two notable venues capture the city's rich cultural tapestry. The Grand Illusion, originally opened in 1970 in a former dentist's office, stands as Seattle's oldest independent movie theater. Now managed by the Northwest Film Forum, it showcases a diverse array of films, from documentaries and anime to indie dramas and classics, enriching the city's cinematic landscape. Nearby, the Neptune, an even older theater, has transformed into a vibrant live music and performance venue, attracting national acts. Despite its modern focus, the Neptune retains a nostalgic touch by offering traditional movie theater snacks like popcorn. Both venues embody Seattle's commitment to preserving unique cultural experiences.

paragraph1: At Pakuri, nestled in the Villa Morra district, diners are treated to a unique culinary experience crafted by Paraguayan chef Sofía Pfannl and Peruvian sommelier José Miguel Burga. The restaurant, housed in repurposed shipping containers, exudes a chic yet relaxed atmosphere. The menu is an exquisite fusion of Peruvian and Paraguayan flavors, featuring dishes like ceviche, chicharrones, and ají amarillo, complemented by manioc chips, sweet potato purée, and butternut squash fettuccine. José's expertly curated wine list highlights the finest vineyards of South America. Despite its sophisticated offerings, the ambiance remains laid-back, with a young staff, a basketball game playing on TV, and the owners' pets freely exploring the space. The lush patio, opening onto a serene cobbled street, enhances the dining experience.
paragraph2:
8 p.m. Eat dinner in a box
Sofía Pfannl, a Paraguayan chef, and José Miguel Burga, a Peruvian sommelier, met while working at Central, the acclaimed restaurant in Lima. Their backstory is tangible at Pakuri, the restaurant they own together in the modish Villa Morra district. In the chic space of repurposed shipping containers, they serve Peruvian-style ceviche, chicharrones and ají amarillo alongside Paraguayan manioc chips, sweet potato purée and butternut squash fettuccine. While José’s wine list is a roll call of South America’s best vineyards, the atmosphere remains unstuffy: the restaurant has a youthful cohort of cooks and servers, a basketball game is often on the T.V. behind the bar, and the owners’ pets wander around. Outside, a verdant patio faces a quiet cobbled street.

paragraph1: “Their No. 1 agenda is to continue producing fossil fuels,” said Andrew Dessler, a professor of atmospheric sciences and the director of the Texas Center for Climate Studies at Texas A&M University. “Once you understand their main goal is to entrench fossil fuels regardless of anything else, everything makes sense.” The party platform, issued last week, makes no mention of climate change. Instead, it encourages more production of oil, gas and coal, the burning of which is dangerously driving up global temperatures. “We will DRILL, BABY, DRILL,” it says, referring to oil as “liquid gold.” By contrast, Mr. Biden has taken the most aggressive action of any president to cut emissions from coal, oil and gas and encourage a transition to wind, solar and other carbon-free energy. He has directed every federal agency from the Agriculture Department to the Pentagon to consider how climate change is affecting their core missions. If Mr. Biden has taken an all-of-government approach to fighting climate change, Mr. Trump and his allies would adopt the opposite: scrubbing “climate” from all federal functions and promoting fossil fuels.
paragraph2: The stark divergence in climate change and energy policies between Mr. Biden and Mr. Trump reflects a fundamental ideological split in American environmental governance. Andrew Dessler, who directs climate research at Texas A&M University, notes with concern that one party's primary agenda revolves around continued fossil fuel production, evidenced by their platform's conspicuous omission of climate change while advocating for increased oil, gas, and coal extraction. This approach stands in sharp contrast to Mr. Biden's comprehensive climate strategy, which encompasses aggressive emission reduction targets and a coordinated transition to renewable energy sources across all government agencies. Mr. Trump and his supporters, meanwhile, have indicated their intention to systematically remove climate considerations from federal decision-making processes, prioritizing instead the expansion of fossil fuel infrastructure and production. This polarization in environmental policy approaches highlights the deep-seated differences between the two administrations' visions for America's energy future, with one embracing clean energy transformation and the other remaining steadfast in traditional fossil fuel development, creating a clear choice for voters concerned about climate action.

paragraph1: I understand how much you want everyone to reconcile and find a happy ending, but sometimes we have to accept that not every family conflict has a perfect resolution. The situation between your nephew and his parents is far more complex than just sharing news about a new baby – these wounds run deep, and simply informing your sister might not bridge the divide that's grown between them. If you're considering sharing this information, I strongly suggest asking your nephew's permission first. It's his life, his family, and his choice to make. From my experience, family therapy could be a potential pathway to healing if everyone's willing to participate and do the hard work. However, I need to caution you against becoming too deeply entangled in their conflict or trying to serve as a mediator between the parties. Sometimes, as painful as it may be to accept, estrangement might actually be the healthiest option for everyone involved. While we naturally want to fix things and bring people together, we must respect that adults make their own choices about their relationships, even when those choices are difficult for us to understand.
paragraph2: AUNT I know how comforting it can be to imagine that every conflict has a happy solution. (It’s why I have a job!) But that’s not always the case. Here, the estrangement is probably more complicated than a few rough conversations. And while telling your sister about the baby may assuage your guilt, it will do little to help anyone else: Your nephew and his parents will still be estranged. You can always ask your nephew for permission to tell his mother, right? But you don’t seem particularly well placed to get involved here: You rarely speak to your sister, after all, and by your own account, you don’t know the full story of the conflict between your nephew and his parents, or even whether your sister knows about the baby already. Still, I admire your desire to help, and I sympathize with your feelings of discomfort. In your place, I would suggest to your sister and your nephew that they might benefit from family therapy. (The baby may give both sides an incentive to reconcile.) But I wouldn’t go beyond that or start shuttling messages between them. As hard as it is to acknowledge, sometimes estrangement is the healthiest outcome. And without closer involvement, you aren’t in a position to know.

paragraph1: “I don’t want to own a house by myself,” I said to my partner of four years as we discussed the benefits of owning property in Bozeman, Mont., our increasingly unaffordable mountain town. “We have to try to make this work.” I was a 30-year-old writer; he was a carpenter and house framer, several years younger. We had been “trying to make it work” for the past year. We fought bitterly, took breaks, got back together. I moved out of our shared house, back in, and out again. Then, in June 2018, a reasonably priced house came on the market during one of our “Let’s try again” periods. The house was spacious: three bedrooms, a two-car garage and a fenced-in backyard. The mortgage was manageable for two people, but not for me alone. Which is why, after the final meeting with the real estate agent, we agreed to split the monthly payment down the middle. My credit was better, so I would be the only person on the actual paperwork, but I would have my partner’s financial contribution and his construction skills to ease the stress of solo homeownership — if we could make our relationship work. Two months later, I closed on the house. Two days after that, we had one last fight and broke up for good, leaving me alone in the house with my cat.
paragraph2: As I sit in my newly acquired home, surrounded by the eerie silence of a space that was meant to be shared, I'm reminded of the gamble I took on love and real estate. My partner, a skilled carpenter and house framer, and I had been navigating the tumultuous waters of our relationship for years, our frequent arguments and breakups a testament to our passion and instability. Despite our rocky past, we decided to take the plunge and buy a house together in Bozeman, Montana, a decision that seemed reckless in hindsight. With my better credit, I took on the mortgage, while my partner agreed to contribute financially and lend his expertise to renovation projects. But just weeks after closing, our relationship imploded in a final, brutal argument, leaving me alone in this sprawling space with only my cat for company. Now, as I wander the empty rooms, I'm forced to confront the uncertainty of my decision and the daunting prospect of starting anew, solo. The house, once a symbol of our shared dreams, has become a bittersweet reminder of what could have been, and the mortgage, a constant, nagging reminder of my own vulnerability.

paragraph1: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday. Millions of people take Ozempic and Wegovy, which are considered to be among the biggest blockbusters in medical history. But last year a European drug safety agency said it was investigating whether the drugs cause suicidal thoughts. The new study, published in the journal Nature Medicine, was funded by the National Institutes of Health and used a huge population. The findings provide data that may potentially reassure people who take the drugs. Novo Nordisk, maker of the drugs, had no role in the study, and the study’s investigators had no conflicts of interest. The investigators used anonymized electronic health records from a database of 100.8 million people. That allowed them to look at two groups: 240,618 who were prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and 1,589,855 who were prescribed Ozempic or other medicines to lower their blood sugar. Suicidal thoughts were included in patients’ records as part of routine monitoring of their health.
paragraph2: In a recent study published in Nature Medicine, researchers explored the psychological effects of the drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, commonly prescribed for diabetes and obesity, respectively. The study, funded by the National Institutes of Health, found that individuals using these medications exhibited a slightly reduced likelihood of experiencing suicidal thoughts compared to those who were not taking them. Utilizing a comprehensive database of anonymized electronic health records from over 100 million individuals, the researchers meticulously compared two distinct groups: those prescribed Wegovy or other weight loss drugs, and those receiving Ozempic or other blood sugar-lowering medications. The findings of this extensive analysis aim to provide reassurance to users of these drugs, highlighting a potential mental health benefit alongside their physical health uses. Importantly, the study was conducted independently of Novo Nordisk, the manufacturer of both medications, ensuring the results were free from any conflicts of interest. This research not only contributes to the understanding of the multifaceted impacts of these medications but also underscores the importance of considering mental health outcomes when assessing the overall benefits of pharmaceutical interventions for chronic conditions like diabetes and obesity.

paragraph1: At Pakuri, nestled in the Villa Morra district, diners are treated to a unique culinary experience crafted by Paraguayan chef Sofía Pfannl and Peruvian sommelier José Miguel Burga. The restaurant, housed in repurposed shipping containers, exudes a chic yet relaxed atmosphere. The menu is an exquisite fusion of Peruvian and Paraguayan flavors, featuring dishes like ceviche, chicharrones, and ají amarillo, complemented by manioc chips, sweet potato purée, and butternut squash fettuccine. José's expertly curated wine list highlights the finest vineyards of South America. Despite its sophisticated offerings, the ambiance remains laid-back, with a young staff, a basketball game playing on TV, and the owners' pets freely exploring the space. The lush patio, opening onto a serene cobbled street, enhances the dining experience.
paragraph2:
8 p.m. Eat dinner in a box
Sofía Pfannl, a Paraguayan chef, and José Miguel Burga, a Peruvian sommelier, met while working at Central, the acclaimed restaurant in Lima. Their backstory is tangible at Pakuri, the restaurant they own together in the modish Villa Morra district. In the chic space of repurposed shipping containers, they serve Peruvian-style ceviche, chicharrones and ají amarillo alongside Paraguayan manioc chips, sweet potato purée and butternut squash fettuccine. While José’s wine list is a roll call of South America’s best vineyards, the atmosphere remains unstuffy: the restaurant has a youthful cohort of cooks and servers, a basketball game is often on the T.V. behind the bar, and the owners’ pets wander around. Outside, a verdant patio faces a quiet cobbled street.

paragraph1: The anime industry is increasingly tapping into the star power of athletes to broaden its appeal and reach new audiences. Leveraging their massive followings, these sports figures are becoming influential ambassadors for anime, dissolving outdated stereotypes and helping to mainstream the genre. Crunchyroll, a leading anime streaming service, exemplifies this strategy by involving prominent athletes in their promotional efforts. For instance, N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson has been featured as a presenter at an awards show, while the platform has also collaborated with the N.B.A. to create exclusive clothing lines. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, emphasizes the effectiveness of these partnerships, noting that athletes can connect with diverse audiences who may not traditionally engage with anime. Turner, a rookie with the Rams, embodies this trend with his unabashed enthusiasm for anime. He frequently sports "Jujutsu Kaisen" shirts and is eager to bring his passion to the field. Turner plans to celebrate any future touchdowns by performing Naruto's iconic "shadow clone jutsu," a testament to his dedication and the cultural crossover between anime and sports. Through these collaborations, the anime industry is not only expanding its fanbase but is also reshaping perceptions, proving that anime can be a mainstream cultural phenomenon embraced by fans and athletes alike.
paragraph2: The anime industry is also trying to capitalize on the interest from athletes. Crunchyroll, a streaming service dedicated to anime, enlisted the N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson to serve as an awards show presenter and teamed with the N.B.A. on clothing. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, said athletes with large followings were great ambassadors for the genre as it continued to push into the mainstream. “All of those old myths and concerns about, ‘What will people think if I tell them that I watch anime?’ go away because if this person that is a celebrity and really famous athlete is talking about it, then it’s OK for every one of us to talk about it,” Purini said. “It’s a very important thing for the medium.” While Turner was a rookie with the Rams last year, he watched anime on team flights and proudly wore “Jujutsu Kaisen” shirts. Although it is rare for defensive linemen to reach the end zone, he is still planning additional ways to celebrate his off-field interests. “The ones that know it, they’ll pick up on it and it’ll be super-cool,” said Turner, who plans to act out Naruto’s “shadow clone jutsu” if he ever scores a touchdown. After he makes a cross signal with his fingers, two teammates will pop out behind him, mimicking the character’s mystical ability to spawn doppelgängers.

paragraph1:
4. Modern Argentina | 10:30 p.m.
Head to the quietly trending Colegiales neighborhood for dinner (around 1,300 pesos with wine for two) at Astor Manduque Porteño (the name translates, roughly, to “where locals eat”). The chef Antonio Soriano is a leading light of the new school of Argentine cooking, and his oft-changing menu is packed with creative dishes, which recently included blood sausage tempura and a salad of beef tongue. There are just eight dishes on offer at any one time, and diners can opt to try three, five or all of the choices, with course size diminishing proportionately. Add the wine pairing, which doesn’t skimp on quality or quantity.
paragraph2: In the heart of Buenos Aires' Colegiales neighborhood, Chef Antonio Soriano is redefining Argentine cuisine at Astor Manduque Porteño. This intimate restaurant offers a constantly evolving menu that showcases Soriano's innovative approach to traditional dishes. Adventurous diners can indulge in creative offerings such as blood sausage tempura and beef tongue salad, with the option to choose from three, five, or all eight available dishes. paragraph1: When Daryl Dixon was introduced in the third episode of “The Walking Dead” in 2010, few viewers could have predicted this half-feral-looking character would end up leading the series. Or that Daryl, played by Norman Reedus, would headline a spinoff set in France. “We wanted to reinvent the show,” Reedus, 55, said in a video interview from Paris. “We just didn’t want to do the same storytelling as in Georgia,” he continued, referring to the location for most of the original series, “and we didn’t want to make an American tourist version of France. So we got French writers. We fought to have French as much as English.” Season 2 of “The Walking Dead: Daryl Dixon” premieres Sept. 29 on AMC, but the new franchise is so successful that Reedus (who also appeared this year in the film “The Bikeriders” and has a second career as a photographer) is already working on the next installment in Spain. He talked about his connection with rock, art and food, as well as his 5-year-old daughter’s influence on his reading. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.
paragraph2: Daryl Dixon, portrayed by Norman Reedus, has undergone a remarkable transformation from a minor character in "The Walking Dead" to the central figure of a successful spinoff series. Set against the backdrop of France, this new series showcases Daryl's journey in a foreign land, providing a fresh perspective distinct from the original series that unfolded in Georgia. Reedus, deeply involved in the creative process, emphasizes how the incorporation of French elements and local writers has enriched the narrative, allowing for a unique storytelling experience that stands apart from its predecessor. The series' success is evident, with a second season already premiering and plans for future projects in Spain, further expanding its global footprint. Beyond his role as Daryl, Reedus is a man of many talents, engaging in film and photography, showcasing his versatility and passion for the arts. In his personal life, Reedus finds inspiration and influence from his young daughter, who has notably shaped his reading habits, offering a glimpse into the softer side of the actor whose on-screen persona is often seen navigating the harsh realities of a post-apocalyptic world.

paragraph1: I met my partner when I was just nineteen, serving drinks at a local bar where life seemed simpler than it is now. Unlike my mother and grandmother, who followed the traditional path of early marriage and settled domesticity, our relationship took a different turn. We fell hard and fast, young and fearless enough to pack our lives into boxes and move to a new state, where we adopted our beloved puppy, Mansfield, who became our first shared responsibility. There was a time when marriage seemed inevitable – my partner even bought a ring – but I wasn't ready then, and somehow, the right moment never came again. Sometimes I wonder if I've disappointed my family by not following in their conventional footsteps, but our love story has written its own rules. Society's expectations weigh heavily at times, whispering doubts about the legitimacy of a partnership without marriage certificates and shared last names. Yet, I've learned to navigate these waters with a practiced smile and well-timed jokes, masking the complexity of our chosen path. Behind my carefully curated image of success and contentment lies a deeper truth: that love doesn't always need traditional validation to be real, even if explaining that to others remains a constant challenge.
paragraph2: But the truth is that my circumstances were different from my mother’s and grandmother’s. First, we never got married. We met when I was 19, tending bar at an on-campus performing arts center. I gave him a free drink, and he took out my recycling. He was so handsome that he should have been vain, but he wasn’t, and he liked animals more than people. We merged our lives and moved to a new state. We adopted a hound puppy and named him Mansfield, after the town where we fell in love. Early on, my partner bought a ring and then returned it, correctly assuming that I wasn’t ready for marriage. He didn’t mention this until years later when he had three jalapeño margaritas on vacation and confessed, sputtering, “Did I never tell you that?” By the time I was 30, most of our friends were married, but it had never felt like the right time for us. When people asked him why we hadn’t tied the knot, he would say that he was waiting for me to propose. I’d cite economics and feminism while harboring a feeling I admitted to no one: Things had gotten hard at times, and someday I might need an out. Our life was beautiful but not without its shadows, a fact that I hid behind a veneer of professional success and witty banter.

paragraph1: But it doesn’t mean cudgeling her with them. Once you’ve said your piece and listened to what she has to say in her defense, repeating the same arguments over and over would be the act of a bully. Citizens, let alone family members, shouldn’t be eager to direct vitriol against people whose political views they don’t share. If the rest of your family wants to go on doing that, you should tell them that they’re being unkind and unhelpful. Partyism is a morally debased form of political discourse. A friend of mine who is active in progressive politics and served in the Biden administration has a mother who voted for Trump. The mother, who is Black, Southern and religiously devout, is a single-issue voter: She’s fervently opposed to abortion. My friend deeply disagrees with her mother’s position but finds it intelligible. They’ve made their peace.
paragraph2: Political disagreements within families can strain relationships, making it crucial to maintain respectful dialogue rather than resorting to hostile exchanges. When family members repeatedly attack each other over political views, it crosses into bullying territory, creating deep wounds that can be difficult to heal. A notable example is the relationship between a former Biden administration official and her mother, whose story illustrates how complex family political dynamics can be navigated successfully. Despite being Black, Southern, and deeply religious, the mother voted for Trump primarily due to her strong anti-abortion stance. Her daughter, though actively involved in progressive politics, chose to understand rather than condemn her mother's position. Their ability to reach a mutual understanding, despite fundamentally different political views, demonstrates how families can maintain loving relationships even when they disagree on significant issues. This approach of empathy and respect proves far more constructive than perpetual conflict and antagonism.

paragraph1: The Cable Factory, a sprawling limestone-brick complex in the formerly industrial western area, has undergone a stunning transformation from a hub of industry to a vibrant cultural destination. Today, the facility is home to a diverse array of art-related spaces, including studios, performance areas, galleries, schools, and museums. Notably, the Finnish Museum of Photography recently showcased a thought-provoking exhibition of politically charged photographs, cementing the Cable Factory's status as a thriving arts center.
paragraph2: Culture Factory, 2 p.m. At the Cable Factory, a hulking limestone-brick factory complex, production has shifted from cables to culture. Located in the once-industrial west, this seven-story former manufacturing facility is today home to a mix of art studios, performance spaces, galleries, schools and museums. While exploring the site, don’t overlook the Finnish Museum of Photography (admission, €8), which recently hosted an exhibition of poignant, politically themed photographs.

paragraph1: Andrey, once a vibrant part of the stoner bohemian community in the Pacific Northwest, found himself adrift as he transitioned from a promising yet indolent high school student to a young adult struggling to find his footing. Surrounded by a tight circle of gamer friends, Andrey was known for his sharp intellect and laid-back demeanor. However, as the years passed, he found himself caught in a cycle of transient minimum-wage jobs, his lack of direction becoming a growing concern for his friends, Sam and Olga. Both stage hands by profession, Sam and Olga worried about Andrey's future and endeavored to help by introducing him to their line of work. Despite their best efforts, Andrey's erratic behavior began to surface, resulting in a series of work-related incidents that raised red flags. Recognizing the need for professional help, Sam and Olga gently encouraged Andrey to see a therapist. During a pivotal session in 2018, Andrey bravely shared a harrowing experience from his past—the traumatic memory of his twin sister Sasha's drowning when they were just eight years old. This unresolved grief had cast a long shadow over his life, manifesting in the stories he crafted as a means of keeping Sasha's memory alive and managing his profound loss. Acknowledging this deep-seated pain marked a turning point for Andrey, offering a glimmer of hope for healing and a path toward reclaiming his future.
paragraph2: Up until his mid-20s, Andrey could blend in with the stoner bohemians of the Pacific Northwest. In high school, he was a bright, if lazy, student, with a tight group of friends who were all avid gamers like him. After he graduated, Sam and Olga watched with concern as he bounced from one minimum-wage job to another. They had hoped he would go on to college for art or music, but didn’t push. They both worked as stage hands, with good union jobs, and he seemed eager to do the same. Then things unraveled. His roommates kicked him out, and he moved to the couch in Sam and Olga’s one-bedroom apartment in Vancouver. They helped him get work as a stage hand, but there began to be “incidents,” odd and threatening behavior that upset their co-workers. Sam and Olga made him an appointment with a therapist. At first, he was open to treatment, his medical records show. “I feel like I’m driving my friends away,” he told a therapist in 2018, when he was 26. “I used to be able to talk to people,” he said. “Now they’re not interested.” In that session, he told the therapist about the family tragedy, a reservoir of pain he had walled off for years. When he was 8, he watched his twin sister, Sasha, drown in a duck pond in a neighbor’s yard. The children were alone. He had tried to save her. “I’ve thought about it to exhaustion,” he said. “I’ve incorporated her into these stories I make up.”

paragraph1: In “Dawn” (on Hulu and Max), which was directed by Matt Reeves and takes place about “10 winters” after the events of “Rise,” humans encounter Caesar’s camp and ask him to help them restart a dam for their survival. Caesar, being the benevolent leader he is, obliges, but is met with resistance from Koba (Toby Kebbell), an ape who saw the worst of humanity in captivity before his escape. Koba plots to overthrow Caesar by making it look like humans murdered him, and therefore leads a crew of apes to attack the humans’ compound. Caesar, however, survives and must break one of his cardinal rules: “Ape not kill ape.”
paragraph2: In the gripping film "Dawn," directed by Matt Reeves, the fragile peace between humans and apes is put to the test. Ten years after the events of "Rise," a desperate group of humans seeks the help of Caesar, the wise and benevolent leader of a thriving ape community, to revive a dormant dam crucial to their survival. Caesar, driven by a desire for coexistence, agrees to assist, but his decision is met with fierce opposition from Koba, a scarred and vengeful ape fueled by a deep-seated hatred for humans. As Koba's treachery unfolds, Caesar is forced to confront the very principles he has sworn to uphold, including his sacred rule against apes killing one another.

paragraph1: ‘Life of Belle’ Stream it on Tubi. Security monitors also capture the mom’s increasingly erratic behavior, like when she empties the house of food, convinced it’s poison. What mom doesn’t remove are the knives — the first clue that the home will soon become a house of horrors. This feature debut from the writer-director Shawn Robinson looks a lot like other low-budget found footage horror films. Like “Paranormal Activity,” it’s set inside a house. Like “He’s Watching,” its leads are a brave young brother and sister. But in those films, otherworldly forces invade domestic space. Here, Robinson takes a disturbingly different path, using a parent’s real, untreated mental illness as the antagonistic force, forgoing metaphor. Far from being exploitative, the film extends compassion toward the suffering of both parent and child. The Robinson family is related in real life — and their performances are scary movie naturalism at its best.
paragraph2: In the unsettling found footage horror film "Life of Belle," now streaming on Tubi, a family's security monitors capture the disturbing descent of a mother into erratic behavior. As she systematically removes food from the house, convinced it's poisoned, a sense of unease settles over the viewer. The ominous decision to leave the knives behind is a harbinger of the danger that's to come. Unlike its supernatural predecessors "Paranormal Activity" and "He's Watching," "Life of Belle" grounds its horror in the all-too-real issue of untreated mental illness. Director Shawn Robinson's decision to cast his own family members pays off, as they deliver naturalistic performances that add to the film's sense of unease. With its low-budget aesthetic and unflinching portrayal of a family in crisis, "Life of Belle" is a chilling reminder that sometimes the most terrifying monsters are the ones that lurk within.

paragraph1: Postcard From the Future Months into dating, my girlfriend and I sat across from another couple and drank margaritas. “If we ever get married,” I said, “we’re going to combine our last names to create a new one: Lavisi.” Our friends laughed at our plan, made so early in our relationship. One of them addressed the free postcard that came with our check to our future selves: “Dani and Jen Lavisi, 123 Lesbian Lane, Lesbos, Greece.” It hung on our fridge for five years — a joke that became a prophecy when that same friend married us and we legally changed our names. — Danielle Lavisi
paragraph2: In the early days of my relationship with Jen, we found ourselves enjoying drinks with another couple. In a playful moment, I suggested that if we ever got married, we should combine our last names to become "Lavisi." Our friends found this amusing and, in good humor, wrote a postcard addressed to "Dani and Jen Lavisi" at a fictional address in Lesbos, Greece. We stuck that postcard on our fridge, where it remained for five years, transforming from a lighthearted joke into a prophetic symbol of our future. Eventually, the same friend who wrote the postcard officiated our wedding, and we legally adopted the combined last name, Lavisi.

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.

Paragraph 1:
Postcard From the Future Months into dating, my girlfriend and I sat across from another couple and drank margaritas. “If we ever get married,” I said, “we’re going to combine our last names to create a new one: Lavisi.” Our friends laughed at our plan, made so early in our relationship. One of them addressed the free postcard that came with our check to our future selves: “Dani and Jen Lavisi, 123 Lesbian Lane, Lesbos, Greece.” It hung on our fridge for five years — a joke that became a prophecy when that same friend married us and we legally changed our names. — Danielle Lavisi

Paragraph 2:
In the early days of my relationship with Jen, we found ourselves enjoying drinks with another couple. In a playful moment, I suggested that if we ever got married, we should combine our last names to become "Lavisi." Our friends found this amusing and, in good humor, wrote a postcard addressed to "Dani and Jen Lavisi" at a fictional address in Lesbos, Greece. We stuck that postcard on our fridge, where it remained for five years, transforming from a lighthearted joke into a prophetic symbol of our future. Eventually, the same friend who wrote the postcard officiated our wedding, and we legally adopted the combined last name, Lavisi.
