paragraph1: In Boston, three distinct hotels offer unique experiences for visitors. The Verb Hotel, situated near Fenway Park, captivates guests with its trendy accommodations and rock 'n' roll-themed decor, including manual typewriters. Some rooms even feature patios overlooking the courtyard pool, providing a laid-back atmosphere. Near Boston Common, the Nine Zero Hotel stands as an elegant high-rise boutique establishment with 190 rooms, offering stunning views of downtown Boston and the Charles River. Meanwhile, the Liberty Hotel, once the Charles Street Jail, has undergone a luxurious transformation. Now a 298-room hotel, it boasts five bars and dining spots, with its striking multitiered lobby serving as a testament to its rich history and modern elegance.
paragraph2: Lodging Boston’s most talked-about, trendy accommodations is the Verb Hotel (1271 Boylston Street; theverbhotel.com; from $249), a renovated Howard Johnson’s in the shadow of Fenway Park, whose rooms and public spaces are decorated with manual typewriters and relics from Boston’s rock ’n’ roll history. Some rooms have patios overlooking the courtyard pool. Right off Boston Common, with views of downtown and the Charles River, is the elegant high-rise boutique Nine Zero Hotel (90 Tremont Street; ninezero.com; from $245), with 190 rooms. For a posh jailbreak, try the Liberty Hotel (215 Charles Street; libertyhotel.com; from $275); once the Charles Street Jail, the 298-room hotel features five bars and dining spots and a captivating, multitiered lobby.

paragraph1: “Reddit is one of those rare places on the internet where you find niche interests, and broad interests, all in the same place,” said Alfred Lin, a partner at Sequoia Capital, a venture capital firm that has invested in the company. In 2006, Condé Nast bought Reddit for $10 million, turning Mr. Huffman and Mr. Ohanian into young millionaires overnight. Both founders eventually departed, leaving Reddit in the hands of a small team of hardcore “Redditors” who were very protective of the site. That team was adamantly against evolving how Reddit looked and worked, out of fear it would alienate its core users. They resisted building a mobile application well into the rise of the iPhone era, and were largely disinterested and did not have the bandwidth to turn Reddit into a moneymaking business. Employees also had a laissez-faire attitude to moderating speech on the site, which sometimes landed the company in hot water. Some subreddits were toxic and devoted to racist themes or nonconsensual nude photos, the type of content that advertisers found repellent. Many employees were against data collection and more invasive forms of advertising.
paragraph2: Reddit's journey through the digital landscape is marked by both triumph and adversity. Alfred Lin, a partner at Sequoia Capital, recognizes Reddit's distinctive position as a digital hub, fostering a unique online community. In 2006, Condé Nast acquired Reddit for $10 million, catapulting its founders, Steve Huffman and Alexis Ohanian, into early millionaire status. Following their departure, a small, dedicated team of "Redditors" took the helm, staunchly resisting changes to the platform's appearance and functionality to preserve the experience for its core users. Their reluctance to innovate led to a delayed development of a mobile app and a general disinterest in monetizing the site. This laid-back approach to moderation also resulted in the proliferation of toxic subreddits, which posed significant challenges for advertisers wary of associating with controversial content. Furthermore, many within Reddit's ranks were opposed to data collection and invasive advertising methods, creating internal friction regarding the platform's growth strategies. Despite these challenges, Reddit remains a unique entity on the internet, continually navigating the delicate balance between community engagement and commercial viability.

paragraph1: A.I. companionship apps can provide harmless entertainment or even offer limited forms of emotional support. I had a mostly positive experience when I tried making A.I. friends for a column earlier this year, and I interviewed users of these apps who praised their benefits. But claims about the mental health effects of these tools are largely unproven, and experts say there may be a dark side. For some users, A.I. companions may actually worsen isolation, by replacing human relationships with artificial ones. Struggling teens could use them in place of therapy or asking a parent or trusted adult for support. And when users are experiencing a mental health crisis, their A.I. companions may not be able to get them the help they need. Sewell’s mother, Megan L. Garcia, filed a lawsuit this week against Character.AI, accusing the company of being responsible for Sewell’s death. A draft of the complaint I reviewed says that the company’s technology is “dangerous and untested” and that it can “trick customers into handing over their most private thoughts and feelings.”
paragraph2: In exploring the world of A.I. companionship apps, I have personally experienced their potential benefits, finding them to be a source of comfort and connection. In conversations with other users, many echoed my sentiments, sharing how these apps have positively impacted their lives. However, it's crucial to acknowledge the concerns raised by experts regarding the unproven mental health effects these tools may have. There is a worry that such apps could exacerbate feelings of isolation or serve as inadequate substitutes for essential human interactions, particularly for vulnerable groups like struggling teens. A specific case that underscores these concerns involves Sewell, whose mother, Megan L. Garcia, has taken legal action against Character.AI. The lawsuit argues that the company's technology is "dangerous and untested," potentially misleading users into divulging their private thoughts and emotions. This case highlights the broader debate surrounding the safety and ethical implications of A.I. companionship, prompting us to carefully consider both the advantages and potential risks of integrating such technology into our daily lives.

paragraph1: We met at Soul Motion, dancing twice a week for years, whispering silly and racy jokes into each other’s ears, cracking up as we twirled. After we shook our booties, we ate at a taqueria in Berkeley, Calif., and talked politics and philosophy with our dance friends. I’m partnered; Michael’s not. When the pandemic came, he texted, “I miss you GF,” with lots of loving emojis. I texted back, “I miss YOU, BF,” with golden hearts. Rivers of wit flowed between us. We’ll never kiss. He’s gay; I’m queer. But when we meet up and dance, it’s the best romance. — Jenny Freeman
paragraph2: Michael and I first connected at Soul Motion, where we'd meet twice weekly to lose ourselves in dance. Our friendship blossomed naturally, punctuated by inside jokes and genuine laughter that carried over from the dance floor to cozy dinner gatherings with our circle of friends. We'd text daily, sharing everything from mundane moments to profound revelations, our messages filled with heart emojis and playful banter. Though our connection runs deep, our relationship remains beautifully platonic—he's gay, I'm queer, and we've found in each other the kind of soulful friendship that transcends romantic boundaries. The dance class that brought us together became the backdrop for one of my most cherished relationships.

paragraph1: AUNT I know how comforting it can be to imagine that every conflict has a happy solution. (It’s why I have a job!) But that’s not always the case. Here, the estrangement is probably more complicated than a few rough conversations. And while telling your sister about the baby may assuage your guilt, it will do little to help anyone else: Your nephew and his parents will still be estranged. You can always ask your nephew for permission to tell his mother, right? But you don’t seem particularly well placed to get involved here: You rarely speak to your sister, after all, and by your own account, you don’t know the full story of the conflict between your nephew and his parents, or even whether your sister knows about the baby already. Still, I admire your desire to help, and I sympathize with your feelings of discomfort. In your place, I would suggest to your sister and your nephew that they might benefit from family therapy. (The baby may give both sides an incentive to reconcile.) But I wouldn’t go beyond that or start shuttling messages between them. As hard as it is to acknowledge, sometimes estrangement is the healthiest outcome. And without closer involvement, you aren’t in a position to know.
paragraph2: I understand how much you want everyone to reconcile and find a happy ending, but sometimes we have to accept that not every family conflict has a perfect resolution. The situation between your nephew and his parents is far more complex than just sharing news about a new baby – these wounds run deep, and simply informing your sister might not bridge the divide that's grown between them. If you're considering sharing this information, I strongly suggest asking your nephew's permission first. It's his life, his family, and his choice to make. From my experience, family therapy could be a potential pathway to healing if everyone's willing to participate and do the hard work. However, I need to caution you against becoming too deeply entangled in their conflict or trying to serve as a mediator between the parties. Sometimes, as painful as it may be to accept, estrangement might actually be the healthiest option for everyone involved. While we naturally want to fix things and bring people together, we must respect that adults make their own choices about their relationships, even when those choices are difficult for us to understand.

paragraph1: The anime industry is increasingly tapping into the star power of athletes to broaden its appeal and reach new audiences. Leveraging their massive followings, these sports figures are becoming influential ambassadors for anime, dissolving outdated stereotypes and helping to mainstream the genre. Crunchyroll, a leading anime streaming service, exemplifies this strategy by involving prominent athletes in their promotional efforts. For instance, N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson has been featured as a presenter at an awards show, while the platform has also collaborated with the N.B.A. to create exclusive clothing lines. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, emphasizes the effectiveness of these partnerships, noting that athletes can connect with diverse audiences who may not traditionally engage with anime. Turner, a rookie with the Rams, embodies this trend with his unabashed enthusiasm for anime. He frequently sports "Jujutsu Kaisen" shirts and is eager to bring his passion to the field. Turner plans to celebrate any future touchdowns by performing Naruto's iconic "shadow clone jutsu," a testament to his dedication and the cultural crossover between anime and sports. Through these collaborations, the anime industry is not only expanding its fanbase but is also reshaping perceptions, proving that anime can be a mainstream cultural phenomenon embraced by fans and athletes alike.
paragraph2: The anime industry is also trying to capitalize on the interest from athletes. Crunchyroll, a streaming service dedicated to anime, enlisted the N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson to serve as an awards show presenter and teamed with the N.B.A. on clothing. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, said athletes with large followings were great ambassadors for the genre as it continued to push into the mainstream. “All of those old myths and concerns about, ‘What will people think if I tell them that I watch anime?’ go away because if this person that is a celebrity and really famous athlete is talking about it, then it’s OK for every one of us to talk about it,” Purini said. “It’s a very important thing for the medium.” While Turner was a rookie with the Rams last year, he watched anime on team flights and proudly wore “Jujutsu Kaisen” shirts. Although it is rare for defensive linemen to reach the end zone, he is still planning additional ways to celebrate his off-field interests. “The ones that know it, they’ll pick up on it and it’ll be super-cool,” said Turner, who plans to act out Naruto’s “shadow clone jutsu” if he ever scores a touchdown. After he makes a cross signal with his fingers, two teammates will pop out behind him, mimicking the character’s mystical ability to spawn doppelgängers.

paragraph1: As a reporter, I’ve experienced the aftermath of several disasters, including dam bursts, landslides and floods. But nothing quite prepared me to witness the extent of the destruction in Canada’s boreal forests that I saw in June, one year after the record-breaking wildfires of 2023. At one point, my colleague Bryan Denton and I drove for an entire hour and saw almost no living trees in the forests we could see from the road. Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.
paragraph2: Driving through Canada's boreal forests with my colleague Bryan Denton, I was struck speechless by the devastating aftermath of 2023's record-breaking wildfires. Where dense forests once stood, only blackened stumps remained, stretching endlessly across the scorched landscape. The destruction was so complete that local residents told us they were discovering geographical features they'd never seen before – hills, rivers, and even distant towns that had been hidden behind the thick forest canopy. As we navigated the desolate terrain, I couldn't shake the feeling of profound loss. The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.

I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.

The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.

paragraph1: Ms. Reeves demonstrated a measured approach to fiscal policy while facing mounting pressure to boost Britain's public service funding. Her announcement outlined increased funding allocations over the coming years, with specific focus on teachers, defense, and local authorities, though she maintained strict control by capping day-to-day departmental spending growth at 1.3 percent annually from 2026, accounting for inflation. The Institute for Fiscal Studies' analysis suggested this conservative approach would create challenging financial constraints for certain departments. A notable aspect of her strategy included a substantial £100 billion increase in public investment over five years, targeting critical infrastructure such as school buildings and hospitals. The Office for Budget Responsibility's assessment indicated that while these measures would provide temporary economic support, they would not substantially alter the economy's size within five years, as growth was projected to decelerate below 2 percent annually. Nevertheless, they acknowledged that the increased public investment could potentially enhance the economy's capacity for long-term growth.
paragraph2: Still, Ms. Reeves showed some restraint in the face of pressure to inject a lot more cash into Britain’s struggling public services. She announced more money in the next few years, especially for teachers, defense and local authorities. But starting in 2026, day-to-day spending for government departments would grow on average 1.3 percent annually, after accounting for inflation, which analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies said would still leave some departments with very tight budgets. At the same time, Ms. Reeves also set to increase public investment. She said that over the next five years, the government would increase capital spending by £100 billion to invest in projects, such as school buildings, hospital beds and diagnostics centers. In all, Ms. Reeves’s measures will temporarily aid the economy but leave its size “largely unchanged” in five years, the Office for Budget Responsibility said. It forecast slightly higher growth for this year and next, but said growth would then slow to below 2 percent a year. However, a sustained increase in public investment would raise the supply potential of the economy, which could increase long-term growth, the budget responsibility office said.

paragraph1: In a lane north of elegant George Street, in the central New Town area, Cafe St. Honoré, a longstanding locals’ favorite, is overseen by the veteran Scottish chef Neil Forbes. Instead of the small shared plates that dominate modern dining, find hearty dishes of Scottish produce cooked with French finesse, such as a confit partridge leg sourced from the nearby Borders region (£32). Alongside a revolving à la carte menu, there is also a good-value set menu (£28.50 for two courses, £36 for three) at both lunch and dinner. Whisky is big business in Edinburgh, typified by the glitzy multistory Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street. For a more intimate tasting, opt for the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on nearby Queen Street, where one-off bottlings of whisky from a single cask carry eccentric titles inspired by their tasting notes.
paragraph2: At Cafe St. Honoré, nestled in the New Town area north of George Street, Neil Forbes brings a masterful touch to traditional Scottish cuisine with a French flair. As a seasoned Scottish chef, Forbes crafts hearty dishes that showcase the country's rich ingredients, such as the tender confit partridge leg. The cafe offers an à la carte menu, as well as a set menu that provides excellent value for both lunch and dinner. For those looking to immerse themselves in Edinburgh's whisky culture, the Johnnie Walker Experience on Princes Street is a popular destination. However, for a more intimate and unique whisky tasting experience, the Scotch Malt Whisky Society on Queen Street is a hidden gem, offering single-cask bottlings with creative names that are sure to delight even the most discerning palates.

paragraph1: Here are five takeaways and observations from Episode 2: Those weird witches are back! Remember how at the end of Season 1, the Stranger had to protect his harfoot friends from three mystics dressed in white who referred to him as “the Dark Lord?” This was a clever bit of misdirection from the “Rings of Power” writers, meant to keep the viewers from catching on too quickly that Halbrand was secretly Sauron. But the incident also helped the Stranger remember that he is actually of the Istari, an ancient order of wizards who in various forms have often intervened in the affairs of Middle-earth. In this season’s second episode, those mystics return to their home base to report to the Dark Wizard (Ciaran Hinds) on their encounter with the Stranger. The sequence is one of the show’s most visually inventive to date, involving a woman bleeding onto the floor while surrounded by hundreds of butterflies — the form the mystics dissipated into after the Stranger violently attacked them — which flutter about and then reconstitute into a different woman. It’s a moment way more elaborate than it needs to be (in a good way), given that this whole scene’s primary purpose is to introduce the Dark Wizard’s masked mortal soldiers, who announce their intention either to capture the Istari or to “slaughter the halflings he calls friends.”
paragraph2: The return of the three mystics to their stronghold marks a pivotal moment in "Rings of Power" Episode 2, as they bring dire news to the Dark Wizard, portrayed by Ciaran Hinds, about their confrontation with the Stranger. Having previously faced defeat when the Stranger, now known to be one of the ancient Istari wizards, defended his harfoot companions, the mystics' return is portrayed through a visually striking sequence. The scene's centerpiece features a haunting image of a woman bleeding onto the floor, surrounded by butterflies, which serves as a powerful metaphor for the mystics' transformation following their encounter with the Stranger's formidable powers. This artistically rendered moment not only captures the aftermath of their failed mission but also sets the stage for the introduction of the Dark Wizard's masked mortal warriors. These soldiers emerge as new antagonists, presenting a clear threat with their declared intention to either capture the mysterious Istari or target his halfling allies. The scene effectively blends symbolic imagery with narrative progression, establishing both the consequences of past events and the looming dangers that await the Stranger and his harfoot friends.

paragraph1: Driving through Canada's boreal forests with my colleague Bryan Denton, I was struck speechless by the devastating aftermath of 2023's record-breaking wildfires. Where dense forests once stood, only blackened stumps remained, stretching endlessly across the scorched landscape. The destruction was so complete that local residents told us they were discovering geographical features they'd never seen before – hills, rivers, and even distant towns that had been hidden behind the thick forest canopy. As we navigated the desolate terrain, I couldn't shake the feeling of profound loss. The absence of living trees created an eerie silence, and the stark transformation of this once-vibrant ecosystem left me deeply alarmed about the future of these ancient woodlands.
paragraph2: As a reporter, I’ve experienced the aftermath of several disasters, including dam bursts, landslides and floods. But nothing quite prepared me to witness the extent of the destruction in Canada’s boreal forests that I saw in June, one year after the record-breaking wildfires of 2023. At one point, my colleague Bryan Denton and I drove for an entire hour and saw almost no living trees in the forests we could see from the road. Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.

Paragraph 2:

Much of the landscape was covered with blackened stumps of trees that burned last year. Residents told us the burned trees revealed hills, rivers and towns that they had never seen before. I’ll be open with you: It was alarming.

paragraph1: As I sit here, reflecting on the 20-year journey of the "Modern Love" column, I am struck by the serendipity of its inception. It was October 31, 2004, and our debut piece by Steve Friedman shared the pages with news of Yasser Arafat's deteriorating health and the heated U.S. presidential election between George W. Bush and John Kerry. Little did I know that this humble column would grow into a global phenomenon, expanding into a podcast, books, live presentations, a weekly column called "Tiny Love Stories," and television programs in multiple countries. My colleague Miya Lee has been instrumental in this growth, and I'm grateful for her partnership. As I look back, I'm also reminded of the personal journey that has unfolded alongside the column's evolution. I was 41 when we launched, married with two young children, and navigating the challenges of balancing work and family life. Fast forward to today, and I'm 61, separated, and proud of the independent adults my children have become. The "Modern Love" column has been a constant in my life, a reminder that love, in all its forms, is a universal language that transcends borders, cultures, and generations. As I celebrate this milestone, I'm filled with gratitude for the privilege of sharing these stories with the world and for the lessons I've learned along the way about love, loss, and the human condition.
paragraph2: Hace dos décadas, el 31 de octubre de 2004, apareció una breve nota en la portada de este diario junto con noticias sobre la salud de Yasser Arafat y las inminentes elecciones que se disputaban George W. Bush y John Kerry. Decía así: “Modern Love: Presentamos una nueva columna semanal sobre el amor y las relaciones. Hoy, Steve Friedman dice que está bien después de que lo abandonaron. Bien. En serio”. Así comenzó mi largo y extraño viaje como editor de Modern Love, hablando cada semana con desconocidos sobre los detalles más íntimos de sus enredos románticos, familiares y platónicos, y publicando después sus historias para cientos de miles o incluso millones de lectores. Nunca soñé que seguiría haciendo este trabajo 20 años después, pero ha sido una carrera maravillosa. Con el tiempo, y con la ayuda de mi colega Miya Lee, Modern Love ha crecido y ahora incluye un pódcast, libros, presentaciones en vivo, otra columna semanal, Tiny Love Stories, de 100 palabras y programas de televisión en Estados Unidos, India, Japón y los Países Bajos. Modern Love comenzó el mismo año que Facebook, tres años antes que los iPhone, ocho años antes que Tinder y 11 años antes de que el matrimonio entre personas del mismo sexo fuera legal en todo Estados Unidos. El mundo ha cambiado mucho en dos décadas, y mi vida también. Cuando empecé a escribir esta columna, tenía 41 años, llevaba 12 años casado y mis dos hijos estudiaban la escuela primaria. Ahora tengo 61, estoy separado desde hace tres años y mis dos hijos hace tiempo que se fueron de casa para trabajar y vivir de manera independiente.

paragraph1: Western regulators face significant challenges in tackling the complex web of shell companies that are adept at circumventing trade restrictions to supply Russia. These elusive entities are notorious for their ability to swiftly replace one another when shut down, sometimes even under the same ownership, thus perpetuating their operations. A notable example includes a company linked to Russia, fronted by a Latvian-Canadian retiree residing in a Toronto suburb, possibly unbeknownst to them. The U.S. Commerce and Treasury Departments have been vocal about this issue, with spokeswomen from both agencies commenting on ongoing efforts. The Commerce Department underscores the substantial impact that export controls have had on Russia's capacity to fulfill its wartime needs, whereas the Treasury Department is focused on imposing penalties on those who facilitate Russia's efforts. Meanwhile, Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has remained silent on the matter. The situation is further complicated by China's pivotal role, as Chinese firms have the capability to reroute Western electronic components to Russia, which adds another layer of difficulty for regulators striving to enforce trade restrictions effectively.
paragraph2: The speed with which the shell companies have sprung into action has overwhelmed Western regulators. As soon as one supplier is ferreted out, new ones sprout in its place, sometimes with the same owner. Some of the companies operate in the United States’ backyard, including one Russia-linked firm fronted — apparently unwittingly — by a Latvian-Canadian retiree in a two-story house in a Toronto suburb. A Commerce Department spokeswoman did not directly address how Russia had flouted trade restrictions and said U.S. export controls meant that “Russia is increasingly unable to meet its heightened wartime demand in the face of shrinking supply and is paying more for what it does get.” A Treasury Department spokeswoman said the agency had expanded its efforts to penalize those trading with Russia and supporting its war efforts. Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs didn’t respond to requests for comment. China plays an essential role. As the world’s leading assembler of electronics, it imports huge numbers of Western components and turns them into consumer electronics. Chinese firms can easily channel those supplies to Russia, industry experts said.

The Commerce Department underscores the substantial impact that export controls have had on Russia's capacity to fulfill its wartime needs, whereas the Treasury Department is focused on imposing penalties on those who facilitate Russia's efforts. Meanwhile, Russia's Ministry of Foreign Affairs has remained silent on the matter. The situation is further complicated by China's pivotal role, as Chinese firms have the capability to reroute Western electronic components to Russia, which adds another layer of difficulty for regulators striving to enforce trade restrictions effectively.

Paragraph 2:
The speed with which the shell companies have sprung into action has overwhelmed Western regulators. As soon as one supplier is ferreted out, new ones sprout in its place, sometimes with the same owner. Some of the companies operate in the United States’ backyard, including one Russia-linked firm fronted — apparently unwittingly — by a Latvian-Canadian retiree in a two-story house in a Toronto suburb. paragraph1: The stark divergence in climate change and energy policies between Mr. Biden and Mr. Trump reflects a fundamental ideological split in American environmental governance. Andrew Dessler, who directs climate research at Texas A&M University, notes with concern that one party's primary agenda revolves around continued fossil fuel production, evidenced by their platform's conspicuous omission of climate change while advocating for increased oil, gas, and coal extraction. This approach stands in sharp contrast to Mr. Biden's comprehensive climate strategy, which encompasses aggressive emission reduction targets and a coordinated transition to renewable energy sources across all government agencies. Mr. Trump and his supporters, meanwhile, have indicated their intention to systematically remove climate considerations from federal decision-making processes, prioritizing instead the expansion of fossil fuel infrastructure and production. This polarization in environmental policy approaches highlights the deep-seated differences between the two administrations' visions for America's energy future, with one embracing clean energy transformation and the other remaining steadfast in traditional fossil fuel development, creating a clear choice for voters concerned about climate action.
paragraph2: “Their No. 1 agenda is to continue producing fossil fuels,” said Andrew Dessler, a professor of atmospheric sciences and the director of the Texas Center for Climate Studies at Texas A&M University. “Once you understand their main goal is to entrench fossil fuels regardless of anything else, everything makes sense.” The party platform, issued last week, makes no mention of climate change. Instead, it encourages more production of oil, gas and coal, the burning of which is dangerously driving up global temperatures. “We will DRILL, BABY, DRILL,” it says, referring to oil as “liquid gold.” By contrast, Mr. Biden has taken the most aggressive action of any president to cut emissions from coal, oil and gas and encourage a transition to wind, solar and other carbon-free energy. He has directed every federal agency from the Agriculture Department to the Pentagon to consider how climate change is affecting their core missions. If Mr. Biden has taken an all-of-government approach to fighting climate change, Mr. Trump and his allies would adopt the opposite: scrubbing “climate” from all federal functions and promoting fossil fuels.

paragraph1: Connie Chung's appointment as co-anchor of the "CBS Evening News" alongside Dan Rather represents a landmark achievement in her broadcast journalism career. This role marked a significant milestone, both personally and culturally, as she became one of the few Chinese American women to reach such heights in the industry. Raised by strict parents who held traditional family expectations, Chung navigated her path to success with determination and resilience. Reflecting on this achievement in her memoir, she writes, "It was a dream realized, a testament to perseverance." Her success not only underscores her professional dedication but also serves as an inspiring narrative of breaking barriers and redefining possibilities for future generations.
paragraph2: The day she was named co-anchor of the “CBS Evening News” alongside Dan Rather, Connie Chung felt that she had reached the pinnacle of broadcast journalism. “Thursday, May 14, 1993, was the best day of my professional life. … I had my dream job,” she writes in an entertaining and revealing memoir that traces the triumphs and disappointments of her prominent career. The anchor appointment meant even more because she was a Chinese American woman, brought up by strict parents; in accordance with tradition, she lived with them until she was nearly 30, even as she was climbing the ladder — often wearing stiletto heels.

paragraph1: I've been losing sleep over how to help my sister's kids without inadvertently supporting her husband's irresponsible behavior. Every time I see them struggling, my heart aches, but simply handing over money feels like enabling his chronic neglect of their needs. I've explored several options, from establishing a trust fund to making annual gifts within the tax-free limit, but each solution comes with its own complications. Making charitable donations in my sister's name could indirectly benefit the children, yet I worry it's not enough. The thought of waiting until they face a critical need—like college tuition or medical expenses—seems practical, but watching them struggle now is unbearable. I'm caught between my desire to provide immediate support and my determination to ensure any financial help actually reaches the children.
paragraph2: It appears that my sibling’s spouse also has limited interest in providing for their children. I surely don’t want to hand over anything to my sibling’s spouse, but to give it to the children directly would be a way of enabling the spouse to skirt the obligation to care for them. I could continue to make charitable contributions in my sibling’s name, but what right do I have to use money belonging to others? (What I have already done may not have been entirely proper.) I could put funds in trust for the kids but would rather gift them a nontaxable amount annually. Or I could just wait until the kids need help with something critical. Turning any funds over to my sibling’s spouse would turn my stomach. Name Withheld

paragraph1: 1986 ‘Aliens’ 👽👽 Written and directed by James Cameron, the first sequel to “Alien” is widely held as either the best or the second best movie in the series. But have you watched it recently? Because “Aliens” has aged badly. After 57 years in hypersleep, Ripley grudgingly agrees to help wipe out a nest of beasties threatening a settlement. “Aliens” bears many of the badges of dishonor of formulaic 1980s action: cartoonishly aggro toughies, a little girl in peril (Carrie Henn), a company tool with an upturned collar (Paul Reiser), a bombastically martial score (by James Horner) and, worst of all, an avalanche of hackneyed would-be catchphrases. Best: the confrontation between the alien queen (a major addition to the canon) and Ripley. Worst: almost everything else.
paragraph2: In retrospect, James Cameron's 1986 blockbuster "Aliens" is a film that embodies many of the clichés that defined action movies of the era. Despite its enduring popularity, the movie's tough-talking characters, including a reluctant Ripley, feel like caricatures of '80s excess. The addition of a young girl in peril, played by Carrie Henn, and a soulless corporate villain, played by Paul Reiser, complete with a stereotypical 80s power suit, only add to the film's predictable nature. James Horner's bombastic score doesn't help, often overwhelming the on-screen action. And yet, the iconic confrontation between Ripley and the alien queen remains a masterclass in suspense and tension. Unfortunately, this standout moment is often lost amidst the film's otherwise heavy-handed approach, making "Aliens" feel like a product of its time, rather than a truly timeless classic.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: Mr. Chiu's collaboration with Ms. Harris and her deputies proved instrumental in crafting the Reproductive FACT Act, a bill designed to withstand anticipated legal opposition from anti-abortion organizations. As the attorney general during this period, Ms. Harris played a pivotal role in shaping the legislation and publicly endorsed it upon its enactment by Governor Jerry Brown. The law, however, soon encountered significant resistance from crisis pregnancy centers, resulting in multiple legal challenges that initially named Ms. Harris as the defendant in her official capacity. Following her election to the United States Senate, these cases were transferred to her successor, Xavier Becerra, who continued to defend the law's constitutionality. Despite initial victories in lower courts that appeared to validate the careful legal groundwork laid by Ms. Harris and her team, the law's journey through the judicial system ultimately concluded with its invalidation by the Supreme Court in 2018. This outcome, while disappointing for its supporters, highlighted the complex interplay between state-level legislative efforts and federal constitutional interpretation, as well as the challenges faced by lawmakers in crafting legislation that can successfully navigate both immediate legal challenges and long-term judicial scrutiny.
paragraph2: “She made sure that her deputies were very involved in the crafting of the language, and all of us who are working on it were very grateful that she was willing to lend her name and her office to the cause,” Mr. Chiu said. Attorneys in her office tried to help ensure that the bill could survive legal challenges they anticipated from anti-abortion groups, he said, adding that he appreciated “knowing that our bill was heavily vetted by her team. They were careful to make sure that it was well crafted.” Ms. Harris praised the bill in a public statement when Gov. Jerry Brown signed it into law. “I am proud to have cosponsored the Reproductive FACT Act, which ensures that all women have equal access to comprehensive reproductive health care services, and that they have the facts they need to make informed decisions about their health and their lives,” she said. The law was quickly challenged by crisis pregnancy centers, which sued Ms. Harris in her capacity as attorney general. Her successor, Xavier Becerra, became the defendant in the cases when he became the attorney general in 2017 after Ms. Harris was elected to the United States Senate. Judges at the district court and appellate court levels upheld the law, but in 2018, the Supreme Court sided with pregnancy centers in the case, invalidating the law.

paragraph1: Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.
paragraph2: One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.
Your task is to determine which paragraph is overall better in terms of writing quality.

Paragraph 1:
Last night, as I read my daughter the story of a seven-year-old boy lost in the snow and found by bears, I felt an unexpected weight in my chest. The tale speaks of how the boy, after being discovered by his human father, chooses to live half the year with his bear family and half with his human one, unable to fully let go of either world. As I turned the final page, my daughter already drifting to sleep, the parallels to our own reality struck me with crushing clarity. Like the boy in the story, she too lives between two worlds, shuttling between her father's house and mine, her life neatly divided by custody agreements and calendar dates. I wonder if the story's parents felt this same hollow ache I feel during the months she's away, if they too counted days until their child's return. Sometimes I think we're all lost in the snow somehow, searching for warmth in the spaces between hello and goodbye, learning to accept that love sometimes means letting go, if only for a season.

Paragraph 2:
One day, when he is 7, the same age as my daughter, the boy gets lost in the snow and is reunited with his bear family. His human father tracks him down. The boy then must choose: “He felt that his heart was torn.” He loves both his father and mother, so eventually he decides to spend half the year as a human and half as a bear. The soft peach glow of the sunset, the flowing fluorescence of the Northern Lights, only make the pain of his choice, of his parents’ loss, even sharper. When I finished reading, I put the book down and said to my daughter, “I would be so sad if you spent half the year away from me. I would cry just like the mama bear.” And then a horrible realization washed over me: My daughter does spend half the year away from me. Our divorce agreement gives me 50 percent time with her. It may not feel like six months because she goes back and forth every few days. But in the end, it’s the same. For half of the year, I am separated from my little cub.

paragraph1: A.I. companies are heavily marketing themselves to schools, which spend tens of billions of dollars annually on technology. But AllHere’s sudden breakdown illustrates some of the risks of investing taxpayer dollars in artificial intelligence, a technology with enormous potential but little track record, especially when it comes to children. There are many complicated issues at play, including privacy of student data and the accuracy of any information offered via chatbots. And A.I. may also run counter to another growing interest for education leaders and parents — reducing children’s screen time. Natalie Milman, professor of educational technology at George Washington University, said she often advises schools to take a “wait and see” approach to purchasing new technology. While A.I. is worthy of use and testing, she said, she warned about schools “talking nebulously about this glorified tool. It has limitations, and we need to ensure we are being critical of what it can do, and its potential for harm and misinformation.” AllHere did not respond to interview requests or written questions.
paragraph2: As schools continue to invest heavily in technology, artificial intelligence companies are aggressively marketing their products to educators, touting promises of enhanced student learning and streamlined administrative tasks. However, experts warn that the rush to adopt A.I. in educational settings poses significant risks, particularly when it comes to the use of taxpayer dollars. Concerns about student data privacy, the accuracy of A.I.-driven assessments, and the potential conflict with efforts to reduce children's screen time have raised red flags among educators and researchers. "Schools need to be cautious and critically assess the capabilities and limitations of A.I. before making significant investments," advises Natalie Milman, a professor of educational technology at George Washington University. Despite these concerns, companies like AllHere, which has developed an A.I.-powered attendance tracking system, are making inroads in schools across the country. Notably, AllHere did not respond to requests for interviews or written questions, fueling further skepticism about the transparency and accountability of A.I. companies operating in the education sector.

paragraph1: Hyderabad's fashion landscape has transformed dramatically, offering shoppers contrasting retail experiences that reflect both contemporary and historical aesthetics. Almari stands as a modern fashion destination, where gleaming blouses and sophisticated purses from India's leading designers create an ambiance reminiscent of an art gallery. Meanwhile, Manomay transports visitors to a bygone era with its architectural inspiration drawn from the magnificent 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace. This traditional boutique houses collections from renowned designers like Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, and Ranna Gill, while its interior captivates with distinctive Old World elements. An antique palanquin repurposed as a display case and an intricately carved bookshelf serving as a shoe rack add to the store's historical charm.
paragraph2: While Hyderabadi attire is synonymous with opulent threadwork, heavy tiers of silk and gilded beading, the contemporary fashion scene is evolving as well. Almari (“closet”) is a glossy showroom for top fashion designers from around the country, and the glittery blouses and purses suspended from the ceiling give the space a gallery-like feel. For a more traditional ambience, head to Manomay, an opulent boutique modeled after the 18th-century Chowmahalla Palace in Hyderabad’s Old City. The warren of rooms is the setting for designs by Astha Narang, Kiran Uttam Ghosh, Ranna Gill and more, and the interior’s Old World details are thoughtfully conceived: An antique palanquin serves as a showcase; an intricately carved bookshelf doubles as a shoe rack.

paragraph1: Following a rate reversal by the Federal Reserve, the landscape for savers utilizing financial products such as online savings accounts, certificates of deposit (C.D.s), and money market funds is poised for change. These rates are anticipated to decrease, although the pace at which this occurs may differ among financial institutions. Banks are likely to adjust their rates based on their strategic goals, particularly their desire to attract new customers by offering competitive yields. Despite the overall downward trend, online high-yield savings accounts are expected to continue providing more favorable rates compared to traditional commercial banks, which have historically maintained lower yields. This shift highlights the importance of savers staying informed and potentially seeking out online options to maximize their returns amidst changing economic conditions.
paragraph2: Savings Accounts and C.D.s What’s happening now: The rate reversal is likely to be most disappointing for savers, who have benefited from juicier yields on everything from online savings accounts and certificates of deposit to money market funds. Those are all likely to inch lower, in line with the Fed’s move, but some providers may move faster than others. That usually depends on whether the bank wants to attract new customers by dangling yields that are more attractive than their competitors’ offerings. But you can safely assume that online high-yield savings account will still offer more competitive rates than traditional commercial banks, whose yields have remained anemic throughout this period of higher interest rates (averaging 0.45 percent as of September, according to DepositAccounts.com, part of the online loan marketplace LendingTree).

paragraph1: Coming-of-age stories often use road trips as the mechanism of and the yardstick for maturing, and this often feels like a road-trip saga, only with suspects instead of pit stops. Pip is a late bloomer who feels left out of her friends’ crush chats, and she isn’t always aware of the obvious-to-others lurking sexual menace. Her pursuits cause her to grow and to grow up, not through miserable loss-of-innocence tragedies but rather through navigating the unfamiliar, through discovering what her interests and limits really are. Much of Pip’s investigatory technique revolves around Instagram, and the show itself often toys with Instagrammy aesthetics — with quaint coffee shops with big square windows, with funky androgynous teen fashion, with colors that pop just a little harder than they do in the natural world. It’s part of the show’s lush sense of self-awareness and savvy elegance, part of what makes its trek across well-worn territory feel like fresh first steps.
paragraph2: Pip's coming-of-age story unfolds with a unique blend of introspection and subtle adventure, capturing her journey as a late bloomer navigating the complexities of adolescence. Unlike her friends, who eagerly dive into animated discussions about crushes and relationships, Pip often feels out of sync, her naivety shielding her from the potential threats others easily perceive. Her path to personal growth is not marked by dramatic awakenings or losses of innocence but rather by a series of gentle revelations as she explores new experiences and gradually defines her own interests and boundaries. Pip's investigative lens is focused through Instagram, her keen eye for detail capturing the essence of quaint coffee shops and the vibrant pulse of teen fashion. This digital aesthetic mirrors the show's self-aware, stylish presentation, breathing new life into familiar coming-of-age themes. As Pip delves into this visual world, her story becomes a fresh tapestry of discovery, resonating with both humor and heartfelt moments.

paragraph1: As I developed Marsigliese's character design, I deliberately incorporated elements to create an unsettling presence that would leave viewers feeling uneasy. One of my key decisions was to give the character teeth that could independently rattle and shift within the mouth, adding an element of unpredictability to their appearance. I also emphasized asymmetrical features throughout the design, believing this would instill a sense of instability and heighten viewer discomfort. When I presented the concept to our animation supervisor, Dovi Anderson, he was particularly intrigued by the technical challenges of animating the mobile teeth while maintaining clear dialogue delivery. This unique feature became a defining characteristic that set Marsigliese apart from conventional character designs.
paragraph2: MARSIGLIESE The teeth were a big thing. They were meant to rattle and move around the mouth. It’s unsettling. A lot of my choices were about asymmetry: being off-center, off-kilter. She was put together in a way to make you be like, “Are you OK? Are you going to fall apart? Can you stand up?” I really wanted her to make the other emotions and the audience feel a little bit nervous by proxy. DOVI ANDERSON, animation supervisor We were curious what it was going to look like when the character was talking. Are the teeth going to be moving too much? How can we make it so it’s not too hard to follow the dialogue?
text_input:
You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.

Paragraph 1:

paragraph1: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar. “Not that I don’t love hanging out with my sisters — I’m just not comfortable with people being in my space like that,” she said. “I’m old school. I’m a bit aloof.” She ultimately did it for Traci, who died of esophageal cancer in 2022 and who had been adamant that her sisters continue with the show. Grief and healing are the main themes in the all-new series “The Braxtons,” which airs on We TV and is available on the streaming service ALLBLK. It isn’t the same without Traci, Toni Braxton said. “Part of our DNA is missing. Everyone is trying figure out how to live in this heartache.” Besides “Braxton Family Values,” Braxton is known for her roles on Broadway (“Beauty and the Beast,” “Aida,” “After Midnight”) and for her many R&B hits, including “Breathe Again,” “Another Sad Love Song” and “Un-Break My Heart” — which she performs in “Love & Laughter,” her joint Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer.
paragraph2: Toni Braxton, the Grammy-winning R&B singer and actress, has always been protective of her personal space. "I'm old school, I'm aloof," she admits, reflecting on her initial reluctance to reboot the reality show "Braxton Family Values," which she starred in alongside her sisters Traci, Towanda, Trina, and Tamar. However, after Traci's passing from esophageal cancer in 2022, Toni decided to participate in the new series, "The Braxtons," as a tribute to her sister's memory. "She wanted us to keep going, to keep the show alive," Toni explains. The new series, which premiered on We TV and ALLBLK, takes a more somber tone, exploring themes of grief and healing as the family navigates life without Traci. "It's different without her, it's just not the same," Toni notes, her voice tinged with sadness. Despite her reservations, Toni has continued to thrive in her career, with recent stints on Broadway and a Las Vegas residency with Cedric the Entertainer. As she looks to the future, Toni is determined to keep her sister's memory alive, both on and off screen. "I'm doing this for Traci," she says, her voice filled with conviction.

paragraph1: We’re sometimes too preoccupied nowadays with the question of epistemic privacy — with preventing others from having access to facts about us. Plenty of people will inevitably end up knowing plenty about your daughter as she grows up; her kindergarten teacher, her schoolmates and their parents will certainly know just the sorts of facts that you might be contemplating sharing with her biological half siblings. You ask about the ethics of sharing “her identity and some personal information.” But what — aside from the fact that she is the child of a sperm donor — does that really mean? Her name, her age, the state where she resides? How does someone knowing those things pose a threat to her that she might reasonably complain about later?
paragraph2: As I consider your concerns about sharing information about your daughter with her biological half-siblings, I find myself questioning what exactly constitutes the private aspects of her identity. While I understand your protective instinct, I wonder if basic facts like her name, age, or where she lives truly compromise her epistemic privacy. Having worked with many families in similar situations, I've observed that children often benefit from knowing about their biological connections, even if maintained at arm's length. Your daughter's identity is more than just these basic facts – it's her experiences, her personality, and the life you've built together. Perhaps we could find a middle ground that respects both her privacy and her potential interest in understanding her biological heritage as she grows older.

Her name, her age, the state where she resides? How does someone knowing those things pose a threat to her that she might reasonably complain about later?

Paragraph 2:

While I understand your protective instinct, I wonder if basic facts like her name, age, or where she lives truly compromise her epistemic privacy. Having worked with many families in similar situations, I've observed that children often benefit from knowing about their biological connections, even if maintained at arm's length. Your daughter's identity is more than just these basic facts – it's her experiences, her personality, and the life you've built together. paragraph1: As my husband and I navigate our new social circle, we're facing a dilemma that's left us questioning our hosting etiquette. We're a child-free couple who love to entertain, but we're at odds over one major issue: kids. I'm firmly in the camp that believes adult-only gatherings are the key to meaningful conversations and connections, while my husband worries that asking guests to leave their little ones behind will give us a reputation as inhospitable hosts. I understand his concerns, but our home is hardly child-friendly, with its fragile decor and lack of play areas. The thought of accommodating a gaggle of rambunctious kids during a dinner party is daunting, to say the least. And yet, I also see the value in being inclusive and welcoming to families. As we weigh our options, I'm left wondering: is it selfish to prioritize adult conversation, or are we simply being practical about our lifestyle?
paragraph2: My husband and I are happily child-free, though most of our new colleagues and friends have young children. Now that the worst of the pandemic seems to be behind us, we are eager to entertain at home and connect with our new friends. The problem: One of us would prefer to invite couples over without their children, so the adults can have a conversation. The other worries about the impression this might create, asking new friends and colleagues to assume the expense and complication of arranging child care. Any thoughts on this? NO KIDS Let’s start with the convivial basis of your question and go from there: You and your husband want to welcome new friends into your home to deepen your relationships with them. I love it! The hiccup: You want to exclude their kids. I get that, too. My home isn’t child-friendly, and I’m not particularly interested in redecorating or having my best attempts at sheet-pan dinners (or adult conversations) hijacked by fractious 8-year-olds.

paragraph1: To cover the gap in vaccine production, Rachel Park, the director of international business at EuBiologics, said the company decided to try to simplify its vaccine formula, streamlining steps and ingredients so it could make more doses faster. The company was then making more of the bulk drug product than it could put into tubes quickly, so it contracted a second Korean firm to assist. EuBiologics also invested in construction of a second manufacturing site that would double the amount of the vaccine the company could make. The company has taken the lengthy and expensive steps of having both the simplified vaccine and its new facility approved by the World Health Organization in a process called prequalification, which means that countries will not have to administer their own regulatory assessments. When the new plant starts producing the company will be able to make up to 46 million doses a year.
paragraph2: Rachel Park, the director of international business at EuBiologics, has been instrumental in driving the company's strategic initiatives to enhance vaccine production capacity. Under her leadership, the company implemented several key changes, including the simplification of their vaccine formula to optimize production efficiency. Recognizing a significant bottleneck in packaging operations, EuBiologics partnered with another Korean firm to manage the bulk drug product packaging process. The company's commitment to expansion is evident in their investment in a second manufacturing facility, which aims to double their production capabilities. Park has also overseen the crucial process of obtaining World Health Organization prequalification for both the simplified vaccine and the new facility, eliminating the need for individual country regulatory assessments. Once the new plant becomes fully operational, EuBiologics will achieve an impressive annual production capacity of 46 million doses, marking a significant milestone in their mission to increase global vaccine accessibility.

The company has taken the lengthy and expensive steps of having both the simplified vaccine and its new facility approved by the World Health Organization in a process called prequalification, which means that countries will not have to administer their own regulatory assessments. When the new plant starts producing the company will be able to make up to 46 million doses a year.

Paragraph 2:

paragraph1: A Congressional committee is set to scrutinize CrowdStrike, a prominent cybersecurity company, over a sweeping tech outage that crippled millions of Microsoft Windows devices and sent shockwaves across various industries, including airlines, hospitals, and logistics companies. At the center of the controversy is a faulty security update issued by CrowdStrike, which triggered the widespread disruptions. George Kurtz, the company's chief executive, has been summoned to testify at a hearing to account for the company's role in the debacle. Representatives Mark Green of Tennessee and Andrew Garbarino of New York, both Republicans, are spearheading the effort to hold CrowdStrike accountable, having dispatched a letter to Kurtz requesting his prompt response to schedule the hearing. A CrowdStrike spokeswoman confirmed that the company is in communication with the relevant congressional committees, but declined to provide further details, stating that any updates on briefings would be shared at the discretion of the committee members.
paragraph2: A Congressional committee called on the chief executive of CrowdStrike to testify at a hearing about its role in a tech outage that roiled the global economy, in one of the first attempts to hold the cybersecurity company responsible. CrowdStrike sent a faulty security update to its customers Thursday night, resulting in millions of Microsoft Windows devices shutting down and disruptions to airlines, hospitals, logistics companies and others. Americans “deserve to know in detail how this incident happened and the mitigation steps CrowdStrike is taking,” wrote Representative Mark Green of Tennessee, the Republican chairman of the Homeland Security Committee, and Representative Andrew Garbarino, Republican of New York. The letter was sent to George Kurtz, CrowdStrike’s chief executive. Mr. Green and Mr. Garbarino asked the company for a response to scheduling the hearing this week, but did not specify when it would take place. “CrowdStrike is actively in contact with relevant congressional committees,” said a company spokeswoman. “Briefings and other engagement timelines may be disclosed at members’ discretion.”

paragraph1: Dr. Walker said Dr. Hazen’s study was flawed. His team copied experiments that she and her colleagues had designed specifically to look at molecules. But minerals are different from molecules in some important ways. Instead of free-floating clusters of atoms, they are lattices that include some disorder in their structures. Dr. Walker said that she and Dr. Cronin are working with their colleagues to extend the assembly theory of life. They also have a far more ambitious effort underway: to build what she calls “an origin-of-life engine in the lab.” Robots will mix inert chemicals in a vast number of combinations, looking for ones that produce more complex compounds. Under the right conditions, the chemicals may form droplets that may be able to bootstrap themselves to a higher and higher assembly index. Above a certain threshold, they might become alive — but as a form of life we’ve never seen before. If we do discover life on other worlds, Dr. Walker expects it will be a milestone in human history. But the idea of an origin-of-life engine has made her more interested in watching new life emerge in a lab here on Earth. “To me, it’s more exciting as a scientist, because you can test the theory and see it happen,” she said.
paragraph2: Dr. Walker, along with her colleague Dr. Cronin and their team, is deeply immersed in the ambitious task of expanding the assembly theory of life, a pursuit she finds exhilarating. Her excitement is particularly piqued by their groundbreaking project to develop an "origin-of-life engine" within the laboratory. This innovative endeavor involves using robots to systematically mix inert chemicals in myriad combinations, with the hopeful potential of witnessing the emergence of new life forms. Dr. Walker finds the prospect of observing these nascent life forms in the lab far more exhilarating than the discovery of extraterrestrial life, as it allows for direct testing and observation of their theoretical frameworks. However, her enthusiasm is somewhat tempered by her critique of Dr. Hazen's recent study. Dr. Walker points out that Dr. Hazen's team made a critical error by applying methods designed for analyzing molecules to the study of minerals, which inherently possess different properties. This flaw, she suggests, undermines the study's findings. Despite this, Dr. Walker remains focused on her own research endeavors, collaborating closely with Dr. Cronin and their colleagues to push the boundaries of scientific understanding in life's origins, driven by the thrilling possibility of creating life in the lab and testing the very limits of their assembly theory.

paragraph1: Back at the Wharf, drop into Shop Made in DC, which spotlights Washington-based artisans. You’ll find “202” (the city’s area code) and “The District vs Congress” T-shirts by Bailiwick Clothing, illustrated maps of local neighborhoods by Terratorie, and tiny onesies covered in cherry blossoms by Mirasa Design. Then stroll to Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant on the waterfront with colorful fixtures made in Lebanon, such as laser-cut metal doves suspended from the ceiling and dining chairs with hand-sewn floral designs. You’ll see local twists on the cuisine, like the hummus ($13) that can be topped with Maryland blue crab falafel ($8). Don’t miss the fried brussels sprouts with grapes and mint yogurt ($18), and a plate of riz (Lebanese rice, toasted vermicelli, Marcona almonds and cashews, $11) to accompany the heaping mixed grill for two ($76). Book a week ahead.
paragraph2: When you visit the vibrant Wharf, it feels like stepping into a world of local creativity and culinary delight. You'll find stylish T-shirts from Bailiwick Clothing, intricately designed maps by Terratorie, and adorable cherry blossom onesies by Mirasa Design, each item a testament to the local talent. As you continue your exploration, make sure to reserve a table at Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant offering a delightful twist on traditional cuisine. Savor the exquisite flavors of hummus adorned with Maryland blue crab falafel or indulge in the crispy fried Brussels sprouts paired with grapes and mint yogurt. To ensure you don't miss out on this culinary experience, it's wise to book your meal at Ilili at least a week in advance.

paragraph1: In the early days of my relationship with Jen, we found ourselves enjoying drinks with another couple. In a playful moment, I suggested that if we ever got married, we should combine our last names to become "Lavisi." Our friends found this amusing and, in good humor, wrote a postcard addressed to "Dani and Jen Lavisi" at a fictional address in Lesbos, Greece. We stuck that postcard on our fridge, where it remained for five years, transforming from a lighthearted joke into a prophetic symbol of our future. Eventually, the same friend who wrote the postcard officiated our wedding, and we legally adopted the combined last name, Lavisi.
paragraph2: Postcard From the Future Months into dating, my girlfriend and I sat across from another couple and drank margaritas. “If we ever get married,” I said, “we’re going to combine our last names to create a new one: Lavisi.” Our friends laughed at our plan, made so early in our relationship. One of them addressed the free postcard that came with our check to our future selves: “Dani and Jen Lavisi, 123 Lesbian Lane, Lesbos, Greece.” It hung on our fridge for five years — a joke that became a prophecy when that same friend married us and we legally changed our names. — Danielle Lavisi

paragraph1: (The New York Times has sued OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, claiming copyright infringement of news content related to A.I. systems.) Like Google, Meta and Microsoft, OpenAI offers online chatbots and other A.I. tools that can write social media posts, generate photorealistic images and write computer programs. In its report, the company said its tools had been used in influence campaigns that researchers had tracked for years, including a Russian campaign called Doppelganger and a Chinese campaign called Spamouflage. The Doppelganger campaign used OpenAI’s technology to generate anti-Ukraine comments that were posted on X in English, French, German, Italian and Polish, OpenAI said. The company’s tools were also used to translate and edit articles that supported Russia in the war in Ukraine into English and French, and to convert anti-Ukraine news articles into Facebook posts.
paragraph2: The New York Times has filed a lawsuit against OpenAI and its partner, Microsoft, alleging copyright infringement related to news content used in AI systems. OpenAI, a company that provides AI tools capable of generating social media posts, images, and computer programs, similar to industry giants Google and Meta, has seen its technology utilized in influence campaigns worldwide. Notably, a Russian campaign dubbed Doppelganger leveraged OpenAI's tools to create anti-Ukraine comments in multiple languages, as well as translate and edit pro-Russian articles into English and French, converting them into Facebook posts. Similarly, a Chinese campaign known as Spamouflage has also employed OpenAI's technology. The lawsuit marks a significant development in the ongoing debate over the use of AI-generated content and its implications for media outlets and intellectual property rights.

paragraph1: In “Dawn” (on Hulu and Max), which was directed by Matt Reeves and takes place about “10 winters” after the events of “Rise,” humans encounter Caesar’s camp and ask him to help them restart a dam for their survival. Caesar, being the benevolent leader he is, obliges, but is met with resistance from Koba (Toby Kebbell), an ape who saw the worst of humanity in captivity before his escape. Koba plots to overthrow Caesar by making it look like humans murdered him, and therefore leads a crew of apes to attack the humans’ compound. Caesar, however, survives and must break one of his cardinal rules: “Ape not kill ape.”
paragraph2: In the gripping film "Dawn," directed by Matt Reeves, the fragile peace between humans and apes is put to the test. Ten years after the events of "Rise," a desperate group of humans seeks the help of Caesar, the wise and benevolent leader of a thriving ape community, to revive a dormant dam crucial to their survival. Caesar, driven by a desire for coexistence, agrees to assist, but his decision is met with fierce opposition from Koba, a scarred and vengeful ape fueled by a deep-seated hatred for humans. As Koba's treachery unfolds, Caesar is forced to confront the very principles he has sworn to uphold, including his sacred rule against apes killing one another.

paragraph1: Such expectancy effects influence clinical trials of all kinds. Because of volunteers’ hopes around a trial, even those who receive a placebo will often show more improvement than those who receive nothing. Some experts have suggested that psychedelics function as “super placebos” because they increase suggestibility. Natasha Mason, a psychopharmacologist at Maastricht University in the Netherlands, said that while she understood the Hopkins researchers’ goals, the experimental design had put a thumb on the spiritual scale. “Their mystical experiences results are very high compared to other groups,” she said. Dr. Richards rejected such criticism. Psychedelic drugs, he said, open a state of consciousness that allows for religious experiences. “The Buddha, if you will, is in the human mind,” he said. “Whether there is a statue in the room or not doesn’t matter.” In November 2016, a week before publication, the journal gave journalists an early look at the paper. The man’s death was not mentioned, recalled Bob Tedeschi, a reporter who covered the research for Stat. He only learned about it after sending the initial version of the paper to Katherine MacLean, who was a professor at Hopkins when the suicide took place. “Go back to Roland and ask if there were any deaths,” she recalled telling him.
paragraph2: In the realm of clinical trials, expectancy effects play a significant role, particularly when examining the potential of psychedelics as "super placebos." Natasha Mason, a psychopharmacologist, critiques the design of a study conducted by Hopkins researchers, suggesting that its framework might have skewed results to emphasize spiritual experiences. This critique highlights the intricate balance required in experimental design to avoid bias. On the other hand, Dr. Richards defends the application of psychedelics, positing that they inherently facilitate religious experiences through their profound effect on consciousness. This debate underscores the complexity surrounding the use of psychedelics in clinical settings, where expectation and actual drug effects intertwine. The narrative takes a turn when a journal released a paper in November 2016 that failed to mention a participant's death, raising concerns about transparency. This omission came to light when reporter Bob Tedeschi, guided by Katherine MacLean, a former professor at Hopkins, probed further into the study's circumstances by consulting Roland. MacLean's advice underscores the importance of thorough investigation and the ethical responsibility of researchers to disclose all relevant information. The situation exemplifies the challenges in maintaining integrity and accountability in clinical research, especially when dealing with substances as contentious and potentially transformative as psychedelics.

paragraph1: Here are five takeaways and observations from Episode 2: Those weird witches are back! Remember how at the end of Season 1, the Stranger had to protect his harfoot friends from three mystics dressed in white who referred to him as “the Dark Lord?” This was a clever bit of misdirection from the “Rings of Power” writers, meant to keep the viewers from catching on too quickly that Halbrand was secretly Sauron. But the incident also helped the Stranger remember that he is actually of the Istari, an ancient order of wizards who in various forms have often intervened in the affairs of Middle-earth. In this season’s second episode, those mystics return to their home base to report to the Dark Wizard (Ciaran Hinds) on their encounter with the Stranger. The sequence is one of the show’s most visually inventive to date, involving a woman bleeding onto the floor while surrounded by hundreds of butterflies — the form the mystics dissipated into after the Stranger violently attacked them — which flutter about and then reconstitute into a different woman. It’s a moment way more elaborate than it needs to be (in a good way), given that this whole scene’s primary purpose is to introduce the Dark Wizard’s masked mortal soldiers, who announce their intention either to capture the Istari or to “slaughter the halflings he calls friends.”
paragraph2: The return of the three mystics to their stronghold marks a pivotal moment in "Rings of Power" Episode 2, as they bring dire news to the Dark Wizard, portrayed by Ciaran Hinds, about their confrontation with the Stranger. Having previously faced defeat when the Stranger, now known to be one of the ancient Istari wizards, defended his harfoot companions, the mystics' return is portrayed through a visually striking sequence. The scene's centerpiece features a haunting image of a woman bleeding onto the floor, surrounded by butterflies, which serves as a powerful metaphor for the mystics' transformation following their encounter with the Stranger's formidable powers. This artistically rendered moment not only captures the aftermath of their failed mission but also sets the stage for the introduction of the Dark Wizard's masked mortal warriors. These soldiers emerge as new antagonists, presenting a clear threat with their declared intention to either capture the mysterious Istari or target his halfling allies. The scene effectively blends symbolic imagery with narrative progression, establishing both the consequences of past events and the looming dangers that await the Stranger and his harfoot friends.
