paragraph1: 8) 2:30 p.m. Après ski ritual With Japan’s volcanic landscape, there are ample onsens (geothermal hot springs) in Niseko; taking to the waters at a public bathhouse is both an essential ritual of Japanese culture and part of the ski experience. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, in a ryokan (traditional Japanese inn) in Annupuri. Know the Japanese etiquette, such as bringing your own little “modesty towel” and soap to cleanse thoroughly before dipping, naked (no bathing suits allowed), into a communal outdoor pool. Like most onsen, this one is separated by gender. The outdoor pool, under a wood pergola and surrounded by snow and boulders, features mineral water pumped from the base of Mount Annupuri. It may be cold outside, but you’re relaxing your body and soul in about 130 degree Fahrenheit, mineral-rich bubbling water. Folding and placing the towel on your head is a custom. Cost: 1,000 yen.
paragraph2: As you carve through the powdery slopes of Niseko, Japan, you'll want to cap off your day with a quintessential après-ski ritual: a soak in a geothermal hot spring, or onsen. Join the locals at Yugokorotei, a public bathhouse nestled within a ryokan in Annupuri, where you can unwind in a serene outdoor setting. But first, be sure to follow Japanese etiquette by bringing a modesty towel and soap, and cleansing thoroughly before entering the communal pool. Note that bathing suits are not allowed, and the onsen is gender-separated. As you settle into the 130-degree Fahrenheit mineral water, sourced from Mount Annupuri, you'll feel your muscles relax beneath the wooden pergola, surrounded by snow-covered boulders. For a mere 1,000 yen, you can indulge in this rejuvenating experience, a perfect way to round out a day on the slopes. So come and immerse yourself in this tranquil Japanese tradition.

paragraph1: Political disagreements within families can strain relationships, making it crucial to maintain respectful dialogue rather than resorting to hostile exchanges. When family members repeatedly attack each other over political views, it crosses into bullying territory, creating deep wounds that can be difficult to heal. A notable example is the relationship between a former Biden administration official and her mother, whose story illustrates how complex family political dynamics can be navigated successfully. Despite being Black, Southern, and deeply religious, the mother voted for Trump primarily due to her strong anti-abortion stance. Her daughter, though actively involved in progressive politics, chose to understand rather than condemn her mother's position. Their ability to reach a mutual understanding, despite fundamentally different political views, demonstrates how families can maintain loving relationships even when they disagree on significant issues. This approach of empathy and respect proves far more constructive than perpetual conflict and antagonism.
paragraph2: But it doesn’t mean cudgeling her with them. Once you’ve said your piece and listened to what she has to say in her defense, repeating the same arguments over and over would be the act of a bully. Citizens, let alone family members, shouldn’t be eager to direct vitriol against people whose political views they don’t share. If the rest of your family wants to go on doing that, you should tell them that they’re being unkind and unhelpful. Partyism is a morally debased form of political discourse. A friend of mine who is active in progressive politics and served in the Biden administration has a mother who voted for Trump. The mother, who is Black, Southern and religiously devout, is a single-issue voter: She’s fervently opposed to abortion. My friend deeply disagrees with her mother’s position but finds it intelligible. They’ve made their peace.

paragraph1: Forgive me for wondering: Is he referring to “an eye for an eye” or the stoning of disobedient children? Either way, for both Trump and true believers, it hardly matters that the First Amendment was intended to protect religion from the state, not to have the state impose a religion. (So much for originalism.) Their goal is to impose one form of religion, Christianity, and the underlying message is that those who do not share it will have to submit. Not only have such moves been declared unconstitutional (“I can’t wait to be sued,” Landry said), but they are also exclusionary and offensive to many. Despite what the Christian nationalist movement would have you believe, America was not founded as a Christian nation. Nor is it one today. In a pluralistic country, neither the Bible nor Judeo-Christian values are universal, including in the two heavily Christian Southern states in which these laws were passed.
paragraph2: Reflecting on the actions and motivations of certain political figures, I find myself questioning whether individuals like Trump and Landry are driven by a literal interpretation of biblical principles, such as "an eye for an eye" or the stoning of disobedient children. Their apparent disregard for the First Amendment, designed to protect religion from state interference, is deeply concerning. It seems they are advancing an agenda that aligns with the Christian nationalist movement, which erroneously claims that America was founded as a Christian nation. However, this perspective overlooks the pluralistic foundation of our country and the constitutional prohibition against imposing a single religion. Such actions are not only unconstitutional but also exclusionary and offensive, particularly in the Southern states where these laws have been enacted. They undermine the diverse fabric of our nation and threaten the freedom of religion that is supposed to be a cornerstone of American democracy, disregarding the rights of those who hold different beliefs.

paragraph1: The two of you could tell them, during an adults’ evening together, that the heavy demands of work and raising children and running a house don’t lend themselves to impromptu visits. You need a few days’ notice. One of you could add that it would be a big help if they sometimes took the kids out when they visited — to a museum, for instance, or for ice cream — so you could catch up on other work. Now, your husband may be unwilling, initially, to establish this new (but totally reasonable) boundary with his parents. Many people dislike friction. In that case, tell him you will do so yourself, but it may create more antagonism that way. Still, let’s hope your husband rises to the occasion: Having a busy job does not entitle people to foist their parents onto others.
paragraph2: You and your husband need to have an honest conversation with his parents about establishing clear boundaries for their visits. While you understand their desire to spend time with the family, it's essential to explain how you're juggling work commitments, childcare responsibilities, and household management. Request that they provide advance notice before dropping by, which will help you better plan and prepare for their visits. Consider suggesting that they could occasionally take the grandchildren out for activities, providing you with some breathing space while fostering their relationship with the kids. Though your husband might be hesitant to address this issue due to his aversion to conflict, it's crucial that he takes the lead in this conversation rather than leaving it to you. Having him communicate directly with his parents will prevent potential resentment and ensure a healthier family dynamic moving forward.

However, this perspective overlooks the pluralistic foundation of our country and the constitutional prohibition against imposing a single religion. Such actions are not only unconstitutional but also exclusionary and offensive, particularly in the Southern states where these laws have been enacted. They undermine the diverse fabric of our nation and threaten the freedom of religion that is supposed to be a cornerstone of American democracy, disregarding the rights of those who hold different beliefs.

Paragraph 2:
Forgive me for wondering: Is he referring to “an eye for an eye” or the stoning of disobedient children? Either way, for both Trump and true believers, it hardly matters that the First Amendment was intended to protect religion from the state, not to have the state impose a religion. (So much for originalism.) Their goal is to impose one form of religion, Christianity, and the underlying message is that those who do not share it will have to submit. Not only have such moves been declared unconstitutional (“I can’t wait to be sued,” Landry said), but they are also exclusionary and offensive to many. Despite what the Christian nationalist movement would have you believe, America was not founded as a Christian nation. Nor is it one today. In a pluralistic country, neither the Bible nor Judeo-Christian values are universal, including in the two heavily Christian Southern states in which these laws were passed.

paragraph1: When you visit the vibrant Wharf, it feels like stepping into a world of local creativity and culinary delight. Begin your adventure at Shop Made in DC, where the shelves brim with unique products crafted by local artisans. You'll find stylish T-shirts from Bailiwick Clothing, intricately designed maps by Terratorie, and adorable cherry blossom onesies by Mirasa Design, each item a testament to the local talent. As you continue your exploration, make sure to reserve a table at Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant offering a delightful twist on traditional cuisine. Savor the exquisite flavors of hummus adorned with Maryland blue crab falafel or indulge in the crispy fried Brussels sprouts paired with grapes and mint yogurt. To ensure you don't miss out on this culinary experience, it's wise to book your meal at Ilili at least a week in advance.
paragraph2: Back at the Wharf, drop into Shop Made in DC, which spotlights Washington-based artisans. You’ll find “202” (the city’s area code) and “The District vs Congress” T-shirts by Bailiwick Clothing, illustrated maps of local neighborhoods by Terratorie, and tiny onesies covered in cherry blossoms by Mirasa Design. Then stroll to Ilili, a Lebanese restaurant on the waterfront with colorful fixtures made in Lebanon, such as laser-cut metal doves suspended from the ceiling and dining chairs with hand-sewn floral designs. You’ll see local twists on the cuisine, like the hummus ($13) that can be topped with Maryland blue crab falafel ($8). Don’t miss the fried brussels sprouts with grapes and mint yogurt ($18), and a plate of riz (Lebanese rice, toasted vermicelli, Marcona almonds and cashews, $11) to accompany the heaping mixed grill for two ($76). Book a week ahead.

paragraph1: Lodging Boston’s most talked-about, trendy accommodations is the Verb Hotel (1271 Boylston Street; theverbhotel.com; from $249), a renovated Howard Johnson’s in the shadow of Fenway Park, whose rooms and public spaces are decorated with manual typewriters and relics from Boston’s rock ’n’ roll history. Some rooms have patios overlooking the courtyard pool. Right off Boston Common, with views of downtown and the Charles River, is the elegant high-rise boutique Nine Zero Hotel (90 Tremont Street; ninezero.com; from $245), with 190 rooms. For a posh jailbreak, try the Liberty Hotel (215 Charles Street; libertyhotel.com; from $275); once the Charles Street Jail, the 298-room hotel features five bars and dining spots and a captivating, multitiered lobby.
paragraph2: In Boston, three distinct hotels offer unique experiences for visitors. The Verb Hotel, situated near Fenway Park, captivates guests with its trendy accommodations and rock 'n' roll-themed decor, including manual typewriters. Some rooms even feature patios overlooking the courtyard pool, providing a laid-back atmosphere. Near Boston Common, the Nine Zero Hotel stands as an elegant high-rise boutique establishment with 190 rooms, offering stunning views of downtown Boston and the Charles River. Meanwhile, the Liberty Hotel, once the Charles Street Jail, has undergone a luxurious transformation. Now a 298-room hotel, it boasts five bars and dining spots, with its striking multitiered lobby serving as a testament to its rich history and modern elegance.

paragraph1: Closing arguments in the trial began on Thursday in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia and are expected to last two days. The Justice Department has taken aim at Google’s search business, claiming the company illegally extended its monopoly by forging default search deals with browser makers, such as Apple and Mozilla. Google has said that the contracts are legal and that its innovations have broadened competition, not constricted it. Peter Schottenfels, a Google spokesman, said in a statement that the Justice Department’s case “is deeply flawed.” On Thursday, Judge Amit P. Mehta stress-tested the Justice Department’s and Google’s arguments in court. He prodded the Justice Department on its assertion that Google’s market power had hindered its search engine’s innovation or quality for consumers. “I’m struggling to see how I could reach findings of fact that would say, ‘Google has not done enough,’ or ‘Google’s product has worsened over the course of 10 years,’ in such a way that I could say it’s because of lack of competition,” Judge Mehta said. He also questioned Google’s assertion that it faced competition from sites like Amazon, where consumers go to search for pricing and other results while shopping, saying the average person would see a difference between Google and Amazon.
paragraph2: The landmark antitrust trial between the Justice Department and Google reached its culmination as both sides presented their closing arguments in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. At the heart of the dispute lies the Justice Department's accusation that Google has unlawfully maintained its search engine dominance through exclusive default agreements with major tech companies, particularly Apple and Mozilla. Google's defense team staunchly maintains that these contractual arrangements are entirely legal and argues that the company's continuous innovations have actually fostered competition in the digital marketplace. Peter Schottenfels, speaking on behalf of Google, dismisses the government's case as fundamentally flawed. Judge Amit P. Mehta has demonstrated keen engagement throughout the proceedings, challenging both parties' positions with pointed questions. He has expressed particular skepticism regarding the Justice Department's assertion that Google's market dominance has suppressed innovation, while also questioning Google's claims about facing significant competition from platforms like Amazon. The case represents a critical juncture in determining the boundaries of digital market power and the interpretation of antitrust laws in the modern tech landscape.

paragraph1: “Small Things Like These” plays just a little like a gangster film, except the web of power at its center is spun by nuns. Set in 1985 and based on Claire Keegan’s 2021 novel, it is a story about how people create and maintain control and the many shades of complicity that result. In this case, the setting is southeast Ireland, and the nuns’ control has woven its way into every aspect of life in a small town. Bill Furlong (Cillian Murphy) sells and delivers coal and fuel in that town, an occupation that barely supports his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and a house full of daughters. But they’re doing OK. He can put food on the table, and they have a happy home life. One day, however, something changes inside Bill: He sees a young woman being nearly dragged into a building near the local convent, and it troubles him. He suspects that she is pregnant and unmarried, like his own mother was, and is being brought to the nuns by her horrified family. She is, quite literally, kicking and screaming. Bill can’t stop thinking about her.
paragraph2: In the quiet, rural landscape of southeast Ireland in 1985, a subtle yet profound transformation is underway in the life of Bill Furlong, a humble coal and fuel seller. Played with nuanced intensity by Cillian Murphy, Bill navigates the intricate web of relationships in his small town, where the nuns wield considerable influence over the community. At home, Bill finds comfort in the loving companionship of his wife, Eileen (Eileen Walsh), and their daughters, their modest means notwithstanding. However, the tranquility of Bill's existence is disrupted when he witnesses a disturbing scene: a young woman, suspected to be unmarried and pregnant, is forcibly taken into a building near the local convent. The woman's desperate resistance and evident distress leave an indelible mark on Bill, stirring a deep sense of empathy and recognition. As he grapples with the implications of what he has seen, Bill's thoughts turn to his own mother's past, and the seeds of a quiet rebellion are sown.

paragraph1: When I was a child, opening the next package felt like a treasure hunt. As I grew older, it began to feel like something far more fundamental, like air or community, something like prayer. Her messages met me like guideposts in a dark forest; if her words couldn’t point the way, at least they offered the comfort of knowing someone had been there before. A decade after I lost my mother, my father followed suddenly. She had spent years preparing her exit, but with him I blinked, and he was gone. The morning of his memorial, the box stared back at me with nothing to say. There was no letter for this. I tried to conjure her voice but couldn’t. My father left no clues or letters. The only parenting I would have, from 22 on, was in the box. When I hit 30, the nearly empty box sat in my Brooklyn apartment, clashing with the furniture. Only those three packages remained: Engagement, Wedding, First Baby. They sat in their shiny cardboard and pink ribbon, expectant, waiting.
paragraph2: Opening packages from my mother was always an adventure, a treasure hunt that filled my childhood with wonder and excitement. These carefully wrapped gifts evolved into something far more profound - they became my lifeline, as essential as the air I breathed and the community that surrounded me. But life had other plans, and the sudden loss of both my parents left me adrift at twenty-two, with no more guidance to come, no more letters to anticipate. All that remained was a box of my mother's packages, a tangible connection to her love and foresight. Now, at thirty, I live in my Brooklyn apartment with this box that grows lighter with each passing year. Inside, only three unopened packages remain, each wrapped in shiny cardboard and tied with pink ribbon, waiting for life's biggest moments: Engagement, Wedding, and First Baby. These final gifts stand as silent guardians of future milestones, holding within their carefully preserved wrapping the last pieces of maternal guidance I'll ever receive.

paragraph1: How much of Mariko do you carry with you? I still get emotional talking about her journey. There was an interview I did after the episode when she dies was aired, and I called her “Mariko-sama” for the first time, which you never do. It’s like calling myself “Miss Anna.” I felt that, almost unconsciously, I was saying goodbye to her. While I was filming it, I didn’t understand the intensity of what I was mentally going through, and how much it had affected me, but it speaks volumes now. I want to approach all my projects the way I approach Mariko.
paragraph2: As I reflect on my time playing alongside Mariko, I'm struck by the depth of our emotional connection. In an interview after her poignant on-screen departure, I caught myself referring to her as "Mariko-sama" - a term of reverence that slipped out unexpectedly, like a subconscious farewell. Only now do I realize the profound impact her journey had on me, a resonance that went unnoticed during filming. I'm left with a sense of awe and gratitude for the experience, and a renewed commitment to approaching future projects with the same level of dedication and emotional investment that Mariko inspired in me.

You are given two pararaphs of writing for a given instruction.

Paragraph 1:
How much of Mariko do you carry with you? I still get emotional talking about her journey. There was an interview I did after the episode when she dies was aired, and I called her “Mariko-sama” for the first time, which you never do. It’s like calling myself “Miss Anna.” I felt that, almost unconsciously, I was saying goodbye to her. While I was filming it, I didn’t understand the intensity of what I was mentally going through, and how much it had affected me, but it speaks volumes now. I want to approach all my projects the way I approach Mariko.

Paragraph 2:
As I reflect on my time playing alongside Mariko, I'm struck by the depth of our emotional connection. In an interview after her poignant on-screen departure, I caught myself referring to her as "Mariko-sama" - a term of reverence that slipped out unexpectedly, like a subconscious farewell. Only now do I realize the profound impact her journey had on me, a resonance that went unnoticed during filming. I'm left with a sense of awe and gratitude for the experience, and a renewed commitment to approaching future projects with the same level of dedication and emotional investment that Mariko inspired in me.

paragraph1: A comprehensive study led by Sarah Mills, an assistant professor at the University of North Carolina's School of Public Health, delved into the ramifications of menthol cigarette bans across various regions, including Canada, the European Union, and specific U.S. states like Massachusetts. The researchers meticulously reviewed existing studies, smoking rates, and cigarette sales data. Their analysis revealed that implementing a menthol cigarette ban would likely have a pro-equity impact, significantly decreasing smoking rates among Black individuals more than other racial or ethnic groups. This finding underscores the potential for such a ban to contribute to reducing health disparities linked to smoking. By targeting menthol cigarettes, which have been disproportionately marketed to Black communities, policymakers could effectively address smoking-related health inequities. This conclusion aligns with broader public health objectives aimed at promoting equitable health outcomes across diverse populations.
paragraph2: The study analyzed the effects of bans in other countries, including Canada and some in the European Union, as well as bans in force in states, including Massachusetts. The researchers reviewed studies, smoking rates and cigarette sales as part of their analysis. “Our review found that a menthol ban will have a pro-equity impact, meaning that we expect smoking to reduce the most among Black individuals who smoke as compared to other racial or ethnic groups,” said Sarah Mills, lead author of the study and an assistant professor at the University of North Carolina school of public health. paragraph1: The anime industry is also trying to capitalize on the interest from athletes. Crunchyroll, a streaming service dedicated to anime, enlisted the N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson to serve as an awards show presenter and teamed with the N.B.A. on clothing. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, said athletes with large followings were great ambassadors for the genre as it continued to push into the mainstream. “All of those old myths and concerns about, ‘What will people think if I tell them that I watch anime?’ go away because if this person that is a celebrity and really famous athlete is talking about it, then it’s OK for every one of us to talk about it,” Purini said. “It’s a very important thing for the medium.” While Turner was a rookie with the Rams last year, he watched anime on team flights and proudly wore “Jujutsu Kaisen” shirts. Although it is rare for defensive linemen to reach the end zone, he is still planning additional ways to celebrate his off-field interests. “The ones that know it, they’ll pick up on it and it’ll be super-cool,” said Turner, who plans to act out Naruto’s “shadow clone jutsu” if he ever scores a touchdown. After he makes a cross signal with his fingers, two teammates will pop out behind him, mimicking the character’s mystical ability to spawn doppelgängers.
paragraph2: The anime industry is increasingly tapping into the star power of athletes to broaden its appeal and reach new audiences. Leveraging their massive followings, these sports figures are becoming influential ambassadors for anime, dissolving outdated stereotypes and helping to mainstream the genre. Crunchyroll, a leading anime streaming service, exemplifies this strategy by involving prominent athletes in their promotional efforts. For instance, N.F.L. player Aidan Hutchinson has been featured as a presenter at an awards show, while the platform has also collaborated with the N.B.A. to create exclusive clothing lines. Rahul Purini, the president of Crunchyroll, emphasizes the effectiveness of these partnerships, noting that athletes can connect with diverse audiences who may not traditionally engage with anime. Turner, a rookie with the Rams, embodies this trend with his unabashed enthusiasm for anime. He frequently sports "Jujutsu Kaisen" shirts and is eager to bring his passion to the field. Turner plans to celebrate any future touchdowns by performing Naruto's iconic "shadow clone jutsu," a testament to his dedication and the cultural crossover between anime and sports. Through these collaborations, the anime industry is not only expanding its fanbase but is also reshaping perceptions, proving that anime can be a mainstream cultural phenomenon embraced by fans and athletes alike.
